PETITION.TITLE: Census
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:
That the current practice of destroying the Census is denying future generations an invaluable and irreplaceable resource of data on medical, historical, social, scientific, and demographic factors.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:

Request the Government to review its current policy of destroying the Census; and support a proposal to retain the census forms for release for specific research purposes in either 70 or 100 years time.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Bourne(from nine citizens)and Senator Calvert(from 14 citizens)

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned strongly opposes any attempts by the Australian government to mine uranium at the Jabiluka and Koongara sites in the World Heritage Listed Area of the Kakadu National Park or any other proposed or current operating site.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate oppose any intentions by the Australian government to support the nuclear industry via any mining, enrichment and sale of uranium.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned recognises the vital role of a strong and comprehensive Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and asks that:
1. Coalition Senators honour their 1996 election promise, namely that "The Coalition will maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC".
2. The Senate votes to maintain the existing role of the ABC as a fully independent, publicly funded and publicly owned organisation.
3. The Senate oppose any weakening of the Charter of the ABC.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Calvert, Sen Paul; MacGibbon, Sen David
PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are the only Australians to be deliberately excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) for honourable `active service'. Australian Archives records show that the only reason for the exclusion was to save money. Members of the Australian Army and Air Force serving in Malaya were not excluded, and the costs associated with the land forces was one of the main reasons for the exclusion of the Navy. An injustice was done which later events have compounded.

There are two forms of benefits for ex‐servicemen, Disability Pensions for war caused disabilities (denied the sailors referred to but introduced in 1972 for `Defence Service' within Australia) and Service Pensions. Allied veterans of 55 nations involved in conflicts with Australian forces until the end of the Vietnam War can have qualifying eligibility for Service Pensions under the Act. Service by 5 countries in Vietnam was recognised after RAN service in Malaya was excluded. The Department of Veterans' Affairs confirms that 686 ex‐members of the South Vietnamese Armed Forces are in receipt of Australian Service Pensions; 571 on married rate and 115 on single rate. In effect, 1,257 Service Pensions, denied to ex‐members of the RAN, are being paid for serving alongside Australians in Vietnam.
It is claimed that:

(a) Naval personnel were engaged on operational duties that applied to all other Australian service personnel serving overseas on `active service'. They bombarded enemy positions in Malaya and secretly intercepted enemy communications;

(b) Naval personnel were subject to similar dangers as all other Australian service personnel serving in Malaya and there were RAN casualties, none of which appear on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial;

(c) the Royal Australian Navy was `allotted' for operational service from 1st July 1955 and this is documented in Navy Office Minute No. 011448 of 11 November 1955, signed by the Secretary to the Department of the Navy. The RAN was then apparently `unallotted' secretly to enable the excluding legislation to be introduced;

(d) the Department of Veterans' Affairs has said it can find no written reason(s) for the RAN exclusion in the Act. In two independent Federal Court cases (Davis WA G130 of 1989 and Doessel Qld G62 of 1990) the courts found the two ex‐members of the RAN had been `allotted'. Davis had served in Malaya in 1956 and 57. As a result of these cases ex‐members of the RAN who served in Malaya and who had, at that time, claims before the Department of Veterans' Affairs for benefits, had their claims accepted. Eight weeks after the Doessel decision the Act was amended to require allotment to have been by written instrument. In parliament, it was claimed the amendment was necessary to restore the intended purpose of the exclusion, reasons for which can not, allegedly, be found.

(e) Naval personnel were not, as claimed, bound by the `Special Overseas Service' requirements, introduced in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962. This Act became law some two years after the war in Malaya ended;

(f) as Australian citizens serving with the Royal Australian Navy they complied with three of the four requirements for `active service'. The fourth, for `military occupation of a foreign country' did not apply to Malaya.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act thereby restoring justice and recognition of honourable `active service' with the Royal Australian Navy in direct support of British and Malayan forces during the Malayan Emergency between 1955 and 1960.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Calvert(from five citizens)and Senator MacGibbon(from nine citizens)

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Public Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned members of staff of the Australian Public Service (APS) express strong dissatisfaction with the Government's current approach to workplace relations in the APS, especially its intention not to negotiate an APS‐wide Agreement on pay and conditions of service. The undersigned believe that any agency level agreements should be subordinate to an APS‐wide agreement on common core conditions, negotiated on their behalf by experienced union negotiators. The undersigned are opposed to the use of Australian Workplace Agreements in the APS.

Your petitioners request that the Senate take the strongest measures it can to persuade the Govern ment to agree to negotiate on an APS‐wide basis, including serious consideration of the Log of Claims of the Community and Public Sector Union. Your petitioners further request that the Senate closely scrutinise the Government's consultative process for revising the APS Act, and rigorously oppose any amendments to the Act which would fragment and weaken the ability and morale of the APS to maintain its high level of service to the Australian people.

PETITION.TITLE: Native Title
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned requests that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples of this country are treated justly and fairly. It is in the interest of all to build this nation in a spirit of reconciliation and cooperation with Australians of diverse racial and ethnic backgrounds.

We call on you to ensure that regional agreements with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples are pursued in good faith, so as to determine their rights to their land in a spirit of reconciliation.

The co‐existence of Native Title and Pastoral Leases on Crown Land is supported by legal principle and historic fact, upheld by the High Court. The people and Governments of Australia have a moral responsibility to give this fact real and just effect.
We call on members of the Senate to ensure that legislation regarding Native Title
(i) complies with internationally recognised principles of non‐discrimination; and
(ii) promotes Reconciliation with Australia's first peoples.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament Assembled.

We the undersigned residents of Australia draw the attention of the House to the fact that incidents of racial discrimination in the period between February 1996 and February 1997 doubled during the same period for the previous year.

We would further like to draw your attention to the 1997‐1998 Federal Budget, which foreshadows a cut to the budget of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission by more than 40 per cent over the next two years.

Your petitioners therefore request that the House resolve to reverse the decision to cut the budget of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commis sion, so that it can carry out its role effectively, that is, defending the human rights of all people in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Paper
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the alleged dumping of cheap imports of coated woodfree paper onto the Australian market by 14 countries.

Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate to be aware of the crisis facing the pulp and paper industry in Tasmania and take any action possible to prevent entry into Australia of dumped paper from overseas countries.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Convention
PETITION.PARA: To The Honourable The President and the Members of The Senate in the Parliament Assembled

The Petition of the undersigned shows that on the 24th June 1997, the Senate rejected the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill 1997 in its original format and sought to amend it for the second time.

The undersigned Petitioners support the Government's proposal that the vote for delegates to a Constitutional Convention be on a voluntary basis and without penalisation of anyone who wishes not to vote, for this is a vote note carrying any legal consequence. A voluntary vote will also determine the actual interest of the electorate on this issue.

We believe that the Government acted in accordance with the mandate given to it by the People at the last General Election and that the Senate, in rejecting the Bill in its original format, are in so doing rejecting the wishes of the People.

Your petitioners request that the Senate support the passage of the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill 1997 in its next reading without amendment and thereby allow the People of Australia an opportunity to put forward their views and to have put before them, in a proper and equitable format, the issues for and against the proposals to change to a Republican system of Government.

PETITION.TITLE: Darwin to Adelaide Railway
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia showeth that:
We are concerned with the outstanding debt owed to South Australia by the Commonwealth Government of Australia for South Australia's investment in Northern Territory.
Payment of this debt was to be in the form of a railway line from Darwin to Adelaide as a legislated agreement passed by Parliament in 1910 called the Northern Territory Acceptance Act 1910.

We have waited 87 years for the Commonwealth Government to honour and complete its obligation to the citizens of South Australia, and your petitioners therefore pray that this House will take all appropriate steps to ensure the fulfilment of this obligation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate the remaining sector of an adjournment debate speech I made last night, which was not completed.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
1997 cotton production has achieved over $1.2 billion of revenue.

Comprehensive studies will be undertaken in relation to economic viability. It is estimated that direct employment would be available to 3,000 people and 7,500 would benefit from indirect jobs. New business opportunities will be available for service and support industries and from improved public service and infrastructure expansion.
There would be no direct cost to the state and the success of the project will result in $900 million of export income per year.
Comprehensive studies will also be undertaken in social areas.

There would be greater family security because of future job opportunities generated for the younger generation and young people of the West Kimberley won't have to move to Perth for employment purposes as jobs would be available in the region. There would also be an added boost to the tourist and scenic value of the region in that tourists will be able to go on day trips to see how cotton is grown, harvested and processed.
Studies will also be conducted in the areas of technology and environmental sustainability.
Australia has a climatic advantage for irrigation, and crops such as cotton, rice, sugar and wine grapes have been very successful Australian export industries.

As previously stated, the West Kimberley has abundant water and consistent high temperature that will allow a diverse range of other crops such as sugar, horticultural crops, and tropical fruits to thrive. And further processing opportunities will be examined for these crops.
In addition, the Kimberley pastoral industry will be boosted by the availability of feed from by products and rotational crops that may allow value adding through local meat processing.

I would also like to state that a research station (subject to the EIS) will be constructed in the West Kimberley and managed by CSIRO, Agriculture WA and WAI to research all agronomic and associated environmental aspects of production.

In addition, the West Kimberley will be introduced to new sophisticated technologically advanced systems and this is expected to achieve new international benchmarks in environmentally sustainable agriculture. For example, the use of sub‐surface irrigation tape will be used to achieve maximum water use efficiency. Water applied `fertigation' application of nutrients and the development of the industry away from the Fitzroy River floodplain will avoid the use of flood irrigation and flood levee banks will not be required.

Chemical applications have been reduced in the West Kimberley by the use of Monsanto INGARD transgenic cotton varieties, and the implementation of CSIRO's Insect Pest Management (IPM) technique is expected to also contribute to reduced chemical dependency.
It is very important to understand that it is not proposed to grow cotton on the Fitzroy River flood plain, so there is no possibility of polluting the river with chemicals from cotton crops.
Trials of Roundup‐Ready plant varieties are expected to reduce herbicide applications.
Comprehensive studies will also be conducted into the effects that the damming of the Fitzroy River will have on Aboriginal Australians.

WAI's policy is to achieve a negotiated agreement with the traditional people; respecting their laws, customs and traditions. Studies will be undertaken in full consultation with Aboriginal representatives. I am advised that WAI have had cooperative discussions with the Kimberley Land Council about this project and that discussions are also being held with other interested Aboriginal groups such as with Dickie Skinner of the Council of Elders.

Currently, unemployment of indigenous people in the West Kimberley is of a very high level. Many Aborigines are dismayed by the current welfare dependency. Participation of Aborigines on the project will depend on choices made by them, but opportunities for work will be plentiful. Presently, because there are so few career and job prospects, there is little incentive for young Aboriginal people to maximise or even undertake education instruction. WAI will apply particular emphasis towards initiating educational training and work experience programs for young Aboriginal people and will enlist the support of schools, TAFE, Skillshare and local University campus to institute educational material that is relevant to future career prospects.
There are likely to be other economic and business opportunities for members of the indigenous community which WAI will encourage.

Given the evidence that I have placed on record in the Senate, contrary to what Senator Murray stated, a thorough appraisal of the damming of the Fitzroy River is being carried out and the study will fully demonstrate how strong economic growth coupled with significant net benefits will be delivered.
The West Kimberley has the prospect of becoming Australia's food and fibre powerhouse and the proposed damming of the Fitzroy River is a very positive step in this direction.
Thank you Madam President.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Proposed Joint Select Committee on the Australian Republic

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of Senator Bolkus, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, he will move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a joint select committee, to be known as the Joint Select Committee on the Australian Republic, be appointed to inquire into and report, by the last sitting day in March 1998, on the following matters:

PARA.TAB: The desirability of Australia becoming a republic with an Australian as Head of State and the process by which that might best occur, including:
(a) the circumstances and the timeframe in which the move to a republic might occur; and
(b) the most appropriate republican model to be put to the Australian people at a referendum.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) That, in considering these terms of reference, the committee shall include (but shall not be limited to) consideration of the following models:

PARA.TAB: (a) the model advanced by the former Prime Minister, the Hon. Paul Keating, in his response to the report of the Republic Advisory Committee ('the minimalist option');
(b) the establishment of an executive Presidency ('the maximalist option'); and
(c) the model advanced by the former Governor of Victoria, Mr Richard McGarvie ('the ultra minimalist option').

SPEECH.PARA: (3) That the committee shall convene a public forum in December 1997 to canvass the principal alternatives for an Australian Republic and shall present an interim report setting out the options.
(4) That, after presentation of the interim report, the committee shall then engage in a series of public consultations throughout Australia on the options identified in the interim report.
(5) That the committee may make recommendations for evidence to be presented directly to either House.

(6) That the committee consist of 4 members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Government Whip or Whips, 2 members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Opposition Whip or Whips, 2 senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 2 senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, one senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats and one senator to be nominated by any independent senators.
(7) That every nomination of a member of the committee be forthwith notified in writing to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives.
(8) That the chairman of the committee be elected by and from the members of the committee.

(9) That the committee elect a deputy chairman who shall act as chairman of the committee at any time when the chairman is not present at a meeting of the committee, and at any time when the chairman and deputy chairman are not present at a meeting of the committee the members present shall elect another member to act as chairman at that meeting.
(10) That, in the event of the votes on a question before the committee being equally divided, the chairman, or the deputy chairman when acting as chairman, have a casting vote.
(11) That 8 members of the committee constitute a quorum of the committee.
(12) That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of 4 or more of its members and to refer to any subcommittee any matter which the committee is empowered to examine.

(13) That the committee appoint the chairman of each subcommittee who shall have a casting vote only, and at any time when the chairman of a subcommittee is not present at a meeting of a subcommittee the members of the subcommittee present shall elect another member of that subcommittee to act as chairman at that meeting.
(14) That the quorum of a subcommittee be a majority of the members of that subcommittee.

(15) That members of the committee who are not members of a subcommittee may participate in the proceedings of that subcommittee but shall not vote, move any motion or be counted for the purpose of a quorum.

(16) That the committee and any subcommittee have power to send for persons and documents, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private during any adjournment of the Senate and the House of Representatives, and have leave to report from time to time.
(17) That the committee be empowered to print from day to day such documents and evidence as may be ordered by it and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.
(18) That a message be sent to the House of Representatives acquainting it of this resolution and requesting that it concur and take action accordingly.

(19) That, in the event that the Senate does not receive a message from the House of Representatives by 4 September 1997 concurring with this resolution, the matters identified in paragraphs (1) and (2) then stand referred to the Legal and Constitutional References Committee for inquiry and report by the last sitting day in March 1998.

SPEECH.PARA: INDIGENOUS EDUCATION (SUPPLEMENTARY ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1997
The bill provides for this government's commitment to two initiatives.

The first is its commitment to lift the requirement for at least 10% of enrolled students to be indigenous before a non‐government non‐systemic preschool, school or vocational education and training institution can be funded under the indigenous education strategic initiatives program (IESIP).

The amendment leaves in place the requirement for there to be a minimum of 20 students in a non‐government non‐systemic school and a non‐government non‐systemic vet institution and for there to be a minimum of 5 students in a non‐government non‐systemic preschool. These limits will avoid the administrative expense of providing small amounts of money to small numbers of scattered students. It will also avoid the situation where there will be little or no benefit to individual students from the provision of small grants.

This amendment will enable institutions where there are significant numbers of indigenous students, but these students represent less than 10% of total enrolments, to qualify for funding under the act. Experience has shown that the 10% requirement has excluded some institutions from receiving supplementary funding in respect of their indigenous students.

The second amendment will permit the adjustment of grants under the indigenous education strategic initiatives program in line with cost increases, for the period up to 30 june 2000. The appropriations for these years are in subsections 13B(4), (5), (6) and (7) in the principal act. Inclusion of a cost supplementation provision in the principal act will bring the program into line with other education programs.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
TRANSPORT LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (SEARCH AND RESCUE SERVICE) BILL 1997

The purpose of this bill is to amend the Australian Maritime Safety Authority Act 1990 (AMSA Act), Air Services Act 1995 (Airservices Act) and Civil Aviation Act 1988 (Civil Aviation Act) to facilitate the amalgamation of the Commonwealth's civil maritime and aviation search and rescue coordination functions into one national centre. The bill also amends the AMSA Act to increase the number of ordinary members on the Board of AMSA and make the appointment of a Departmental officer to the Board discretionary.

Australia's civil search and rescue coordination functions are presently divided between state/territory Police Services, industry and volunteer groups and at the Commonwealth level, between two agencies, Airservices Australia (AA) and the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA).

The effectiveness of search and rescue coordination activities relies on successful communication between these agencies. One of the first acts of this government last year was to initiate an independent review into the costs and benefits that could arise from a rationalisation of the Commonwealth's civil search and rescue functions. The review was to also recommend on the best administrative organisational model and location of a search and rescue coordination centre.

The review concluded that the present dual Commonwealth civil search and rescue coordination system lacks a clear and unified strategic and operational focus, with no clear accountability for systems failures. The report recommended the establishment of a single civil search and rescue coordination centre to be managed by AMSA.

The minister for Transport and Regional Development announced on 15 January this year the establishment of a new national centre for the coordination of civil maritime and aviation search and rescue. This centre will bring together the search and rescue coordination functions of AA and AMSA. The national centre, to be called "AusSAR, the Australian Search and Rescue Organisation", will be located in Canberra and managed on behalf of the Federal Government by AMSA.

Search and rescue functions will be better coordinated and more effective through improved communications and responsiveness under the new centralised structure. This initiative will strengthen Australia's already formidable international reputation in search and rescue. Both AMSA and AA support this amalgamation.
Amendments

The amendments to the AMSA Act make clear that in addition to its present maritime search and rescue service, AMSA will also provide an aviation search and rescue service. The provision of the amalgamated service will be performed in a manner consistent with Australia's obligations under applicable international conventions.

The Airservices Act will be amended to reflect the transfer of responsibility for aviation search and rescue to AMSA. AA will continue to manage any liabilities that arise out of its present provision of search and rescue services.

The Civil Aviation Act will be amended to enable the Civil Aviation Safety Authority to continue to have a role in setting safety standards and making regulations relating to the performance of search and rescue services by aircraft.
AMSA Board

The bill also increases the number of ordinary members on the AMSA Board from three to four given the increased responsibilities of AMSA and to enable the appointment of a member with aviation experience. This is consistent with the government's aim that members of Boards have relevant experience.

The AMSA Act will also be amended to make the appointment of a Departmental officer to the Board discretionary. This will provide the minister with the flexibility to appoint a Departmental officer for specific periods where particular expertise is required.
Transitional Arrangements

The bill makes arrangements for the transfer to AMSA of assets associated with AA's search and rescue function. The value of these assets is to be determined by the minister following independent valuation. The assets transfer will not be subject to capital gains tax.
The transitional arrangements also enable the minister or his delegate to transfer rights under contracts from AA to AMSA.
A regulation‐making power will provide for regulations to be made in relation to transitional matters arising from the transfer of the search and rescue function from AA to AMSA.
HEALTH INSURANCE (PATHOLOGY SERVICES) AMENDMENT BILL 1997
The Health Insurance (Pathology Services) Amendment Bill 1997 gives effect to several Government initiatives relating to Medicare benefits for pathology services.

This bill would allow the Governor‐General to make Regulations to give the Health Insurance Commission power to directly impose penalties for the less serious infringements relating to pathology. It is envisaged that the proposed system of penalty notices, operating in a similar manner to traffic infringement fines, would enable the Commission to deal more efficiently and expeditiously with these infringements.

The bill also makes an amendment to the licensing scheme for the collection of pathology specimens. It introduces a requirement that the owner of a licensed collection centre must at all times display a notice clearly visible from the outside, to let the public know that the centre is licensed. The bill increases the maximum penalty for infringement from $100 to $1000, to be in line with other penalties relating to collection centres. The intention of this is to provide a deterrent to the operation of unlicensed collection centres and to protect consumer interests.

Currently, the Act restricts pathology providers from entering into arrangements for the occupation of premises with medical practitioners or entrepreneurs, except for the establishment of licensed collection centres, accredited laboratories, or the rendering of professional services. The aim is to prevent arrangements that constitute inducements to medical practitioners. An amendment in this bill clarifies the wording of the provision to establish beyond doubt that professional services must be performed by the pathologist in person. In other words, the arrangement cannot be one where the medical practitioner receives payment for providing, for example, storage space to a pathologist.

The bill also seeks to streamline administration of approvals for accredited pathology laboratories, approved pathology practitioners and approved pathology authorities. These are renewed annually, or very three years in the case of the laboratories. Currently, Medicare benefits are not payable where these approvals lapse simply as a result of administrative carelessness on the part of the pathology provider, for example, posting the application forms a few weeks after they are due. This can result in major financial losses to the pathology provider and in patients being deprived of Medicare benefits. The amendment will allow backdating of approvals in limited circumstances, to ensure that Medicare benefit payments are not disrupted in instances that do not warrant it.

The measures we are introducing in this bill are important to the maintenance of the Pathology Agreement which was introduced in the 1996‐97 Budget, and which limits pathology expenditure under Medicare to pre‐determined levels. They will strengthen the Agreement by reducing inappropriate practices which undermine its basis. They have the support of the pathology profession.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency Bill which the Senate is considering proposes to appropriate the funds and to issue the securities to effect Australia's membership of the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency, commonly known as the MIGA. The Treasurer, Mr Costello, signed the MIGA convention, which is contained in schedule 1 of the bill, on behalf of Australia on 30 September 1996. This act, though significant, did not attract much attention back in Australia. The reason for this was that his trip was the embarrassing first trip to the US for the new Treasurer—the trip where the world got to know Mr Costello as an indiscreet Treasurer, amongst some other characteristics that have become apparent in respect of his behaviour in recent times.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will remember that the Treasurer had a meeting with the Chair of the Federal Reserve, Mr Alan Greenspan, wherein they discussed, amongst other things, the future prospects for US interest rates. Mr Costello then, very improperly, divulged the contents of that meeting and the market‐sensitive information arising from the meeting to a group of journalists. Mr Michael Stutchbury, writing in the Australian Financial Review, correctly realised the significance of the Costello indiscretions and reported them on page 1. The rest is history.

We then had the embarrassing scene of the Australian Treasurer trying desperately to disavow the report. Then a tape of the meeting surfaced, showing clearly that the Treasurer had fibbed in his earlier denials of the reported contents of the interview, where he had described the original report as `fanciful'. In the meantime, the Treasurer, Mr Costello, had moved world bond markets significantly, ensuring that billions of dollars changed hands. Not even you, Senator Kemp, could accomplish this.Indeed, the pressure became so great that the Treasurer had to cancel—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry, I think you should withdraw an earlier comment. You were probably waiting for me to say it, but I think that the—
—Which comment was that?
—I think you talked about the Treasurer fibbing.
—Sorry. `Terminological inexactitude' is what I should have referred to.
—I knew, Senator Sherry, that you would probably have a response, but I do think you should withdraw that.

—I totally withdraw the allegation that the Treasurer fibbed. It was a terminological inexactitude that rocked the world on that occasion. We all know Senator Kemp avoids terminological inexactitudes. He avoids everything.

SPEECH.PARA: The pressure became so great that the Treasurer had to cancel a planned press conference because of the huge international embarrassment he had become. That is very unfortunate in the context of this important piece of legislation we are considering now. The other events, which I have referred to, did overshadow his signing this very important agreement on behalf of Australia.

I think the headline from the Melbourne Age of 3 October 1996 summed up the matter very well—`Costello gaffe echoes around the world'. We have recently seen the Treasurer's next foray into international affairs with the embarrassment at the South Pacific Forum economic ministers meeting. This time it was not loose lips that embarrassed the Treasurer but sloppy organisational practice. Again Australia's reputation is diminished because of amateurish procedures and incompetence. Needless to say, the signing of the MIGA convention was overshadowed somewhat due to the Treasurer's indiscretions. However, the matter is finally before the Senate and the bill is supported by the Labor opposition.

MIGA is an institution of the World Bank. It was established in 1988 by international convention. Its purpose is to foster foreign investment in developing countries and transitional economies by providing insurance against various risks and advisory services, such as legal advice, concerning the facilitation of foreign investment. These services complement the programs and activities of other international institutions such as the World Bank, the International Finance Corporation and the United Nations Industrial Development Organisation.

MIGA was created on the premise that investors, especially in projects in developing countries, were inhibited by fears of non-commercial risks and lack of local knowledge and technical assistance. MIGA could assist these investors by issuing guarantees, including co-insurance and reinsurance against non-commercial risks in respect of investments in a member country which flow from other member countries. MIGA can offer protection against losses arising from non‐convertibility of currency but not devaluations and various other risks, such as losses of ownership or control over the investment, losses arising from an inability of the investor to enforce a court decision concerning an investment contract against the host country and losses arising from damage to tangible assets arising from disturbances, including revolution, terrorism and sabotage.

From its inception until 1996, MIGA has considered 215 projects. Forty developing countries have benefited from these projects and more than $US15 billion of direct foreign investment has been generated from investment guarantees issued by MIGA. This means jobs and opportunities for often the most disadvantaged peoples in the world. Eradicating poverty in the world, which I am sure is a shared goal of all members of this Senate, means facilitating economic development throughout the developing world. MIGA provides one piece of the international frame work to facilitate increased economic investment by assisting investors to have the confidence to invest in nations which are considered to have significant sovereign risk.

There are 128 developing countries of MIGA and 21 industrial country members or signatories to the convention, including all of the G7 nations. As well as assisting the laudable aims of MIGA, Australian membership should also assist Australian firms doing business—for example, through obtaining an MIGA guarantee or through obtaining political risk insurance. I say as an aside that this is one aspect that some critics of our international involvement often do not choose to highlight. In addition, Australian membership should be viewed positively by other nations in terms of fulfilling our international development obligations.

The total cost of the shares in MIGA are around $25 million, of which 10 per cent will be paid in cash in 1997‐98, a further 10 per cent by way of promissory note, with the balance being a contingent liability which is on call if required. The bill appropriates the necessary moneys under clause 4 and authorises the issue of securities under clause 5.

In 1993, the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade concluded that the benefits of joining MIGA were in excess of the costs and that therefore Australia should join. I reiterate the economic advantages of being a member of MIGA exceed the economic costs. That is obviously as well as the important contribution MIGA makes to assisting in the eradication of poverty in those 128 countries.

I would ask Senator Kemp at this stage if he could confirm for the Senate the financial implications of the legislation for future Australian governments. Specifically, is it correct that the maximum amount of additional contribution beyond the $2.5 million pledged in cash and the $2.5 million to be covered by promissory notes is actually around $20 million? I reiterate the Labor opposition's support for the passage of this legislation as swiftly as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: —The development of the global economy means that Australia must direct its foreign affairs policy towards not only protecting our own interests but also working with other governments to ensure a cooperative approach to solving common problems. A few of those common problems include controlling international speculation, ending the exploitation of women and children, protecting the environment, raising workplace health and safety standards, solving the growing refugee problem, addressing the growing global levels of unemployment and income polarisation, reducing the concentration of economic and technical power and ending the use of the land mines. These problems can only be overcome by governments working together to set the national and international standards under which the new global game will be played.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is a middle ranking power and there is obviously a limit to what it can do. Australia can, in fact should, take a stand on these important matters of great principle. This is the spirit in which I propose to move an amendment to the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency Bill.

This bill proposes to appropriate funds and to issue securities to affect Australia's membership to the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency. The MIGA is an institution of the World Bank and it is designed to foster foreign investment in developing countries by providing insurance against risks and by providing advisory services regarding foreign investment.

Australia signed the MIGA in September 1996. That was after the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade recommended that we join the MIGA because the benefits outweighed the costs. Those benefits which they nominated included the encouragement of economic growth, that membership would provide part of the rationale for our policy on overseas aid and, importantly, that it also provided for facilitated commercial opportunities for Australian business operating in developing countries.

When the foreign affairs white paper is tabled today by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) it is likely to recommend that Australia focus its energies to expand our relationship in Asia. Presumably, this will refer to a growing economic relationship. Considering the dreadful damage that the government has inflicted on our people-to-people relationships with Asia through the closing down of Radio Australia's Darwin transmitter, it really cannot be anything else.

With this growing economic focus, the Democrats believe that Australian business must take responsibility for ensuring that our investments and the employment practices of Australians working overseas recognise the rights of workers and the need to protect the environment. The federal government should make it clear to all Australian businesses operating overseas that it expects that they shall act at all times in a manner consistent with international human rights and in accordance with Australian domestic law.

This will not be news to my fellow members of the foreign affairs and human rights subcommittees of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade because it is something that I raise with them all the time. In fact, it is something for which I have, I am sure, a good deal of sympathy inside that committee.

If Australian workers are protected by occupational health and safety rules and regulation in this country, then why should Australian businesses be allowed to drop those standards merely because they are operating offshore? Similarly, if Australian companies have to undertake an environmental impact statement before they undertake, for example, infrastructure development in this country, then why should those standards for environmental protection not be undertaken in overseas developing countries, especially those whose rules and laws are not consistent with our minimum standards?

This is not only for the protection of the workers or for the protection of the environment of those developing countries within which Australian businesses seek to operate. These standards would also indicate that Australia is still a good global citizen, willing to comply with at least minimum standards for workers and environmental protection. That is something that we need to reinforce very much at the moment. So those are the reasons why I am moving my amendment to the second reading motion of the bill today. I therefore move:
At the end of the motion, add:

"but the Senate is of the view that all Australian companies operating overseas should adhere to the minimum environmental and occupational health and safety standards that would apply to the company in Australia or to a company registered and operating in the relevant country".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency Bill is designed to accept an international convention and join the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency, a part of the World Bank institutions. The agency is intended to protect foreign investors—and that should be understood as private sector investors—by insuring them against various risks. The idea is that foreign investment is the same as development and that what is good for Union Carbide is good for Bhopal.

SPEECH.PARA: The World Bank hardly has an unblemished record on human rights and environmental issues, even in its own programs. It has supported large infrastructure projects which have resulted in hundreds of thousands of people being forcibly relocated from small subsistence farms to urban shantytowns. It has supported numerous badly planned projects, such as dam projects that did not fulfil their objective of providing good physical infrastructure because they were poorly planned and silted up quickly. They did not fulfil their social objectives: they mostly provided power for exploitative industries at subsidised rates while not providing any substantial benefit to ordinary people, resulting in dislocation of large numbers of people and the flooding of communities.

The dams were also frequently environmentally destructive, again due to poor planning, not only destroying waterways that were biotically important and affecting things like fisheries as far as the ocean but also being reservoirs of disease, creating conditions downstream which favoured parasites that live in the snails of slow moving waters. In relation to dam projects, schistosomiasis seems to be something of an environmental disease that continues to affect people.

BREAK.PARA: The World Bank's poor environmental and social record has resulted in various cosmetic and, later, serious efforts to make their loans and the projects that they supported less environmentally and socially malign. They even had Herman Daly, as well‐known theorist in the area of ecologically sustainable economics, on their staff to monitor their performance. He remained highly critical during his time at the bank. He decried their lack of action and resources for their environmental unit and their failure to apply the environmental standards they had developed as criteria for loans in their own activity.

I think they have made some improvements since Daly's time, but they are not huge. There has been substantial criticism of the World Bank for its support of the International Monetary Fund and the IMF‐like structural adjustment policies requiring the wind‐back of regulation governing foreign investment and imports, and requiring cutbacks in the delivery of availability of social programs like health, education and the provision of clean water. So it is with reservation and suspicion that I see that this agency will be administered by the World Bank.

The agency is part of a push to protect the investments of global companies and to allow them to invest in ways that give little or nothing back to recipient nations. Most of the international measures in trade fora, such as the World Trade Organisation's consideration of trade‐related investment measures—TRIM—and APEC demands, particularly by the United States, try to force nations to eliminate any regulation of foreign investment through the use of the trade sanctions cudgel. Along these lines, we have seen the United States push for Australia to eliminate the Foreign Investment Review Board, in spite of the totally innocuous and ineffective nature of that organisation.

In the so‐called developing world, the push for freedom of foreign investment takes the form of restrictions or prohibitions on any nation requiring a company extracting forest to actually do some of the downstream processing in the country. They prohibit any requirement for a percentage of profit to be reinvested within the nation where profit is made. They prohibit any requirement by a so‐called sovereign nation to say that goods produced in a country must be made available at competitive prices within that country. They prohibit any restriction on the transfer of assets or profit.

On the other hand, we are told by the same World Trade Organisation that we cannot apply similar environmental or sustainable process standards on imports as we do on our own products because that would be infringing on the sovereignty of other nations. Though this is administered by the World Bank, the investments they wish to eliminate risks from—using donations from Australia and other developed countries, paid for by their citizens—are private sector investments made on a for‐profit basis. They are not development assistance. They are not in any way or form in order to benefit the people of the country in which the investments are being made.

We see in the criteria for eligible investments, article 12, that investments can be new greenfield investments. They can be investments to modernise, expand or develop existing investment. They can therefore be used for something like CRC expanding an HCFC plant in China, even though China produces excellent, indigenously developed refrigerants that do not add to global warming. Under 12(c)(ii) guaranteed expenditure can be any use of profit within the country, presumably from the non-use of the term, whether or not that use is investment.

The things that the agency must satisfy themselves about, as included in 12(d), are minimal. An investment must be economically sound, that is, be likely to turn a profit. It must not be a criminal operation. That is reassuring given that their risks are being guaranteed by the taxpayers of the so-called developed world. It is nice to know the World Bank will not support drug cartels or sale of female sex slaves, at least where those are open purposes of investment.

Another criteria is that the host country already has a legal framework prohibiting most of the things this agency is supposed to prevent the risk of, that is, legal protection of the investment. A fourth criteria is that the investment be consistent with the declared development objectives and priorities of the host nation. Now that criteria has some potential to assure there is some benefit to people. It depends how it will be interpreted. Unfortunately, the World Bank has never been strong on these issues.

The World Bank does, however, have criteria and guidelines for social impact, social justice and equity, environmental protection and ecologically sustainable development. We hope that our government will argue that these be explicitly included in the criteria for giving a private sector investment a multi-governmental public sector guarantee against economic risk. We think that the World Bank, in all of its agencies and institutions, must be made much more responsible and its policies applied more consistently and transparently.

A second element we seek to see as a criteria is that investors should apply the standards of environmental protection, occupational health and safety and public health and safety at the level required in their home countries or standards which apply in the country whose standards are highest, where a company is equally at home in several countries. I do not think this is a lot to ask. These investors are being presented as worthy of international support on the basis that they are part of the international development effort. But today's international development effort takes account of the legitimate social goals of nations receiving assistance and stresses the need for measures that reduce absolute poverty, increase equity and specifically help the poorest people and communities. It takes account of the relationship between poverty and environmental degradation, and exploitative investment. It embraces the principles of ecological sustainability in some form or other.

It is therefore entirely inappropriate to support the sort of investment based on reduced costs because there are lower standards of protection. Part of the principles of development is the application and transfer of improved technology, particularly technology which makes a project safer; safer for workers, safer for the public around a plant and safer for the environment on which the poor in a developing nation depend far more heavily than those in developed nations. The principle of profit maximisation through exploiting lower standards in a poor country runs diametrically opposite to these principles of development.

In that respect, I would like to point out that one of the stated objectives of this agency is—from page 20, line 8—to seek to remove impediments, in both developed and developing member countries, to the flow of investment to developing member countries.

We have Bhopal as one of the major testaments of profitoriented investment. This agency, with its guarantees, would, on my understanding, insulate Union Carbide from India's attempts to wrest some compensation from them. If India sought to freeze accounts or hold profits and assets in the country, that is precisely the sort of risk this agency would protect a corporate investor from and it would use Australian money, and the money of other developed nations, supposedly provided for development purposes, in order to do this. This is not a fanciful scenario; these things are happening.

This agency would protect investors against risk—including companies like BHP, RTZ/CRA, Western Mining or Century Zinc—in investments like Ok Tedi, Bougainville or Mindanao. Any attempt by nations involved to prevent the repatriation of profits, even to assure that they do not just flee pending a court action, would seem to be covered here under article 11(a)(i) which guarantees against loss resulting from:

. . . any introduction attributable to the host Government of restriction on the transfer outside the host country of its currency into a freely useable currency or another currency acceptable to the holder of the guarantee, including a failure of the host government to act within a reasonable period of time on an application by such holder for such a transfer.

In other words, this first measure is insurance against a company having its financial assets frozen. The second is a guarantee against having any material assets or activities frozen in any way. Work at Ok Tedi could not be ordered to stop for an investigation, since it would:
. . . deprive the holder of a guarantee of his ownership and control of, or a substantial benefit from, his investment.

In addition, the fourth measure would insure Bougainville Copper against their economic loss from the civil disturbance there, in spite of the fact that they are heavily implicated in the disturbance and the conflict started in 1988 as protest against environmental degradation and social loss from the mining venture.

I know the rhetoric is about arbitrary moves by dictatorial leaders of banana republics, but this is more about making sure big transnationals do not ever lose a cent. What is not recognised is the inequality of power in relationships between global companies and the poor. I know that, in many cases, it is the governments of those companies which are very much involved in those decisions. That does not make it any better.

For years now, we have had reports from South America and other countries of poor people, often displaced from their land, living in tin shacks amidst industrial effluent and heavily polluted land, seeing their children born with outrageous levels of birth defects, and people of all ages suffering from industrial diseases and cancers. Even when these people know they have a high chance of having children born without limbs or with various disorders, often both serious or irremediable, they move in because, when development of a dam, ranch, mine or forestry operation eliminates their farm and the farms of all their neighbours, there is nowhere else to go. These industrially blighted areas hold the potential of a job which may mean the capacity to survive, although the very low wages do not give a capacity to do much more than survive in the shantytowns. This picture is, after all, what developing world poverty is about. It is these kinds of situations that have created the passions of Susan George or Jacabo Schatan.

The developing world can easily be the Navaho‐Hopi reservation in the US south-west, where the wonderful offer of jobs and opportunities in the uranium mines around Redrock resulted in the premature death of virtually all the adult men in the town. The United States government then tried to cover the embarrassment by demanding that the widows move away to Flagstaff or some other major town before they got a pension. The Widows of Redrock campaign was born—the Navaho women's fight to stay on their own land, among their own people. That campaign was about the right not to be moved away, but the underlying theme was the utter contempt with which these people were treated, due to the ability to overlook a number of occupational safety and public health laws since it was on an Indian reservation.

The big free trade push of the last decade put a new wrinkle in this situation. We have seen situations in North America where the opening of the border between the United States and Mexico and the institution—though perhaps imposition would be more accurate—of a free investment regime has meant that a very large number of industrial enterprises moved from the United States to Mexico. They did not move deep into established Mexican population areas, but just across the border, so the managers could continue living in Texas, Arizona or California. The goods produced could be immediately sent to their intended market, which was the United States.

The industrial estates—in which the United States environmental laws did not apply, where waste was simply dumped into the surrounding countryside and rivers—became known as the Maquiladoras. I remember vividly an article about a relocated Zenith plant which makes colour TV picture tubes. It had moved from the United States. The author of the article talked with US workers who had lost their jobs and who had seen not only their own plant shut down and disappear but also many of the other industries in town.

The article also interviewed Mexican workers who lived in shanties near the factory, very near to waste tips. The workers talked about industrial diseases and the effects of being exposed to the chemicals that line picture tubes. They were not that ignorant, just poor and powerless. They knew that a job in a Maquiladora was one of the few opportunities they had to feed their families, and they were not going to imperil that by com plaining too loudly about wages and conditions.

Not long after that article, a year or so, there were news reports from southern Texas of whole towns where suddenly a very high percentage of babies began to be born with serious congenital birth defects. By serious, I mean born with part of their brain and spinal nerve chord exposed. Nearly all of the problems were nervous system skeletal development problems, and the cause was found to be pollution in the rivers from the waste of Maquiladoras across the border in Mexico.

Are these the kinds of investments we are seeking to protect? Both the United States and Mexico used the rhetoric of development for pushing to create this sort of situation. I know that a clause in the covenant about being consistent with the development goals of a host country system is not going to prevent such investment. So we have here a program to use Australian taxpayers' money in the name of development to guarantee corporate investors against risks and loss in such operations. Do people really wonder why I do not consider this kind of bill non-controversial?

Occasionally, people speaking for their party—these are parties which blindly support the free trade agenda—accuse me of not wanting poorer nations to develop. I think it is fine for them to develop. I do not consider it development when poverty forces poor people to live in working conditions which imperil the life and health of workers, their families and children in order to bolster corporate profits and make one gang of corporate capitalists slightly more competitive so that they can try to take over the market from their mates and win the market share or profitability game. That is what it is—it is a game for them.

I do not consider it development when this destructive exploitation of the poor and developing countries is used as a club to destroy living and working standards in so-called developed countries, including our country, or to prohibit any discrimination which recognises the cost imposed by allowing exploitation of people and nature to create competitive advantage.

I just do not buy the explanation that the developing nations are underpolluted and poor families in India, Brazil or Mexico who live near these industrial towns need to have one child in four born with serious pollution-caused congenital diseases. I do not accept that situation made as a result of imperilled survival. Inequalities of power established by social relations of poverty equate to free choice.

The focus of both the Democrats' second reading amendment and my substantive amendments are simply to require that, if it is set up in the name of development, it should not be supporting the kind of situation where unsafe practices are used to disastrously exploit poor developing nation workers which, in turn, is used as an argument to reduce wages and conditions for battling workers in the north. My amendment goes a bit further and asks that the environmental standards be applied to avoid situations such as the Ok Tedi and Bougainville disputes. I will continue my remarks during the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency Bill and to briefly sum up the second reading debate. We welcome some of the remarks, but we do not agree with some of the other remarks that have been made.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say that, though I welcome the general comments by Senator Sherry, I think it is a pity that an otherwise fairly good speech was diminished by the pathetic pot shots he took at the Treasurer (Mr Costello). It is fascinating with the Labor Party in that it has a shadow Treasurer in the other place who will not ask the Treasurer a question. When he raises his head, he is promptly sent packing. So what happens is that we have a former shadow assistant Treasurer getting up in this chamber and taking pathetic pot shots at the Treasurer.

What we do know is that Senator Sherry will never have the chance to move this nation on any particular issue, and I make no concession on that topic. I think that I said he diminished an otherwise useful contribution to this debate with those earlier remarks. I am sorry he is not in the chamber, because I was going to take this opportunity—but I guess I will take it later—to commiserate with the fact that he was dropped as shadow assistant Treasurer. I guess I will save those commiserations for another debate. It is a bit of a pity that they keep on moving Senator Sherry around. They never seem to be able to find a place for him but, as I said, I will take the opportunity on another occasion to express my regrets to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'd be careful!
—I supported Senator Sherry as shadow Assistant Treasurer—we like to have him in that position. We strongly supported him there, Senator, so therefore there is a degree of sincerity in my remarks.
—People in glasshouses shouldn't throw stones.
—Senator, you were not in the chamber for the start of this debate when a pathetic little stone was thrown over here—it has now been returned! You were not here for the start of the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency Bill 1996 is an important bill. Membership of the MIGA will be of undoubted benefit to Australia. The government will not be supporting the second reading amendment which, I understand, Senator Bourne has moved. Nor will we be supporting the amendment which I understand will be moved by Senator Margetts.

All MIGA insured projects are reviewed to ensure that they are financially sound and that they satisfy World Bank environmental standards and comply with the environmental laws of the host country. The MIGA convention does not give the MIGA the authority to get involved in domestic political issues, and so it does not.

Once Australia is a member of the MIGA, it will have representation on the MIGA board of executive directors through the representative executive director at the bank. Australia would be able to raise any environmental concerns regarding MIGA operations in that context. Australia's concerns about the environmental aspects of World Bank and Asian Development Bank supported projects are already dealt with in this way, and that provides a mechanism for responding to sensitive policy matters. As I said, we will not be supporting Senator Margetts's amendment.

Senator Sherry asked if I could confirm the figures he raised. I am able to say that, as I think was outlined fairly clearly in the second reading speech, Australia will be providing $2.45 million in cash, a further $2.45 million as a promissory note, and the remainder of Australian dollars—$19.6 million—on call. Of course, these Australian dollar amounts may fluctuate with changes in the Australian‐US dollar exchange rate. These US dollar amounts are the maximum authorised by the bill, which reflects the convention establishing the MIGA. In conclusion, I commend this important bill to the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 2, page 1 (lines 7 to 9), omit the clause, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 2 Commencement

PARA.TAB: (1) Subject to subsection (2), this Act commences on a day to be fixed by Proclamation.

(2) A Proclamation is not to be made under subsection (1) until the Council established under Article 30 of the Convention amends Article 12 of the Convention to provide for the following requirements for eligible investments:

TAB.TAB: (a) compliance of the investment at least to the standards on environmental protection, occupational health and safety, and public health and safety found in regulation within the investor's home country; and

(b) compliance of the investment with all formal or internal criteria and guidelines of the World Bank on protection of the environment, ecological sustainability, and social justice, as if it were a World Bank loan.

SPEECH.PARA: The Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency is subject to an international covenant. We therefore cannot amend it or any of its clauses, except for the commencement. The only options available to us are to accept this or reject it.

I give notice now that, unless my amendment is passed, I will oppose the bill. I do not believe in giving private sector for profit investment any guarantees unless there is a responsible development agenda. I do not believe in undermining the sovereign right of nations to effectively decide on regulation and management of foreign investment when we claim that we can do nothing for the environ ment or workers of poor ex‐colony nations because it violates their sovereign rights. Does sovereignty apply only when it is for maintaining high levels of exploitation and never when it comes to social and environmental protection?

I am aware that this measure creates a guarantee only for non‐commercial risks. My problem is that these are defined to cover virtually any regulatory action a nation might take to make a foreign investment more beneficial to it and any remedial measure it might take in the case of something like the Bhopal disaster. This is irresponsible, particularly as it totally ignores the need to address the fact that, in the global market, competitive advantages are created by the lack of consistent measures to ensure economic activities are ecologically sustainable and beneficial for people.

It is particularly irresponsible because it dovetails efforts through the World Trade Organisation to undermine any unilateral action by nations to ensure that their imports, competing with products for which appropriate environmental standards are developed, are not advanced in market terms simply because they are produced or extracted unsustainably. We are not allowed to discriminate against unsustainably harvested tropical timber. This is a disgrace.

The measures are also particularly irresponsible because they dovetail with efforts through the World Trade Organisation to undermine any unilateral action by nations to ensure that their domestic products are not subject to unfair competition based on the exploitation of child labour, bonded labour or prison labour such as that of the notorious Chinese laogai camps. Political and social prisoners are forced to work for many years making hardware and other products, including diamond brand products, that flood our hardware stores.

We have been prevented from dealing unilaterally on these issues, which are basic issues of global responsibility and human rights. Now we are preventing nations from effectively attempting to regulate foreign investment. Make no mistake: a nation may still be allowed to do something like freeze assets, but this will be fairly ineffective if the assets are guaranteed by an international agency like MIGA. This is a corporate agency, not a development agency. It has nothing whatsoever to do with decreasing poverty.

The international labour standards issue is a large one. The agenda of the major international agencies—the World Trade Organisation, the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank—are all in opposition to it. My amendment would say that, before even thinking of supporting this covenant, Australia should at the very least ensure that it is in accord with the very basic guidelines and criteria of the World Bank designed to ensure that development is not destructive.

Before Australia supports this covenant, we should ensure that the covenant requires corporations to use good environmental management technology and practices and should use decent public and occupational health and safety measures, as it does in developed countries. This would apply equally to all corporations wanting a MIGA guarantee to all competitors seeking that protection for investment. Of course it is not giving anybody an unfair advantage unless they wish to operate outside that. It is a measure designed to ensure that free investment in a global economy, if it is to be considered development, must raise the level of protection within developing countries, not translating to an excuse for corporations to lower their technical standards of safety and protection.

I see this covenant as part of the push for more free ranging corporate power at the expense of civil and political power. I see it as part of the battle between a vision of competitive economic warfare with the winners writing the rules and a vision of human and humane development which includes providing for ecological survival. The intention of this covenant is right in line with the World Trade Organisation, IMF and World Bank push for dominance of global capitalists. My amendment seeks to subvert this covenant and make it part of the struggle represented by the United Nations, UNCTAD, and UNCED push to ensure that all people on earth can live sustainably in peace and with material sufficiency.

BREAK.PARA: Let me remind honourable senators that these assurances, these standards, that have been agreed by the United Nations come very slowly over a long period of time and Australia, with all of the other nations who are members of the United Nations, has been part of this process. It is not something that we are imposing on other nations; it is something that the nations of the world in the United Nations have agreed to. There is a war of world values going on. I know which side I am on, and I commend my amendment to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will be supporting Senator Margetts's amendment, which is very similar to ours. We live in hope that the next time we go for the same thing we will get it.
