PARA.EMPHASIS: House of Representatives reasons for disagreeing to Senate amendments 1 to 8 and 10 to 68—
Senate Amendment Number 1

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Amendment proposes a preamble be included which specifies the role of the Convention and the appointment and election of delegates to the Convention. The House of Representatives does not accept the Amendment, as it does not reflect the purpose and scope of the Bill.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Senate Amendments Numbers 2-8 and 11-68

PROCTEXT.PARA: These Amendments focus on the method of voting for half of the delegates to the Constitutional Convention which will meet for 10 days in December 1997 to consider the question of whether or not Australia should become a republic. The Amendments require that voting in the election be by a compulsory attendance ballot, which will make Australians who choose not to vote in the election for delegates liable to prosecution and add up to $20 million to the cost.

The Amendments also propose that the election be conducted along the lines of a Senate election. In light of the large number of candidates which could contest this election (possibly exceeding 200-300 candidates in New South Wales) a pure Senate "style" election would make it difficult for electors to vote for someone other than a group, and would extend the time needed to count the vote.
Accordingly, the House of Representatives opposes these Amendments (Numbers 2-8 and 11-68).

PARA.EMPHASIS: Senate Amendment Number 10

PROCTEXT.PARA: This Amendment provides that candidates' $500 nomination fee should be returned if the candidate is elected or the candidate/candidate group receives at least 4% of the total number of votes. Given the Government will be providing a tax deduction for election expenses up to a limit of $1,000 to candidates, whether successful or not, the House of Representatives does not accept Amendment Number 10.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night when the debate was interrupted I was pointing out that the National Party is very much in favour of the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill 1997 , although it is well known that the National Party opposes voluntary voting and the majority of the party and the party's position is for the continuation of the constitution as it stands at the moment. I put those two issues very firmly on the record.

SPEECH.PARA: The government went to an election with a very clear proposal that we have a convention and that the convention be made up of a number of elected delegates—a number of women, a number of Aboriginals, a number of young people; a good mix representing all sections of the Australian community. I think the government has been very honest. It is no secret where the Prime Minister's position is on the constitution. He has continued to progress this bill, although he could have very easily said, `All bets are off. We have put it up twice; it has been rejected twice so just let it disappear into the ether.' But he has not. He has met his commitments, not once, not twice but now three times.

The Labor Party seems to be holding out. I cannot quite understand this. I usually can follow the logic of the Labor Party, but it seems to be holding out on some spurious objection that this is a sort of stalking horse for non-compulsory voting for the rest of Australia. There is a very big difference in voting for a government—voting for 148 members of parliament, voting for 76 senators—that is going to stay in office for three years and govern the nation. If that were the proposal I would not be supporting non-compulsory voting, but that is not the proposal.

The proposal is that we elect 36 delegates to the convention and that the convention sit for approximately 10 days at some time in the future. There is a huge difference between compulsory and non-compulsory voting for a convention and for the election of a government. Therefore, I have no hesitation in supporting this bill. I am on the record as a very strong supporter of compulsory voting.

We went to the election and we came up with a convention that would give fair proportional representation to all Australians. The opposition's obstruction to this is very hard to understand. I believe they are denying the people a say in the progress of the Constitutional Convention. They are denying the opportunity for democracy to work.

The latest proposal of the Australian Democrats is to have a Senate committee go out and take evidence right around Australia. I thought that was an absolutely stupid idea, and I thought it was one that only the Democrats would come up with. But not to be outdone by stupidity, the Labor Party proposed exactly the same thing this morning. It just shows that you really do need the big man on the frontbench. I do not think he would allow you to get into so much trouble. Senator Robert Ray is a good tactician. If he was on the frontbench, I would find it very difficult to see how this would ever happen.

If the proposal of the Senate inquiry is to work, where is the appropriation going to come from to go to a referendum, or to put the yes or no case, or to have the election? It is just a nonsense. It is just a grandstanding nonsense that will absolutely drive this debate nowhere. The objection of the Labor Party to non-compulsory voting or voluntary voting is very hard to understand when they elect their own delegates on non-compulsory voting or voluntary voting. ATSIC delegates are elected by voluntary voting. Senator Nick Minchin nominated a few other points, particularly that Senator Kernot gets elected to her leadership of the Australian Democrats by a voluntary vote of all members.

In short, it is very difficult to understand where the Labor Party and the Democrats are coming from on this issue. It is a denial of what was put forward in the policy of the then opposition that we would have this convention when we gained government. It is a convention that will appoint 40 parliamentary delegates made up of 20 state and territory delegates and 20 federal parliamentary delegates, and 36 non-parliamentary delegates including groups such as Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders and representatives from local governments, and at least 10 will be between the age of 18 and 25.

So that is a pretty broad church that will be able to get in there and debate this issue if this bill goes through. It will be able to come up with whether or not Australia should become a republic, which republic model should be put to the electorate to consider against the status quo, and the time frame and the circumstances under which change may be considered.

I think that is very commendable. It should go to a convention where a whole number of issues can be debated by people that are able to put some research in. That will no doubt be reported on by all the major newspapers and television stations. That message will go out. No doubt there will be a case put for the constitution to remain the same. There will also be a case put for the republic to take place, but at least it will be an informed debate by all sectors of the community.

The proposal that the Democrats and the Labor Party are putting up today will be just a Senate inquiry going around Australia. It will have no support from the government at all. It will be run by the opposition. If this is to be successful, one way or the other, it has to have the government behind it. It is a complete and utter nonsense to go out there with a Senate inquiry. You are absolutely devaluing the currency of Senate inquiries with this sort of situation. I support the bill on behalf of the National Party. I hope Senator Harradine can bring some sense into the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been agonising over the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill 1997 with colleagues in the Greens party both in Tasmania and the mainland for the last week. We have twice put to the government proposals which would have allowed the convention to proceed with very minor concessions by the government. I spoke with the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) two days ago about this and he was adamant that they would brook no conditions whatever. The strong impression I gained in those talks I had with him and his colleagues, despite their denials, is that they do not want this legislation to pass and that they do not want the republic to progress.

SPEECH.PARA: In my talks with the Greens around the country, there have been great misgivings about whether I should vote to ensure that the convention does proceed. I thank everybody who has expressed those misgivings but who have ultimately given me the support to make a decision based on a consensus coming from the Greens around the country.

We have in the Senate at the moment the ranks of those opposed to the republic supporting this legislation and the ranks of those supporting the republic opposing this legislation. They are the ranks of absurdity. Somebody needed to break from those ranks, and I have decided to do so. I have decided to do so in the interests of this nation because Australians want a republic. They want to be involved in the path to the republic. They want a republic as we move into the new century. They want a republic for this nation. They want a republic for the Olympics. To pass this opportunity is to kill those aspirations of the Australian people. I will take it on my shoulders when the critics come out, but I firmly believe that, in the interests of Australians, it was necessary for me to change and to support this legislation, and I will be doing so by supporting this motion.

In doing so, I want to say this: the one thing that the debate and the intransigence on both sides of this Senate indicates is that we need to give the republic back to the people. For all its shortcomings—and they are considerable—this convention is a means of doing that. I hope that the assent to the convention will mobilise all Australians for or against the republic so that they come forward in good faith for this country, express their opinions and become involved in this debate, not simply leave it to the delegates but ensure that their voices are heard as well.

One of the great stumbling blocks put in the way of assent to this legislation has been the formulation post‐election by the government of a postal vote system. I spoke strongly against this matter in the Senate when it was considered before. I have not changed my mind about the fact that there ought to be a full and compulsory vote. We had the situation of two competing principles, both held strongly by the Australian Greens. One was that we should be moving expeditiously to a full and rounded republic. The other was that we should protect the system of compulsory voting, which is so important to Australian elections.

We have to remember that this convention is an advisory body with essentially no powers, except those galvanised through the Australian people and through the republic. We have to remember the impulse, the power of that voice, on government to act and the promise of the government that there would be plebiscites or a referendum if there is consensus before the year 2000. It is not a parliament that is being elected. They are not people who can make definitive decisions. It is a once‐off constitutional convention.

In those circumstances, and knowing that there is no way that this government, or any government in the foreseeable future, has a hope of changing the compulsory voting system while this Senate has the configuration that it does, including the National Party, and opposes such a voting system, it became clear that the republic should not stumble on that impediment placed there by this unwilling Howard government. I am going to support this principle, this once‐only opportunity in this period of conservative governments, to progress the republic.

BREAK.PARA: I feel strongly that we will not see a change to the voluntary voting system. I note that I am not the only one who has changed position on this. The Labor Party has as well. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), as late as March, when this legislation was coming before the parliament, said that he would not block this legislation—shortcomings as it had. Labor is now blocking it, and we Australian Greens are opening a way for it to proceed.

We have to remember also that half the delegates for this convention are to be appointed—no vote at all, not even a free vote. Maybe there has been too little emphasis on the shortcomings of that. I believe that all the delegates to this convention ought to be voted for.

As to the republic, we Greens are concerned that the major parties have their focus too narrow. We want to see this opportunity seized to make changes beyond the head of state for Australia as it moves into the next century. Why should we not take this opportunity to recognise and celebrate the indigenous nation of Australian peoples at the head of the constitution? Why should we not take this opportunity to recognise local government in our constitution? Why should we not make this the opportunity to take into the constitution a bill of rights and responsibilities for all Australians, for this nation of ours, forevermore.

Why should we not recognise the responsibility of the nation and its national parliament and government for the environment of this country and put it into the constitution? It deserves to be there. These are just some of the matters which ought to be on the agenda of the constitutional convention and, as an outcome of that, put to the people of Australia in the plebiscite or referendum that follows.

Indeed, why should we not take up the finding of this parliamentary committee that section 44 of the constitution should be altered to ensure that all Australians have a fair opportunity to stand for parliament? I think most Australians do not recognise that more than a million citizens are denied that opportunity because section 44 puts a question mark over people being able to stand for parliament if they have dual nationality or if they are recipients of an office of profit, including, potentially, even pensions. That is blocking their way to being able to stand for office.

These considerations have loomed hard and high in my consideration. I feel strongly about this. I feel it is the right decision. I feel it moves the roadblock. I again thank my colleagues in the Australian Greens for coming with me down this difficult path to this right outcome for this nation and for 18 million Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating whether we should insist upon our amendments to the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill. The motion that is currently before the chamber is:

SPEECH.PARA: That the committee does not insist upon its amendments which the House of Representatives has insisted on disagreeing to.

I would first of all like to acknowledge the very fine speeches that have been made not only over the last couple of days in the Senate and the House of Representatives but also on the previous occasion that this matter came before us. A considerable amount of thought has gone into all of those speeches. They are interesting reading and have assisted me considerably. I believe everybody is interested in who should be the head of state in Australia. The constitutional convention that is proposed by the government is to consider that matter. The speech by Senator Minchin yesterday was a very strong speech indicating the strength of view of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and Senator Minchin and the cabinet about this particular question and about the right of the people to consider it.

Last night Senator Margetts also made a deeply considered speech. That set me thinking a little bit about what matters would be considered by a constitutional convention if such a constitutional convention or if a parliamentary committee were to go around the place and consider other views. Senator Margetts was saying that there are other matters to be considered which are not included in the agenda in this bill. The agenda of the constitutional convention as set out in this bill would provide a forum for discussion on whether the present constitution should be changed to a republican one; in particular, which republican model should be put to the electorate to consider against the status quo; and, in what time frame and under what circumstances might any change be considered.

Those of you who have studied my speeches on the convention—I suppose none of you have done that, and that indicates your sense—would find that over the years I have been concerned to ensure the preservation of parliamentary democracy as we know it. There should not be further moves—as was proposed by a frontbencher of the Labor Party at the time—to introduce into the constitution by referendum, for example, a bill of rights or measures that would take away from this parliament the duties to be performed on behalf of those who elect us. For example, that would be a broadly based bill of rights which would be able to be interpreted by judges. This country would then have a system of judge made laws, as there is to a certain extent in the United States at this time.

Those are the things that concern me. The issue as is put forward on the agenda—it is a limited agenda; I think the people of Australia believe the agenda should be considered before the year 2000 or around about the year 2000—is, namely, who should be the head of state. That is a very important question. How do we progress this matter? Certain proposals have been suggested. Ultimately, the parliament is the organisation which will have to determine the question that goes to the people. It is the parliament's prerogative—and, indeed, duty—to do that. If there is a constitutional convention, the parliament will no doubt be assisted by what occurs at the constitutional convention and in the lead‐up to the constitutional convention. If not, a suggestion has been made by both the opposition and the Australian Democrats that a committee of the parliament should be established.

My view is that at some stage that will need to take place. At some stage, members of the parliament from all parties, and others in the parliament, should with goodwill consider what provisions ought to be included in a referendum bill. That will have to be done at some stage. It has been put to me, and people have said so in their speeches, that if there is no constitutional convention the puff will go out of the debate on the republic or who should be the head of state. Of course, that is a matter which needs to be considered. I am still concerned about the major questions that have been raised; that is, the precedent that might occur as a result of the voting provisions in this particular bill. That is a very important problem, a very important matter, that has been addressed by everyone in this chamber. It does concern me—I have previously expressed my view on this.

Another matter that does concern me somewhat is the nature of the proposed composition of the convention. Frankly, as we all know, in previous days when there was a constitutional convention there was equality of representation from the states. Clearly, the government has got equality of representation when it comes to politicians, but it does not have that equality of representation when it comes to those who will be elected and those who will be appointed. That does worry me a little bit because this is a specific convention for a specific purpose, but it is not a matter which weighs heavily on my mind.

It is true that under section 128 of the constitution the Senate has the power to vote for a referendum bill and have that bill referred to the House of Representatives. If the House of Representatives rejects that legislation, it is put to them again after three months. If the House of Representatives rejects it again, under the current provisions of the constitution the Governor‐General may put the matter to the people for determination.

There would be a constitutional argument as to whether the Governor‐General could do that without the support of the government. In any event, you do need the support of the government, at least for questions to go to the people. Unless you get that support there will be a negative vote by the people. Look at the history of constitutional referenda in this country. I would not like to be betting on the outcome of constitutional referenda, having regard to the form for the outcome in these matters.

Having regard to all those matters and the need to continue to have public debate about the matter, I am inclined to support the proposition that is currently before us: that we not insist upon the amendments. However, the matter that concerns most people about this is the voting provision under this act. It is of great concern not only to me but also to a broad number of people—probably the majority of the people in the parliament. I expect that that is so.
Under those circumstances, I had discussions with a number of people about this. I am proposing an amendment to the current motion before us—the amendment would be at the end of the motion. It reads:

"but the Senate is of the view that having regard to the fact that the system of voluntary voting provided for in the bill is for the election of delegates to a specific Constitutional Convention for a limited and temporary purpose in special circumstances, the system should not be seen as a precedent for elections of members of parliament or for any other ballots including referendums".

That is the proposition that I am putting to the Senate. I will at a later stage be moving an amendment in the committee of the whole to amend the bill by inserting a declaratory statement that it is not the intention of the parliament that the method of voting for election under this act should be taken as a precedent. I do hope that that will receive the unanimous support of the parliament. It is, of course, for the government to say, but I understand that the government would support the amendment to the motion currently before us and the amendment to the legislation itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite obvious that the opposition would be disappointed with the turn of events over the last 12 or so hours. I have always maintained, and I think people have always had a view of Senate predictability, that trying to work the numbers in the Senate is a bit like dancing with wolves. One can never be certain; one can never walk out of this place knowing that the votes will be okay in the morning; and one can never work out what will be critical in terms of debate.

BREAK.PARA: I do want to acknowledge that Senator Harradine did, in fact, contact me and warn me about what he was thinking, as he has all the way through, I must say, and I am appreciative of that. We will vote for the Harradine amendments. Obviously, we think that it would be a bit naive to expect that they may carry some weight in terms of an ongoing crusade by some to have voluntary voting imported into our system, but I do thank Senator Harradine for the advance notice.

I also take an opportunity to congratulate Malcolm Turnbull for a successful turnabout. We have worked very closely with him over recent months; we have obviously disagreed over latter days, but the resilience of the Republican Movement is such that we are mature enough to continue to work with each other in order to maximise the vote for the republican cause into the future. Senator Brown also has been discussing this with me. From time to time we lost contact, but I am sure he will also be in the cart in terms of the quest for a republic.

We obviously have some firm views about the inadequacies of the government's proposals for the procedures of the convention. We do not think it is the best way to progress the republican issue but, more importantly, we think it is flawed in many ways.

We are now faced with the reality of an election for this convention. In this context, the leader, myself and, in fact, every spokesperson for the opposition, has made it clear that, though we have always thought that this process was flawed, we have said that if it proceeds we would participate in the process as part of the Australian Republican Movement. We would not run our own tickets but we would join with others who are like‐minded in wanting Australia to become a republic, as well as encouraging involvement from other groups. Under the broad umbrella of the ARM, with Democrats, with members of the Liberal Party, with Independents, with Greens and so on, we would work to maximise the outcome. That, of course, will still be our position with the passing of this legislation.

Despite that disappointment, we will be in the cart to maximise the return for the Aus tralian Republican Movement and to ensure that some constructive thinking and constructive agendas are set so that there is a continuation of pressure on government and so that we move towards a republic referendum before the year 2000, and to realise the aspirations of so many millions of Australian people. We will do it with the labour movement, we will do it with the Republican Movement and we will work with other organisations. It has always been our view that the plebiscite was the most appropriate way to go. With the authority of the Australian people expressed in a plebiscite, that sort of impetus would ensure that the republican road was more certain than the one proposed by the government. But we do know why the government is proposing this one; it is because they do not share the conviction that Australia should be a republic.

We will participate under the ARM umbrella and within the ARM umbrella with other organisations. But the focus now is also going to be on the government to make this work—to make it work fairly and to make it work in a way that reflects the views of the overwhelming majority of Australians who have made up their minds on whether Australia should become a republic. We will ensure there is scrutiny so that the appointed members reflect fully the expressions of the Australian public. We will scrutinise to ensure that all Australians have a fair and equal say and that the process is fair.

To ensure that the process is fair, I think that the ultimate test on what the government is doing is twofold: they will have to reach that benchmark of ensuring participation of all the Australian people at all stages of the process. We do not think that they can realise that, but that is the benchmark that has been set for them by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and that is the benchmark that we believe should be the appropriate one and we will ensure that they are tested against it.

The second benchmark against which they will be tested is the fairness of the process. I think the ultimate test there is that the process should and must deliver an outcome which does reflect the overwhelming support by Australians for Australia to become an inde pendent republic by or around the year 2000. They are the two tests that you have set for yourself, Senator Minchin, and they are the two tests that we have set for you as well, and we will ensure scrutiny through the process.

This convention will now be held next year. There is likely to be an election next year as well. I think it is important that this election be held in the lead‐up to a general election. The closer the better, as far as the opposition is concerned, because for us it will focus people's attention on a clear distinction between the unity on our side of politics for a republic and the disharmony, disunity and disagreement on the government side in terms of a republic.

In the pre-election 12-month period pressure will be on the government to ensure that the process is fair and it does not fall apart and that those millions of people who have moved addresses will be contacted and will be able to understand the new system of voting that the government is proposing. The burden is now on the government. We are very disappointed with the outcome. We have been thinking very hard about how to proceed in the event that this legislation got through. We will go back now to work with the Republican Movement to ensure that the outcome that the Australian people want is reflected in this process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats have listened to the speeches of the Tasmanian Green, Senator Brown, and the Tasmanian Independent, Senator Harradine, and have not been persuaded by their arguments. Senator Minchin, we recognise that you have won the day. You have negotiated and achieved the outcome that you desire. I hope and the Australian Democrats hope that the result will indeed be a good one for the Australian people. The Australian Democrats will vote to insist that the Senate amendments be carried despite the fact that we have lost the day.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning to Senator Harradine's two circulated amendments, it is our view that this election will be a precedent and that those amendments are not only naive but also remind us of the Telstra naivety where it was known in advance that the proposal would be rejected by the government. This is a precedent. Because we consider it a precedent we will be voting against both of Senator Harradine's amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate at the outset that the government is prepared to accept Senator Harradine's amendments to the motion I moved at the beginning of the committee stage. As I have repeatedly said, we are dealing with this particular election entirely on its merits. We have pleaded with the ALP and the Democrats to see it in those terms and to examine electoral systems based on the particular circumstances. This is an election of delegates to attend a convention to discuss the question of whether or not Australia becomes a republic. We are not electing a parliament; we are not electing a government. In those circumstances, as is the case with so many other organisations in Australia, the most appropriate method is a voluntary postal ballot. We have done that purely on its merits.

SPEECH.PARA: The argument that has been advanced in this chamber repeatedly that this is somehow some kind of Trojan Horse has always been nonsense. Only this parliament can change the Commonwealth Electoral Act to the previous position that elections be voluntary. The Commonwealth government has no proposition for the parliament to do that. If that question ever arises it should be dealt with on its merits and it would be a decision for this parliament alone. We have always asked the chamber to consider the question of the voting system for the election of delegates entirely on its merits and therefore we have no difficulty in accepting Senator Harradine's amendment to this motion.

I express my gratitude to Senator Harradine and Senator Brown for their decision to now support this motion and presumably the bill. That means that the government and the Australian people can now proceed to have an election of delegates and to have a convention. We would hope to have the election in the latter part of this year and to have the convention itself in the first half of next year.

BREAK.PARA: It is quite true, as many in this chamber have said, that the coalition is not committed to Australia becoming a republic. We went to the Australian people saying that we thought the current constitutional arrangements had served Australia extremely well and that the case for change had not be made out. That was a clear statement of our position. So to attack us for saying that we are not committed to a republic is a nonsense because we made our position quite clear and we got elected on that basis.

Despite that position, we put down a process which we believed would recognise the fact that there are a many Australians who have a contrary view and who want to consider this question. We thought about it long and hard and believe that the process we put up is the best way to involve the Australian people and to resolve the question of whether or not to become a republic and, if so, what sort of republic. The election process we have in mind does give all Australians the opportunity to be involved, but on the principle that they will have the right to choose whether or not to vote for delegates to the convention. That is their fundamental democratic right.

I think that the convention will be a terrific national forum. It will be in Canberra, the nation's capital. Australians from all over the country and from a wide range of backgrounds, experiences and interests can come together to discuss these fundamental questions in, I hope and the government hopes, a very constructive way.

We will be asking the convention to discuss the up-front question of whether or not Australia should become a republic and then, if so, what is the best republican model for Australia. I hope that supporters of the current arrangements, as I am, will constructively engage in that debate and discuss the question of which model is the best for Australia if we are to make the move and also to have the convention discuss the best timing and circumstances under which such a change should be made if it is to occur.

We are quite sincere and positive in our wanting this convention to be a success in that sense. We would not be going through this process of a major national election and a convention if we were not sincere in wanting something constructive to come out of it. My great regret is that we could not achieve this position at the end of June. If we had, we would now be completing the election process and moving towards a convention in December.

The obstruction we have faced in the Senate on this question has meant a six‐month delay in the process and, of course, it has meant that the whole issue was killed stone‐dead by the hands of those who support a republic. As Jeff Kennett quite rightly said during the recess, this whole debate has been killed by the republicans themselves. That is, of course, what panicked Mr Turnbull and the Republican Movement into requesting the Senate to change its position.

The issue completely disappeared because the republicans in this chamber voted to kill it off completely. So I think it has backfired badly on those who have advocated a change to a republic. I think the wiser ones have seen the light and realise that, if we are to progress this debate, we should get on with it.

I am particularly disappointed by the position that the Labor Party and the Democrats have continued to take. They are going to vote against this for the third time. For parties that have actively campaigned for Australia to become a republic, it does seem extraordinary that they would keep on insisting that the process not proceed except according to their rules—an absolute objection to the procedures laid down by the government.

You can legitimately say that you think that the election should be conducted under other rules and argue that case. But, at the end of the day, I would have thought that the government of the nation, having listened to your arguments and rejected them, has the right to proceed to hold the convention based on the rules which it proposes. I accept that in principle you are committed to compulsory voting—a principle that I think is wrong—but to allow your obsession with forcing people to vote, to deny advancing the process of discussing the question of the republic, seems very much the action of an ostrich sticking its head in the sand.

It is clear that Malcolm Turnbull has realised how ridiculous that position is and has pleaded with you all to change your position. We are grateful that at least Senator Harradine and Senator Brown have acted in a responsible manner in wanting to allow the process to proceed.

The arguments against allowing this legislation through simply have not been persuasive. It is one thing to come in and state a position of principle—that you do not like voluntary voting—but to actually vote in a manner to deny the government of the day the opportunity to implement its policy on this matter does seem to us to be the kind of obstruction that Senator Kernot referred to in her speech yesterday.

The whole debate seems to have been conducted on the basis that we are talking about changing the method of election of parliamentarians—that has never been the case. Why you cannot agree—in the way that the parliament did in relation to the ATSIC elections with voluntary voting—that voluntary postal voting is the most appropriate method for delegates to a convention, who are there for only 10 days, completely escapes me, particularly given that any change to the constitution will involve a compulsory attendance ballot of all the Australian people. That is the only way the constitution can be changed, and there is no proposition to change that.

The Labor Party and the Democrats have been very pig‐headed on this and have reflected their unfortunate attitude of not wanting to cooperate at all and of trying to deny the government the opportunity of trying to implement a policy on which it was elected. In the event, I think they have locked themselves out of this debate. Despite their objections and obstructions, I am grateful that we are able to proceed.

I am pleased that Senator Bolkus, on behalf of the ALP, has said that they will involve themselves in the debate. I trust the Democrats will do the same. This national election deserves to have the support of all parties. We should all be out there encouraging all Australians to exercise their right to vote—I will be doing that, and I look to you to do the same—encouraging candidates to nominate and to run for an election and ensuring that we have good constructive participation by all Australians in this quite exciting process. I think it is exciting. I think the election of delegates and the convention itself will allow that national forum to convene to discuss these important questions.

I will touch briefly on and remind the committee of the amendments. These amendments have bipartisan support. Amendment No. 3 was an amendment put to the Senate committee by Malcolm Mackerras in relation to the number of below‐the‐line preference boxes for territories and smaller states. Amendments Nos 5 to 15 are the detailed amendments recommended by the committee in a bipartisan fashion in relation to overseas voting and which also the government is happy to accept. Because these amendments are, in my understanding, non‐controversial, I will conclude my remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —The International Monetary Agreements Amendment Bill 1997 , which is before us, allows Australia to participate in the IMF's new arrangements to borrow, commonly known as NAB agreements. Australia played a key role in the development of the NAB following the Mexican financial crisis of late 1994.

SPEECH.PARA: In a world characterised by massive flows of international capital, the IMF needs the capacity to draw on considerable resources in order to intervene effectively to deal with financial emergencies when they arise. The Mexican crisis highlighted the IMF's inadequate supplementary financing facility to deal at short notice with a major international financial emergency.

Until now, the IMF's principal source of supplementary funds for intervening to stabilise financial emergencies has been through the general arrangements to borrow, known as the GAB. The members of the general arrangements to borrow are the G10 group of major industrialised countries—that is, the G7 plus Belgium, the Netherlands, Sweden and Switzerland. That adds up to 11 by my count. I do recall asking about this. Maybe the parliamentary secretary can tell us why it is 11 and not 10. The GAB provides special short‐term loans to the IMF members facing a currency crisis. The present GAB quota is approximately $US26 billion.

Following the Mexican currency crisis of late 1994, the Australian government played a leading role in supporting moves to expand the GAB and its membership. At the IMF's annual meeting in October 1995, former Labor Treasurer Ralph Willis expressed Australia's support for a doubling of the GAB and stated that Australia would be prepared to participate in a wider scheme provided that, firstly, all participants had the same rights and responsibilities; secondly, contributions were based on the relative economic standing of the participants; thirdly, all members were able to participate fully in activation arrangements; and, fourthly, voting rights were determined by the shares of commitments.

In the event, some of the smaller members of the G10 resisted attempts to expand the membership of the GAB as they wanted to protect the privileges they enjoy as members of the G10. In effect, expanding the GAB would have meant opening the membership of the G10 to a wider group of countries. The Australian government was instrumental in finding a way through the impasse by proposing the new arrangements to borrow as a new supplementary financing facility for the International Monetary Fund.

The NAB does not replace the GAB, so the G10 countries continue to maintain their exclusive club. But it is expected to be the IMF's supplementary financing facility of first and principal recourse. In recognition of Australia's role in establishing the NAB, it is expected that Australia will be the first chair of the group.

The bill has no budget implications. Any future payments made out of the consolidated revenue fund would be classified as a financial transaction and would therefore not affect either the headline or underlying budget balances. In effect, Australia would be making a loan to the IMF. Given the IMF's status, this would obviously be a very low risk transaction.

The second part of the bill proposes some minor changes to streamline the Australian government's financial dealings with the IMF. As it stands, the Commonwealth is currently required to make all its transactions in special drawing rights—known as SDRs—with the IMF via the Reserve Bank. Under the new framework, special drawing rights will be bought and sold by the Commonwealth without the need to transfer to and from the Reserve Bank.

In closing my remarks, I certainly hope that in respect of the appointment of the chair of the first group—if, as I am informed, Australia is to be the first chair—we do not have the unedifying spectacle, and I believe totally inappropriate spectacle, we had recently of the appointment of then Senator Jim Short to the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. I would certainly seek some comments from the parliamentary secretary about the appointment process with respect to this position.
Finally, I would like to once again acknowledge the role of our former Labor Treasurer, Ralph Willis, who did play a lead role on behalf of Australia in establishing these arrangements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: —The International Monetary Agreements Amendment Bill 1997 proposes measures, as we have just heard, to allow the Commonwealth to make about $1.5 billion available to the IMF. The IMF has potential to bring great relief and great benefit to the communities of the world. However, in its present position and with its present resources, it is really just the workhorse of the financially powerful nations and a diversion from their own financial policies.

SPEECH.PARA: The IMF has come to prominence with the decline of bank lending and the decline in the ability of the developing nations to pay interest and the principal on their own loans. It is arguable that the banks recognise that they cannot enforce repayment of those loans. They need a third institution with international muscle which can enforce repayment and round up enough money to make ongoing repayments possible.

The recent examples in Mexico and Thailand illustrate this clearly. In Mexico, the banks loaned huge vats of money, about 80 per cent of their debt, and they were very possibly going to lose all of it. In stepped the IMF with a rescue plan and funds to add to the banks' emergency funds, and the Mexican economy was rescued. The salient factor in this example is that the IMF's contribution to the rescue package was about $1.3 billion, and that was partly our money.

In Thailand over the last few weeks, the $15 billion organised by the IMF is—to use the words of Peter Hartcher in the Financial Review of 12 August 1997—`aimed chiefly at protecting the assets of big banks and international lenders'. Mr Hartcher then goes on to say that the rescue `represents an attempt by the governments of the lending countries to use public resources to protect the assets and the interests of their private sectors'. Attached to this money are requirements for privatisation, tax reductions and the lifting of restrictions on the supply of offshore currency. We also have to ask ourselves why Thailand got into this trouble over their currency. That was not because of the machinations of other countries playing with their dollar. It was because their dollar became the plaything—as everybody's currency all over the world potentially is—of business and of currency speculators. I often wonder if in fact we should make the larger transnational corporations sign a few ILO agreements and basic human rights agreements, because they have far more power than many small countries.

If this is our money—and it is—we should make sure that it is being provided for a good purpose. The IMF has the potential to give money for many good purposes, and these amendments should ensure that our contributions to the IMF satisfy our humanitarian concerns.

Perhaps another example is the goings‐on in Zaire. The IMF was a keen supporter of the now ex‐President Mobutu Sese Seko. His excesses are now legend as he lives off the benefits of his country and the trade supported by international sanction and financial support. We have most probably bought part of one of those European palaces for him.

However, we are also concerned that the objectives of the IMF in its present structure impose financial regimes on countries that do not march to the financial beat of the financially powerful nations. As a last resort of credit, countries are forced to comply with criteria that the IMF imposes to ensure free trade and comparative advantage or, more precisely, to ensure the abolition of trade barriers. This is not necessarily to the advantage of the particular nation involved, and we have to recognise that so-called free trade has a good side and also a bad side. The recent debate over car tariffs and the current debate over the TCF industries are local examples of the consequences on lifestyles and jobs for Australians that unthinking free trade agendas have.

We believe that growth should be sustainable, equitable and just. That is why we are going to support the amendments of the Greens when they come up. It is our money; it is individual Australians' money that goes into the IMF. It is not the IMF's money and it is not this government's money. It is our money that they distribute and it is money that we should have a say in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating here the International Monetary Agreements Amendment Bill 1997 , another of those bills which goes to provide money to the International Monetary Fund, the IMF. Given the huge contention within the development community, international social justice organisations and among nations of the south about IMF loans and the conditions placed upon them, I think this bill can hardly be considered to be non‐ contentious. It was the intention of the government to shove this through without debate at the end of last session.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this particular bill is to provide funding for the NAB—the acronym for the `new arrangements to borrow'. The NAB is set up to get extra money for the IMF for really substantial bailouts of large economies. It comes as a result of the collapse of the Mexican economy, as was mentioned, a few years ago. The NAB allows the IMF to call upon member nations such as Australia to throw in extra contributions. This bill would authorise the Treasurer to take that money out of consolidated revenue or to borrow money in order to meet our obligation under the IMF. In our case the amount of money we are talking about is $1.5 billion, plus any amount extra that is needed should some members not be able to meet their obligations.

BREAK.PARA: The government says that we do not need to pay if we cannot. This is true, but I cannot imagine Australia in any but the most extreme circumstances going to the IMF and saying, `We're in crisis and we would like to be audited in evidence that we really can't afford it.' No, I think we will make our contribution even if we have to borrow it. This bill gives that power to the Treasurer. It is not a new power in respect of IMF loans. At any moment the IMF can ask for $1.5 billion, and it will come out of consolidated revenue. This amount is more than the Commonwealth pays directly for secondary education, at a time when all sorts of sectors of the Australian community are being denied benefits, including higher education, because we do not have enough money.The government disingenuously says that this is only a loan, which is true. The money is nonetheless not here and available. For the five years until repayment we will have to find the money from other sources.

The authorisation of the power to take $1.5 billion from revenue, whenever it is asked, is not our primary objection to this bill. The real problems for the Greens are the purpose for which the money is lent and the implementation of that purpose. IMF loans are not loans without strings. They are not loans to help people or to aid development. Under schedule 4, item 10 of this bill it says that the loans will be made under the terms covered in article 5, section 3. This basically allows the IMF to impose so‐called economic discipline or structural adjustment policies on recipient nations as conditions of the loan.

Such structural adjustment policies go by the acronym SAPs—these debates always seem to develop a certain amount of acronym mania. SAPs impose control over government policy by the International Money Fund. The effect of such control is to maximise export income and loan repayments, often at the expense of social welfare. A frequent result of IMF SAP conditions is that the recipient nation is forced to wind back programs for basic education and health, wind back minimum wage legislation and suffer increased unemployment and poverty. The other aspect of SAPs is that they usually have conditions requiring the recipient nation to drop barriers to imports and overseas investment. Such barriers may have been designed to provide some minimal shelter for the development of indigenous industry or industries of national significance. They may have been designed to prevent abuses of market power.

I will give you several examples of these situations in my subsequent comments. First I would like to tell an illustrative joke. One day a man came to the door to find Fred, someone he knew as a person who was very active in the community, at the door. Fred explained that a member of the community had fallen on hard times and was unable to pay his debts. He was taking a collection to help this unfortunate. The man of the house was moved by Fred's charity and gave generously. As Fred was leaving he asked, `Fred, if it's not offensive, can you tell me the name of our unfortunate brother?' Fred replied, `The debtor is me.' A few months later Fred returned with a similar story of collecting for an unfortunate. The man was incensed and asked, `I suppose you are the poor person in question?' `No,' said Fred, `it is the poor farmer Susan.' Fred outlined her plight: a large and a demanding lender. The man again contributed generously saying, `I feel ashamed. I'm sorry I doubted you, Fred, but after last time I thought you might again be the debtor and the recipient of my charity.' `Ah, but I am the recipient; this time I am the creditor.'

Who are the IMF loans meant to serve? Many analysts looking at the loans and their outcomes have concluded that their purpose is to ensure lenders continue to receive a flow of cash from southern nations regardless of social and environmental costs or issues such as sovereignty. How cynical. The emphasis on export incomes rather than domestic production, the emphasis on loan repayment at the expense of social programs, the elements of coercion and imposition of policies that are domestically extremely unpopular are all evidence that the purpose of the IMF loans is not to serve the recipient nations. Of course, the entire thing is masked in economic fundamentalist rhetoric that states that only through the imposition of laissez‐faire capitalism can people actually get ahead through the mechanism of the trickle‐down theory. There are other ruder versions of that, but I am not going to mention them.

The results bear this out. The Special Rapporteur for the United Nations Economic and Social Council's Commission on Human Rights, Danilo Turk, who was given the job over a five‐year period of examining the impact of debt and SAPs, noted in paragraph 66 of his final report that southern debt was between $1.4 trillion and $1.45 trillion at the end of 1991—double its level at the beginning of the debt crisis in 1981. He further stated:

. . . the debt situation has resulted in an unprecedented reverse flow of financing from developing to the industrialised world. Total resource flows from the South to the North between 1982 and 1990 amounted to at least $US432 billion, equivalent to more than six Marshall Plans, evaluated in 1991 dollars. Between 1985 and 1990, Brazil paid out $54.5 billion more to its creditors than it received in new loans. According to the World Health Organisation, it would take slightly less than that amount to provide safe water and sewers for all of Latin America during the next decade .

IMF loans do not address the debt situation; they perpetuate it by attempting to force servicing of debts rather than addressing the fundamental inequity of the terms of debt. Debt, in being serviced, is often not discharged. Several studies—the Brandt report, the Brundtland report, the Turk report, the report of the Commission on Human Rights in 1992—have all outlined debt as a fundamental problem. They identify debt and the structure of lending—including the IMF and World Bank loans and their role in perpetuating the debt cycle—as a major source of poverty, inequity, environmental degradation, violation of human rights and what has been described as a recolonisation of the developing world.

The other area of conditionality mentioned was the fact that IMF loans usually require opening the economy to international investment and imports and deregulation of the financial sector. This has several outcomes, including an increase in capital flight as barriers to taking money out of developing countries are removed, and an increase in the importation of luxury goods. These are both consequences of the internal or intranational inequities in distribution of wealth. They are often exacerbated by unregulated foreign investment and the undermining by SAPs of policies to promote social welfare.

It is estimated that at least a third of Latin America's debt problems would disappear if capital flight was prevented and reversed. Capital flight reduces the money in national savings to meet a country's own capital needs. Going to northern banks adds to the injury of the loss: the insult of being offered the money as foreign loans. In terms of the importation of luxury goods, the IMF is reported to have demanded deregulation of such areas as imported alcohol, toilet tissue and so on in a high level mission to Brasilia in August 1984.

While some argument might be possible that restrictions on imports of productive equipment are bad for a developing country, it can hardly be claimed that development is assisted by importing Johnny Walker! A third consequence is the displacement of development plans in favour of corporate plans. As an example, in India in 1964‐65, a famine was used by the US and the World Bank to impose liberalisation of investment terms on the Indian fertiliser industry as a condition of providing food aid.

TITLE.XREF: CARRIAGE OF GOODS BY SEA AMENDMENT BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 June, on motion by Senator Brownhill:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports the Carriage of Goods by Sea Amendment Bill , which amends the Carriage of Goods by Sea Act. The bill is a compromise by the related industries, shippers, shipowners and insurers, and reflects the report of the maritime cargo liability working group. It makes provision for a regulation making power to cover highly technical elements of an industry endorsed package relating to the treatment of different types of carriage contracts, cargo handling methods and shippers' losses due to delays. The bill also facilitates technological improvements in the industry and provides for the adoption of new technologies such as electronic data interchange. The opposition supports the bill and does not propose any amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Mackay for her contribution to the debate. The Carriage of Goods by Sea Amendment Bill resolves a serious difficulty in the existing legislation with the operation of the Hamburg Rules trigger and implements a package of improvements to Australia's marine cargo liability regime agreed with interested parties in the maritime industry after extensive consultations.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill will extend the protection now offered by the Carriage of Goods by Sea Act to Australian shippers, increasing the incentive for carriers to minimise loss or damage to marine cargoes and thus will put downward pressure on marine cargo insurance costs.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 June, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —In my contribution to this debate on 26 June, I stated the concern of the Australian Greens that this legislation allows a change to the media cross‐ownership rules. We do not believe that such a change should be entertained at a time when there is a major review of those rules taking place in secret, behind closed doors, under enormous pressure by the media organisations and the media magnates. We think it should all be out in the open and, if there are to be changes to the rules, there should be a public discussion before such changes are made. I will not reiterate the arguments I put before, but I want to move the following second reading amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add:
"but the Senate is of the view that Australia's cross‐media ownership rules should not be changed until a full, open and independent public inquiry has been held".

That would mean, in effect, that this change is sensibly held in abeyance until there has been that open scrutiny of what it means in terms of not only the change itself but flow‐on changes which are alarming those people who closely watch the intricacies of these rules.

I put that amendment and I hope that the Senate will support it. It is a big issue in Australia. We have arguably the most concentrated media ownership of any nation in the world—certainly of any similar country. We have seen the number of owners reduced dramatically over the last couple of decades.

I see this change, which I am sure the government will say is one at the margins, being a further erosion of that diversity of ownership; if not an erosion per se, it opens the door to further constriction and confinement of the diversity of ownership. That is not a good thing for the fourth estate; it is not a good thing for democracy; it is not a good thing for society. I commend this amendment to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Herron) adjourned.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 12.51 p.m. to 2.00 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of the Speaker of the House of Commons, the Rt Hon. Betty Boothroyd MP. On behalf of honourable senators, I have great pleasure in welcoming her to the chamber. It is not the first visit of the Speaker to Australia but it is her first visit to this country as Speaker. —Hear, hear!
