TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Hill representing both the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Prime Minister. What is the government's view of calls in late July by the Malaysian Prime Minister, Dr Mahathir, to substantially water down the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights? Does the government agree with Dr Mahathir that the declaration was `formulated by the superpowers, which did not understand the needs of poor countries'? Does the government agree with Dr Mahathir and some other East-Asian leaders that human rights are a Western imposition contrary to Asian values?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not support any need to water down the declaration. We believe it has been a very useful foundation. It is one of the foundations to enable international pressure to be applied towards the wider acceptance of universal human rights, those rights that we should regard as unqualified and those rights that are necessary to protect the dignity of each and every individual.

ANSWER.PARA: What has been pleasing is that most countries in the world have accepted the declaration and the other major conventions in that regard. In accepting them, those countries have been prepared to advocate them publicly. What has been a little disappointing is that some countries which have advocated them have not necessarily applied them with the vigour and enthusiasm that we would like to see. So we engage with other like nations around the world to encourage and support not only their adherence in principle to the declaration and conventions but also their adherence in practice.

No, we do not see the declaration as some sort of Western imposed obligation. We are very pleased to see that the declaration and conventions have been adopted by most of the Eastern world. Furthermore—and I think Senator Cooney is more learned than I in these areas—any student of Confucius or Buddha will find within such teachings many of the principles that are enhanced with the declaration and other appropriate conventions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. What did Mr Downer mean when he spoke at the Australia‐Indonesia Business Council in Bali on 16 June of the necessity of Australia addressing human rights issues `in a more Asian way'?

—I can tell you what I think Mr Downer would have meant. There are ways in which the basic principles can be expressed within developing countries, some of which have tended to distinguish development from these rights in terms of priority. There are ways in which it can be expressed that these rights support economic development and support the benefits that can flow from economic development—in other words, they are not inconsistent; they are mutually compatible and mutually reinforcing. I am sure that that was the point Mr Downer was making Bali.

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. Does the minister recall a statement by Senator Cook on tariff policy two years ago when he said, `Our thrust as a government has been to push for opening up the economy, internationalising it through tariff change'? Does the minister also recall Senator Cook saying, `We are committed to tariff reductions . . . Our task is to further the internationalisation of the economy,' and that, `the era of the handout mentality is dead'? What is the government's approach to industry policy and specifically to the promotion of exports, investment and job creation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I take note of a lot of what Senator Cook says. I will never forget that on 20 September 1995 he said, `Our budget will be balanced and in surplus. Our budget will continue to move into greater surplus.' Within a few months we found it was $10 billion in deficit. I remember some of his quotes on the innovation statement, too, but I will not embarrass him further on that.

ANSWER.PARA: I do particularly remember what he used to tell us about tariffs and the fact that Labor was opening up the economy by pushing down the tariff barrier and how that was in the interests of all Australians. Yes, I do remember those quotes.

I guess the change of mind is familiar, isn't it? We were talking about it yesterday in relation to taxation. Mr Beazley wanted a broad‐based consumption tax; now he does not want it. Senator Evans wants death duties reinstated; Mr Beazley apparently does not. Senator Evans wants payroll taxes lifted in the states. Anyway it is very muddled, but it is very muddled also on the issue of industry policy. Senator Cook said on 6 June 1994:

The government . . . recognises that its reforms have worked. The key to our economic restructuring has been the phasing down in a careful way of tariff protection to expose the Australian manufacturing sector to international competition to cause it to become leaner and more competitive.
It was said that, if tariff reform was attempted in these areas—
the transport sector, et cetera, then they—
. . . would be killed off entirely. Well, they have not been; they are flourishing.
If we had left the tariff wall intact, the old quality, high priced, inefficient Australian vehicle would have been now overwhelmed and we would have no car industry.

That was Senator Cook in 1994, but where is Senator Cook today? He has put down a notice of motion to be debated today saying that we are now well ahead of the world in dismantling tariffs and it is time to stop. He was in here before saying, `We're opening up to competition and it's great for Australian industry.' Now he is saying that, because certain industries have closed down on the basis of what they inherited from Labor, it has all got to be stopped because it was basically wrong. Unfortunately, you cannot have it both ways. It is amazing. You have good reason to shake your head, Senator Cook. It is embarrassing that in government you called for one thing; in opposition you are calling for the exact opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Hill, the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is the minister aware that the Australian Taxation Office is preparing a crackdown on salary repackaging arrangements which include novated car leases? Why then is the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet advocating the use of such options as novated car leases for its senior officers which will help avoid income tax, the new superannuation tax and the Medicare levy surcharge? In light of this, does the government support the salary repackaging crackdown by the tax office, or do they support the Prime Minister and cabinet officers being engaged in tax avoidance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think there is any inconsistency at all, Madam President. We would understand the tax office particularly focusing on evasion and wanting to take action against that. We would understand them addressing the issue of avoidance as well, but the position of the Prime Minister in relation to this matter—which you asked me to find out for you yesterday—as it relates to the public sector is that provision for the introduction of flexible remuneration packaging is included in the government's policy parameters for agreement making in the Australian Public Service under the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Act 1996, and that flexible remuneration packaging is already employed widely in the private sector and in many state government departments and, provided that it is legitimate, that is fine.

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet is developing a policy on flexible remuneration packaging in anticipation of offering Australian workplace agreements to all SES staff shortly. A draft is being used in discussions on the introduction of flexible remuneration packaging arrangements but has not, at this time, been endorsed by either the secretary of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet or the Prime Minister. The government's intention is to provide public servants with access to arrangements comparable to those available more broadly in the community and they will remain subject to the same tax rules as apply to the community generally. So there is no inconsistency, Madam President.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you refer to flexible remuneration packages and appear to consider that it is fine, but in the use of these flexible remuneration packages these officers just happen to be able to avoid your new 15 per cent superannuation tax and the Medicare levy surcharge. Why will the government not instruct all departments that the use of novated car leases and other fringe benefits by senior officers cannot be used in order to avoid tax, particularly taxes you have introduced?

—I am sorry to hear that Senator Sherry knocks the public servants in not accepting that they should have the same opportunities as those in the non‐government sector. We think they deserve a fair go. The determination of taxable income is a question for interpretation under the act and it should equally apply to whether you are employed in the government or non‐government sectors.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, Senator Ellison. It relates to the government's decision to introduce new arrangements to assist the Australian car manufacturing industry. Will the minister inform the Senate of the benefits to jobs, exports and investment which have resulted from this decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Synon for that question. I am pleased to inform the Senate that last week Toyota announced the details of its plan to invest $1 billion in its Australian facilities. It is a decision which will directly benefit three key areas on which the government is focusing: jobs, exports and investment. It is good news which is directly linked to the government's sensible and pragmatic decision on tariff arrangements for the car industry. These new arrangements announced by the Prime Minister on 6 June this year are designed to secure investment by the major car manufacturers in the lead‐up to the APEC free trade region in 2010.

ANSWER.PARA: The decision by Toyota to make large scale, long‐term investment in Australia is confirmation of the success of the government's strategy for industry. Highlighting Toyota's decision will be the direct creation of 400 jobs and hundreds more indirectly. A doubling of exports of the Camry motor vehicle will be achieved by the year 2000. There will be $1 billion in new investment. There will also be the manufacture of a new V6 family car and the location of a research and development facility in Australia. Japan's leading car manufacturers have a very positive view of Australia and of the government's approach to industry. In fact, the President of Toyota, Mr Okuda, said at that announcement last week:
The Government's decision on future policy arrangements signals a genuine commitment to the continued development of Australia's automotive manufacturing industry.

The government is very serious about the task of encouraging investment in all industries, and we are equally serious about assisting industry to meet the challenge of free trade. This is something that the Labor Party never did when it was in office. We are very serious about providing the right climate for growth, increased competitiveness, increased exports and the creation of jobs. It is a commitment which we have but clearly the opposition does not have. Their comments after the Toyota announcement amount to little more than sour grapes, because we have just delivered more for the car industry in one decision than they had in 13 years.
This is what the Herald‐Sun newspaper said the day following the announcement:
The Opposition's response, delivered by Labor's industry spokesman Simon Crean, was unfortunately in line with the negativity of his colleagues' response to the government's tax reform plans.

Clearly the opposition do not believe in the potential of Australian industry. The government on this side, however, is getting on with the business of encouraging growth in jobs, exports and investments. Toyota's decision, I believe, shows that this strategy is bearing fruit.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Hill, representing the Minister for Resources and Energy. When does the government intend to implement its petrol plan announced by the Treasurer on 11 December to, first, end surveillance over petrol prices and, second, repeal the sites act and the petroleum franchising act after the agreement on a new oil code? Is it true that the government's objective to obtain commitments from the oil majors to allow open terminal access and price transparency is in doubt after Roland Williams, CEO of Shell Australia, wrote to the Treasurer saying that they will sell petrol based on supply contract and that Shell prefers terms of sale?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be surprised because, as Senator Neal would know, this government is very much committed to transparency and open government. It gives the public confidence in good decision making, and we think that is highly appropriate. The other thing I can say with confidence is that, when the government does make a promise, it keeps its word. I am sure that this one will be honoured as well.

ANSWER.PARA: I might say in passing that I am thrilled the Senate has decided to support us on the constitutional convention, which will enable us to keep yet another promise. As to the—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. Could I invite you, Madam President, to ask Senator Hill to have a dip at answering this question. I really think that you would have to acknowledge that commentary on the constitutional convention is not in order and that he ought to be instructed to answer the question. I ask you to draw that to his attention and direct him to answer the question.

—The minister still has more than three minutes in which to answer the question. He may have strayed a little from what you would have preferred, but I think the minister should be allowed to answer the question as he sees it.
—I will not be long, Madam President. All I wanted to say is that the honourable senator has asked for the detail of the timetable, and I will be pleased to provide it to her.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it true that the petrol plan will progress no further until the fair trading report is implemented? The national chairman of the Shell National Action Group has stated:

QUESTION.PARA: We cannot allow the current Coalition Government to continue ignoring the plights of small businesses as exposed in the Fair Trading Inquiry. If they continue to ignore the important issues, they will be turning their backs on the very section of the business community which not only voted them into power, but could solve the unemployment problem overnight, if they were given the opportunity and conditions in which to flourish.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think there is any link between the two. As I said, I will seek advice on the timetable and come back and seek to be helpful.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister assisting the Prime Minster for Public Service Matters. I refer the minister to the recent COSBOA study of Cooma, which found that the loss of 361 government jobs in the town resulted in a total loss for the town of 180 families and income of around $11.8 million. I ask: will the government be commissioning further studies on the effect of government service cutbacks and public sector job losses on regional communities before more public sector jobs are cut? Don't the comments by Dr Kemp yesterday signal that your Public Service reforms are not about accountability or any effort to improve services and that they are going ahead irrespective of the social and economic consequences for regional centres and towns?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not familiar with the circumstances surrounding the cuts in relation to Cooma.
—You weren't yesterday either.

—No, it was a separate question. I did not turn my mind to Cooma, because I was not asked about it. But I am being asked about it today, and I am also being asked about a COSBOA report, of which I do not have knowledge either. If there is anything that can be provided on those two matters, I imagine that you will hear about it in due course.

ANSWER.PARA: Clearly the government is conscious of the need to take account of the impact of cuts, but what I think you continue to ignore—presumably because it suits your own political purposes—is that the government is committed to a new legislative framework which will ensure greater efficiency, greater accountability and, ultimately, better results for the public, whom the Public Service are meant to serve.

You asked me about Dr Kemp's remarks yesterday. Dr Kemp was releasing a report by Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu, which had been commissioned by the Management Advisory Board and its Management Improvement Advisory Committee as part of achieving the cost-effective personnel service project.

It found that the proportion of human resources staff to total organisation employees for public sector organisations surveyed was 3.98 per cent, whereas best practice in the private sector was 1.02 per cent. I do not know why you want to ignore these things. You somehow just want to throw your hands up and say, `Shock! Horror!' because there seems to be a significant disparity in the figures which suggests that there are much higher levels of inefficiency in the public sector.

The direct costs of delivering HR services in the APS agencies surveyed was, on average, two and a half times that of best practice. The finding was that it takes about four people in the Public Service to perform the same personnel functions that can be provided by one person in the private sector under best practice.

BREAK.PARA: That is my understanding of what Dr Kemp was saying yesterday. It seems to be a very valid point arising from those findings. It deals with the effectiveness of the provisions of human relations services to staff in the public sector. I think the finding is that, whilst the private sector has a strategic view of the role of human relations, in the public sector it is almost seen as an end in itself, and the obsession is with the inputs rather than the outputs.

I think you would be doing everyone a great service—including taxpayers and those who want to work in an efficient environment—if you focused on outcomes, rather than saying, `Shock! Horror! Isn't it tragic that a couple of jobs were lost,' irrespective of whether there might be very significant benefits to taxpayers, because the more you promote inefficiency in the public sector, or anywhere else involving public funding, the less capacity we have to deliver a whole range of very important social services.

If you are not really interested in that, then I presume you are in the same boat as that crowd opposite who were happy to turn a blind eye to a $10 billion budget deficit and go on saying, `Hang on! We can find another area of need somewhere else where we would like money spent. We will not care about the bottom line. We'll just go on handing out the money.' That is how you put up taxes. That is how you make sure Australia is not competitive. That is how you go backwards at twice the rate. Let us focus on what this report was about. Forget the scaremongering, worry about the bottom line and you will go a lot further.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his attempt to answer yesterday's question, and I also thank him for promising to get back to the Senate with answers to the questions I raised earlier. Could he also tell us how many jobs have already been lost in regional areas since his government came to office. How many more will go in Dr Kemp's drive for further downsizing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —There you go; you are at it again. You are incorrigible! You seem to think that more jobs will be lost because of some sort of blind ideological commitment. Dr Kemp is not on about that at all. Dr Kemp is on about an efficient Public Service. That report was actually released in 1995. The report was handed to that lot opposite when they were in government, so it is not new news; it is old news. The tragedy is that some people have not caught up with its implications. That is what you ought to be on about.

ANSWER.PARA: You ought to be interested in efficiency, but you do not seem to be. You ought to be interested in whether or not it is going to be a better outcome for consumers and for users of the services. If they have to pay twice as much to provide a service in country areas, then someone else goes without. That is what I think this report is all about. That is what Dr Kemp was on about and, to the extent that we can help you on COSBOA and Cooma, we will do our best.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone. Has your department yet given you a proper explanation as to why it has given at least $2.8 million of taxpayers' money to notorious business shonks, Greg Adams and Rick Manietta? When did your department bring this affair to your attention? Why has your department put even more money into this dubious project when the company, South Pacific Cruise Lines, has not been able to meet its contractual obligations?

—Thank you, Madam President, and I thank you, Senator O'Brien, although with some reluctance because I do not have sufficient information at hand to concur with your assertion, made under privilege, that these people are some sort of notorious shonks. It is not a description that I would automatically apply to anyone who found themselves in a bankrupt situation at one stage of their life. In fact, if I wanted to go through the list of bankruptcies caused by the ineptitude of the last Labor government, I would hardly be inclined to automatically assert that, because someone had been a bankrupt, they were a notorious shonk.

BREAK.PARA: Senator O'Brien, you are a nice bloke, but you are just a little bit impatient. You asked questions about this in the estimates committee last week, and you were given answers. You asked a question about this earlier this week. I told you I would have the additional information that you raised with me investigated and that, when I had satisfactorily had that investigated, I would come back to you. You are just a whisker too impatient to expect that that would be done by today. It will be done. People are working on it. When I have an answer, I will give it to you. Okay?

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, is it that your department will not tell you what it is doing, or is it that you do not want to tell us what your department has done? It is beyond belief that we have had to wait for about 10 days for an explanation on something of this serious nature. Did you know that in the Courier‐Mail today the principal of the company admitted that the company was seeking money from US casinos in response to an allegation that they were getting money from the Mob. Money from US casinos—what do you think that implies?

—Senator, you may be in the habit of taking a phrase like `money from US casinos' and attributing to it whatever your imagination allows, but I am not in the position—and nor do I desire to be—to make such inferences. I note that you do it under privilege. It is up to you to decide what you say under privilege in this place. I told you that I would have the department investigate the matter. I told you that as soon as I had the appropriate information I would give it to you, and that answer stands.

—My question is to the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs, Senator Ellison. It refers to the anti‐dumping action taken by Australian Paper against 14 countries, including Finland, Sweden, Switzerland and South Korea. Given that an anti‐dumping inquiry process takes at least 215 days to complete, and given the serious financial threat and unfair competition that dumping represents, is the minister concerned that many Australian businesses could go out of action in that particular time? In view of the direct threat to 1,000 jobs in Burnie and Wesley Vale, and in view of the threat to 4,000 other jobs on the north‐west coast of regional Tasmania, what action can be taken to speed up the anti‐dumping inquiry process?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of Senator Harradine's great interest in this matter as he has raised it with me previously, and I thank him for the notice that he gave me on the matter. At the outset, can I say that the government is well aware of the importance of the paper manufacturing plants at Burnie and Wesley Vale, which contribute an enormous amount, both in employment and purchases, to the Tasmanian economy. My Tasmanian Senate colleagues have brought this home to me as well. I am also well aware of the potential effect on paper manufacturing operations in Tasmania and the social impact that it may have on the community there should there be any dumping of coated wood‐free paper in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: By way of background, can I say that the previous government allowed 245 days as the time frame for the investigation of a dumping complaint. My predecessor, Geoff Prosser, commissioned the Willett review and, as a consequence of the recommendations of that review, the time frame for investigation was reduced by 30 days to 215 days. This time frame for undertaking anti‐dumping investigations in Australia is very good when compared to other major practitioners. Australia's time frame for initiating dumping complaints and reaching a decision is a total of 215 days. This comprises 20 days for an initial examination to determine if a prima facie case exists, and then there are 85 days allowed for Customs to come to a preliminary finding. After that the matter then goes to the Anti‐Dumping Authority and that has a time frame of 110 days to make a final finding and then a recommendation to me. Currently the matter of dumping is on reference to the Productivity Commission and the terms of reference are being settled by the Treasurer and the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, my colleague Minister Moore.

BREAK.PARA: In this case we have a complaint by the Australian industry which manufactures coated wood‐free paper. It is against the exports of this paper from 14 countries in Asia, Europe and South Africa. The application for dumping notices was lodged with the Australian Customs Service on 19 June this year and on 9 July Customs initiated an investigation of the allegations made in the application. The time frame in this investigation has been extended from the normal 85 days to 120 days because of the complexity of undertaking concurrent inquiries in 14 countries. I might say that some of the inquiries involve Customs officers going to countries in Europe. Europe is now on holidays and this is making it very difficult to get information from those European countries.

Of course, what has to be found is that there has been dumping, then that there has been a material injury caused to the industry, and that the material injury has been caused by the dumping. In arriving at a decision we have to make investigations in countries as to the pricing of the goods concerned. Adding to the complexity is the fact that we are dealing with 14 countries and Customs will be visiting at least 22 companies. I can assure Senator Harradine that the Customs Service is using every facility available and I have asked them to examine in every way possible how this time frame may be shortened. Other than that I will keep Senator Harradine and those other senators interested as to the progress of this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question, on two things. Firstly, the resources available to Customs—is that a problem at the present moment? Have you made extra resources available so that there will be a rapid result of their inquiries? Secondly, in respect of the undertaking given before the last election to reduce the time period to 150 days, is that likely to materialise in the near future?

—The answer to the second question depends upon the review by the Productivity Commission. But can I say that one of the problems we have here is that we have to conduct a comprehensive investigation within a proper time frame. If the time is too short, the investigation may well not be appropriate. As for resources, I can assure Senator Harradine that there are over 20 Customs officers involved in this investigation. But even if we had 100, the fact is that Europe is on holidays during this period of the year and that these are European countries. To get an answer from these European countries is very hard at this point in time. Even if we could increase the number of officers, we would still have that trouble in dealing with the overseas investigations. But let me reassure Senator Harradine that Customs is doing everything possible to bring this to a swift conclusion.

—My question is to Senator Ellison, the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology. What assistance will the government be providing to government departments and Australian businesses in view of the hundreds of millions of dollars they will need to spend to avoid the impact of the millennium bug?
—I thank Senator Hogg for that question. This in an area for which Minister McGauran has responsibility. I will undertake to approach the minister and get back to Senator Hogg on this.

—I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Minister, while you are referring the matter to Minister McGauran, you may be aware that he has predicted that the cost to government departments could be as high as tens, and possibly hundreds, of millions of dollars and the cost to Australian business could be as high as $6 billion. Will you ask the minister to confirm that, notwithstanding these costs, the government will be making no further budget allocations to address the problem?
—Madam President, Senator Hogg can rest assured that I will take that matter up with the minister.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Is it a fact that as a result of this government's policies Australia now has one of the most open and competitive telecommunications regimes in the world? What evidence is there that business and residential telecommunication users are already reaping the benefits of this highly competitive new regime? Given that this regime only began on 1 July, what is the likelihood of further benefits for consumers in the coming months?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it is a very good news story. Certainly since 1 July we have had further dramatic evidence of the fact that we now have one of the most liberalised and effective telecommunications regimes in the world. In fact before the local carriers in the US can enter the long distance market they have to go through a series of tests and certainly the interconnection regime we have here has been confirmed by American authorities as a much fairer and quicker one in terms of providing access to carriers and consumers.

ANSWER.PARA: There have been substantial price reductions following 1 July. AAPT announced it would offer up to 60 per cent off the current costs of national and international long distance calls. Primus‐Globe‐Talk has reduced all its international charges. WorldxChange is now offering a flat rate of 39 cents a minute for calls to the US, which is about a third of the Telstra peak week day tariff. Telstra is now offering, for a higher up-front line rental charge, local calls for as little as 18 cents for households and 12 cents for high volume businesses.

There is a great deal that has already happened and I think there is a lot more in prospect. If you want to know where you can get comparative information about prices, then there is a web page—www.phone4less.com.au —which provides all of the relevant information that consumers need to make those comparative choices.

From 1 July the interim interconnection price for Telstra's national access service has dropped by about 35 per cent. Many new players have entered the market. Yesterday we had the announcement that Victoria's privatised electricity distributor, United Energy, was licensed as a carrier. AAPT, Primus, Horizon and OmniCONNECT have all have been licensed since 1 July.

The authoritative Australian Communications magazine says, `All up, the federal government can be very pleased with the infrastructure competition emerging in response to the July 1 liberalisation.' TechniCall is now offering 20,000 new smart pay phones. Austar is offering a trialling of a wireless interconnect access service in Ballarat. The Asia-Pacific head of on-line services for AT&T said recently that last month's deregulation of the Australian telecommunications industry should encourage a new diversity of communication services such as Internet telephony.

It is a very good story indeed. The great shame is that Senator Schacht has actually been sent off the field and he is not here to hear all the good news. He is no Nathan Buckley and we know he has not had a great year, but I would have thought that he at least deserved another game. Whether or not he is at the weather bureau trying to unban the weather, whether he is at the ABC apologising profusely for all the harm he did to their prospects and indeed to the government's own prospects, who knows.

It is a tragedy that we have yet another impromptu meeting of the sandpit club. There they are—those who cannot face the music, those who want to bury their heads in the sand. This is the biggest sandpit club in the world. All they want to do is just pretend it is not happening. They can only go one step further. They can join Senator Schacht in the change room. If they want to go out and have a good hard look at themselves, here is the big opportunity. Go back to square one, get your policies right, think about what is happening in this area, as is happening in so many other areas, and you will get it right. If you cannot get any hard ball gets then we are happy to give you some training. All I have to say is that, to date, you are well off the mark.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the minister further explain the benefits to rural and regional Australia as a result of this new telecommunications regime?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly in regional and rural Australia there are a lot of very significant benefits, particularly as a result of our decision which involved persuading Telstra to upgrade the modernisation of its networks by two years to make their exchanges ISDN capable to the tune of 93.4 per cent by 1 July this year. Our regional telecommunications infrastructure fund, which of course was part and parcel of the partial privatisation of Telstra, which this mob opposed absolutely—lock, stock and barrel; they would not have a bar of it—is working as it should, providing very significant benefits. But they are not even prepared to concede that.

ANSWER.PARA: In Tasmania only recently they made a $4.5 million allocation—the first in a series—to provide a new electronic commerce centre to enable a number of small businesses in the fields of dairying and aquiculture to get on-line and hopefully deliver the sorts of services that are already happening in other parts of Australia. Regional Australia has a lot to gain and it is all thanks to our efforts, not theirs. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer the minister to the federal government's recent set back in the High Court on the issue of Commonwealth immunity from state laws in the Defence Housing Authority case. Given the court's recognition that the Commonwealth can be regulated by state laws in a manner more extensive than that submitted by the Commonwealth, what changes, if any, are anticipated to current Commonwealth arrangements?

—That is an area that the Attorney-General has responsibility for and he is reviewing the implications of that case, Senator Foreman, and considering the government's position in relation to that. The government is not in a position at this point to state how it will react to the decision.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the government intend to introduce legislation to facilitate changes to current arrangements or will the government use its powers under section 109 of the constitution and legislate to ensure paramountcy?

—Senator Foreman must have heard the answer I gave previously because, as I stated, the government is currently considering its position and taking advice. It will make its announcement once it has considered the implications of the case. It would be improper to do anything else and to do it in a hasty manner.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President—

QUESTION.PARA: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the noisy Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, the Commonwealth's fraud control policy sets out a number of requirements for agencies to have procedures in place to prevent fraud. I understand in your department there are some 30 investigators to chase up Austudy overpayments and other fraud matters. Are these departmental investigators doing the work of investigating crimes against the Commonwealth? Where does the government draw the line between the work of police dealing with crime and in-house investigators doing the same task? Can you assure the Senate that these investigators are not doing police work without the protections built in for a police officer's job such as interrogating Austudy recipients who are aged under 18 without an adult present?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Stott Despoja, I would love to give you a long answer to your first question in three months so that you could salivate over the opportunity that your leader has finally given you. You ask a question that goes clearly to the specifics of a case that, in my view, you have in mind. The matter, generally, that you raise is a difficult matter. There are investigators in the health commission in a whole variety of areas where departmental people will have investigators, and it is sometimes a fine line as to when matters should be handed over to the police.

ANSWER.PARA: Certainly, if you have an example of where you believe a young person has been put at risk by inappropriate behaviour, I would hope that you would immediately and privately give me that example and I will undertake to follow it up. If that is not the case and your question was more of a general nature, I will certainly make inquiries in the department to ascertain not only whether that is happening, but also to give you a broader answer generally as to the clear distinction, to the extent it ever can be, between departmental investigators and when matters should be handed over to other law enforcement authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I appreciate the Minister's willingness. I would also appreciate an answer on this one. Minister, I have similar questions on notice, as your department would be aware. Are you stating to the Senate that you are not aware of examples of young people—that is, under the age of 18—being interrogated in their homes without an adult present? Would you condone such an activity?

—Senator, you can draw a long bow if you like. You asked whether that sort of thing was happening and I simply said to you that, if you have a case of it, I would like to know about it. I did not imply that I believed it was happening or that I believed it was not happening, nor did I give you any indication necessarily of whether I thought it was appropriate. What I said was, if you have got a case—or cases—then raise it with me and I will be happy to follow it up; and I will take your question generally on notice and come back with a full answer in respect of the individual suggestions you have raised and, more generally, cover the field of those activities.

—My question is also to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone. Minister, I refer you to the answer you gave yesterday in respect of your government's record on indigenous education. In giving your answer, why did you forget that in your last budget you halved Abstudy entitlements for students attending basic tertiary residential courses from eight weeks per year to four weeks? Minister, how many students will be affected by these cuts? How many will no longer be able to complete their courses? Can you explain how these students will be better off because of your policies for indigenous education?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Bolkus, for your question in relation to the tighter targeting of Abstudy introduced in this budget. What I indicated to the Senate yesterday stands. You are asking me now specifically about changes to Abstudy regulations. As I started to indicate to Senator Denman—I said I would come back to her but I will take the opportunity to give a little more information now; I will, nonetheless, come back to you, Senator Denman, fully—there were some savings to be made in relation to Abstudy in this budget. They were in the vicinity of $10 million a year which I think compares very favourably, if you like, to the sorts of expenditures that we are outlaying on indigenous education.

ANSWER.PARA: That $10 million a year is made up of 13 individual changes, one of which I freely admit we have had some difficulty with. That relates to students travelling away from home for their courses. As soon as we realised that that was a problem for them, we were in discussions with the relevant institutions and I believe we are very close to resolving that situation. Senator Bob Collins raised it with me. I indicated to him, as I recall, that we were already on the job attempting to make sure that those institutions were not particularly disadvantaged.

Can I give you an idea of the sorts of changes that we have made, so that you understand why we made them. For example, students in Abstudy are entitled to compassionate travel—that is, to return home. That is a perfectly reasonable requirement on behalf of Abstudy students, but the government does not believe it is reasonable to not have a cap on that. For example, the number of trips that could be taken was unlimited. The government has put a cap on that and students will now be limited to two return trips a year for full‐time, away‐from‐home students; and compassionate travel cannot be used for students suspended from school and those attending away‐from‐base activities. Independent and pensioner students who use travel entitlements—

TALK.START.PARA: —You're on the wrong page!

—No, I am not. Independent and pensioner students who use travel entitlements for dependents will not be eligible for fare allowance during the year for themselves or for their dependents. Graduation travel will be limited to students approved for fare allowance to undertake their course away from their permanent home. These are all perfectly reasonable changes.

ANSWER.PARA: If you went to the man in the street and said, `Do you believe the Abstudy entitlement should include an unlimited opportunity for compassionate leave to return home?' the answer would be, `No.' If you then said, `Do you think two trips a year is reasonable?' the answer, in my view, would unquestionably be, `Yes.'

There was an allowance in Abstudy for some ancillary expenses that I do not have the specific details on, but I will just give you this one example. The vast majority of Abstudy applicants taking advantage of that had ancillary expenses of under $2,000. As I am advised, there was a very small number—in the vicinity of 10 but, I think, fewer than that, sharing 87 or three—in the vicinity of $80,000. That is unreasonable. Nobody would expect that to continue. So a limitation of $2,000 was put on in the ancillary expenses. We could go through each of the procedures if we had time, but I think you will find that they are reasonable. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you did not answer the question. I referred you to the slashing of weekly benefits from eight weeks per year to four. You glibly refer to tighter targeting when in fact we are talking about the slashing of entitlements. If you have been involved with the institutions, as you say you have, can you inform us what the impact of these cuts will be, for instance, on Batchelor College in the Northern Territory, where it is predicted that enrolments will fall by some 80 per cent, student load targets will not be met and the funding base of the college will also collapse? How will these students be better off? Minister, why were these institutions not consulted before you took these drastic measures to slash benefits?

—Senator Bolkus, with John Ingram at Batchelor College acting as a sort of CEO and Gatjil Djerrkura as the chairman, I think you can be satisfied that no harm will be brought to bear on Batchelor College.
—They have influence?
—Yes—
—So it's who you know, is it?
—No, I do not say it is who you know.
—That is just what you said.
—No, it is not.
—Explain yourself.

—You never explained your ineptitude. Batchelor College will come to no harm under this government, nor will the other indigenous education providers. If you had a better record in this area, you might be entitled to ask this question without looking vaguely embarrassed, given your failure to achieve anything for indigenous education.
—It's not what you know, it's who you know! You have to be in the swim!
—You did not achieve anything of substance whatsoever. So do not worry about Batchelor College. It is in safe hands.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman, and it relates to an important issue in Queensland. Minister, what will be the real benefits to young people in regional areas of Queensland under the youth allowance? How will the youth allowance improve the income support arrangements for young people living in rural and regional areas of Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator O'Chee, like me, lives in regional Australia and has a special interest in the needs of the people who live around us, which have not always been accommodated in the past and, certainly, under the previous government did not get much attention. The youth allowance is a significant social policy reform, as I have said before in this place, and it is going to simplify and improve the income support arrangements for young Australians wherever they might live. It has many positive aspects, and I am pleased to note that many of them have been acknowledged by some of the welfare organisations I have consulted with as well as by the Australian Democrats.

ANSWER.PARA: The youth allowance will be paid to more than half a million young Australians who are in education, training or jobsearch. For the overwhelming majority of young people currently receiving income support—about 378,000—their entitlements will not be changed under the youth allowance. In fact, many of them will be eligible for more assistance than they currently receive—by that I mean about 137,000 more.

The youth allowance is all about providing incentives for young people to take up education and training opportunities because that is the best prospect for them to secure a job. We simply cannot continue to send a message to young people that they are better off on the dole than in education or training. Young people who leave school without any qualifications are three times more likely to be unemployed.

The youth allowance will be particularly appreciated by families in regional Australia because it provides real incentive and support for young people living in regional and rural areas who might have to move away from home to take up education, training or look for work. This is not about keeping unwilling students in school. You can acquire job skills in a variety of ways. It is about providing incentives to take up appropriate education and/or training.

Dr Kemp's plan for $550 million for at least 220,000 new apprenticeships and traineeships gives an indication of how committed we are to encouraging young people. Dr Kemp has said that 3,650 inquiries have already been received on the hotline about the new apprenticeship scheme, which he released under a national campaign. In one week that has been the interest from around the country.

For the first time, some 70,000 young people who need to live away from home for study or jobsearch will be eligible for rent assistance, and that is up to a maximum of nearly $75 a fortnight. It will make a massive difference in the living standards of young people who have to go away to study or to work. The parental income cut-out point for a family with one dependent living away from home and getting the full rate of rent assistance will be $58,658, and that will increase for additional dependents. That is more generous than the current situation with Austudy.

Young people under 18 living away from home will also receive an increased rate of payment—and that means about 15,000 unemployed and 19,500 thousand students. Under the youth allowance, the requirement under Austudy for a minimum entitlement of $1,000 a year will be abolished, and that will help an estimated 41,200 students. The abolition of the education leaver waiting period will benefit another 19,900 former students. Youth allowance recipients will also be eligible for the remote area allowance and also for a pharmaceutical allowance.

The previous government on a number of occasions acknowledged the need to keep young people acquiring skills. The sad thing is that they left the disincentives in place whereby you were financially better off if you were unemployed than if you were in study. For kids from regional Australia, that meant they did not get the education and training they deserved. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Minister, does that mean that young people, for example, who live in small country towns who would have to travel away to study will not have the disincentives that used to exist and will in fact have a better opportunity to travel away and study and a better opportunity to get skills?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —That is absolutely what will happen. That is why there has been such a marked response from people in regional areas. They recognise that, for many of them, it has been impossible to give their children the opportunities they wanted to give them in life. That was especially the case over the last 13 years. What happened was that families who had several children either gave none of their children the opportunity to go away and study or train, or they were in the invidious position of having to choose between one of several children. How did they choose who got that chance in life?

ANSWER.PARA: This massive improvement in training opportunities as well as in financial assistance for young people who are going away to study or work or train is going to make a huge difference to those families who never could have afforded in the past to see their children get the opportunities they needed. I think that we all see great recognition all around country Australia of what this government has done for their children.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Hogg asked me a question on the firearms buyback. The question he put had five parts to it. The first was: what does the government anticipate the spending for the final month of the firearms buyback will be? The answer to that is that it is not possible to give an accurate estimate, but advice from the states and territories indicates that up to an additional $50 million may be paid in compensation to individual firearm owners by the end of September. Each state and territory is also assessing claims for compensation for loss of business from licensed firearms dealers, and that assessment process will continue for several months. Because of the relatively complex nature of those assessments, it is now not possible to provide a final figure for compensation to be paid to firearms dealers.

BREAK.PARA: The next two aspects of this question were in relation to the anticipation of a surplus from the Medicare levy and the size of that surplus. My advice is that, at this stage, because of the answer to the previous question, it is difficult to assess whether there will be a surplus and, if so, what size it will be.

The fourth part of Senator Hogg's question related to the $63 million spent on administration. The government believes that the administration costs are not too high. These costs include not only the cost of administering the compensation program but also funding for new licensing and registration systems and for public education. These funds were provided by the Commonwealth in response to representation from the states and territories.

The final and fifth aspect of Senator Hogg's question was whether, when the government conducted an audited scheme, it would include an audit of the administration expenses incurred by state and territory governments. To that I can say, yes, part of the agreement with the states and territories for funding of their buyback and other systems was that there would be a final audit to ensure that the substantial taxpayer contribution to this process was properly spent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone), to a question without notice asked by Senator O'Brien today, relating to South Pacific Cruise Lines Ltd.

I want to refer to what appears to me to be a rather sorry saga about South Pacific Cruise Lines Ltd—if it is a cruise line. This is a company that did not exist until very late last year. Frankly, if you explore its history and the history of its dealings with this department, you become more and more alarmed.

In February of 1997, DEETYA entered into negotiations with a training provider from Victoria, William Angliss 2000. On 17 February, a Mr Greg Adams, whom I mentioned in question time, resigned as director of the South Pacific Cruise Lines Ltd. According to the Courier‐Mail, he has been involved with a string of failed companies and is linked to two New South Wales companies which are subject to winding-up actions in the New South Wales Supreme Court with over $60,000 in debts.

Mr Adams said that he was made a director only in May and that the ASC records were wrong. I doubt that. Two days after his resignation, the Queensland minister, Mr Davidson, announced that that government was supporting this cruise line venture. Later, just before contracts with the Commonwealth were signed for the funding which we have been discussing, Mr Adams was reappointed as director.

There have been contracts which were signed on 16 May between the department and this cruise line company to provide $2.8 million to the company for training at a rate which is exceptionally high, which is effectively providing this company with funding of $800 per trainee per week for a training program. That is an exceptionally high figure. Payments have been made—unacquitted advances to this company, a company which apparently has very little in terms of assets.

In the Queensland parliament—I am surprised the minister has not been watching the Queensland parliament—it has been revealed that the shares in this company are held by individuals on behalf of another company. That company, which is known as Chancellor Australia Pty Ltd, was evicted from its Sydney premises in April of this year for failing to pay its rent. So the company that the Commonwealth is funding to the tune of $2.8 million is owned by a company that cannot afford to pay its rent and it has directors who have very, very dubious business backgrounds.

The minister adverted to my comments about the article in Courier‐Mail today where the principals of the company admitted that they were seeking finance—I believe to the tune of $5 million—from US casinos for this operation. Apparently they cannot get it from traditional lenders, probably because there are not assets there to justify an investment.

The ship that the company is pursuing, as I understand it, is not known as the Alloura—as they say. It is still in dry dock in Singa pore, as of an inquiry on Monday. The authorities in Singapore are not aware of any intention to move it. But perhaps there is an intention—one never knows with these things. William Angliss, the trainer, said on 8 July that the ship might not materialise. The general manager of the company, Mr McGregor, announced that the vessel that they announced they had in February is the MS Alloura, but it is not the same vessel. They have changed tack since they told the Queensland government—and apparently this department—that they had a vessel.

Yesterday in the Queensland parliament Mr Davidson, the Minister for Tourism, stated that an agreement had been struck by the shipping line, South Pacific Cruise Lines, and DEETYA, for about $2.7 million. We know it is $2.8 million. He stated:
I understand that there has been a further allocation of funding to South Pacific Cruise Lines.

That is the question I asked the minister yesterday. I asked the minister again today to give us some information, and the minister declined. The minister says she needs more information. I think you should note that Mr Davidson, the minister in Queensland, had this to say:
I have done everything we possibly can to ensure that the Government—
he means the Queensland government—
has not been exposed to South Pacific Cruise Lines.
But the Commonwealth is well and truly exposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the same matter; that is, the answer given by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) in response to Senator O'Brien's question today. I think it raises very serious concerns about accountability, and the accountability of the minister to this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The minister has within her portfolio allocated $2.8 million of taxpayers' money to a private company with no corporate record and with directors who have extremely questionable backgrounds to their business dealings. The minister has been unable to account to this parliament the measures taken to ensure that that money has been spent correctly and that taxpayers have got value for money.

It is not as if the minister has not had warning of this issue. The money was handed over to this company—$2.8 million of taxpayers' money—on 5 June this year. As early as 11 June concern was raised in the Queensland press about the qualifications of the directors of this company to receive public funds, given their corporate record. Since that time there has been a range of speculation and concern raised within the Queensland parliament and by the press in Queensland.

On 19 August this year, Senator O'Brien and I both raised with the minister our concerns about the expenditure of this money. We asked her and her department to account for their actions in relation to this grant. The minister was unable to assist us. The department, unlike its usual high standards of competence, was unable to give satisfactory responses as to their handling of this matter.

Yesterday, Senator O'Brien quite rightly sought to pursue that matter with the minister, and asked for her explanation as to the expenditure of these funds. Not only did he raise the concerns that have been raised in the press and raised by Senator O'Brien and me at estimates, he raised a further allegation. The allegation is based on information we have received that, in addition to the $2.8 million already allocated to this firm, since that time the minister and/or the department has approved even further funds to be given to this company. They have thrown good money after bad, it seems.

It is quite unacceptable for the minister to fail to provide an answer to Senator O'Brien's question. She has had, as I say, since estimates on 19 August to address the concerns raised with her. Her department admits they have been aware of concern about the bona fides of the directors involved in this company since 11 June. It really is unacceptable that the minister is not able to provide answers about what has happened to the taxpayers' money and what processes have been put in place by her to ensure proper accountability for that money.

BREAK.PARA: This money has been allocated as a grant from a program called training for employment; the idea being that the training funds are provided by the government in return for a guarantee of jobs—jobs for young people in Queensland. It seems unlikely that the company will be able to provide those jobs. If they default on that contract that money has largely been wasted. We want to know what the minister is doing about it.

We have not been unreasonable. We have asked her at every opportunity to investigate and report back to the parliament. She keeps ducking the issue. The buck stops with Senator Vanstone: at least $2.8 million of taxpayers' money; an allegation that either she or the department has approved even further funds; no explanation about what checks were made into the bona fides of this company; what guarantees there are about the use of the money and the protection of the taxpayers' interests; what action the minister has taken to ensure proper processes; and what action she has taken to allay concerns raised at estimates about those processes.

Quite frankly, the department could not provide a satisfactory explanation of their processes before they handed over $2.8 million of taxpayers' money. The best they could say was that they did a company search and that the company was a listed company. It had only been in formation, I think, since December last year. The company does not have the necessary company record or financial base to be involved in the sort of exercise that they embarked upon. Now Senator O'Brien has raised very serious concerns about the bona fides of the directors; bona fides that would have every Australian, I think, most concerned about this use of taxpayers' money.

The minister must be held accountable. She must come into this parliament today, in my view, and provide answers. That is not unreasonable. If more money has been allocated to this company since these concerns have been raised, the minister will be hard pressed to defend her actions. (Time expired)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: White Paper on Foreign and Trade Policy

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN MACDONALD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a statement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) on the White Paper on Foreign and Trade Policy, together with the white paper, and seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the documents.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The statement read as follows—
This is the first White Paper on foreign and trade policy produced by an Australian government.
Its publication reflects the government's commitment to a foreign and trade policy which the Australian community understands and supports.
This White Paper puts the national interests of Australia squarely at the centre of Australian foreign and trade policy.

Its fundamental message is that, in all that it does in foreign and trade policy, the government will apply a basic test of national interest: does it advance the security of the Australian nation, and the jobs and standard of living of the Australian people. The answers to these specific questions must always be yes.

A clear sense of the national interest, an understanding of what is important for Australians and confidence in the capacity of Australia to shape its future internationally define this government's approach to foreign and trade policy.
The starting point of this White Paper is that an active foreign and trade policy is crucial to Australia's future security and prosperity.

It is crucial because Australia has global interests. It is part of the global economy. Its prosperity is tied to its performance as a trading nation. Its security is closely tied to the security of its neighbourhood. But our horizons must extend well beyond our immediate region. This is the experience of our past and it is the key to our future. For Australia, the alternative to a foreign and trade policy of broad scope is irrelevance and decline.
The policies and strategies set out in this White Paper represent both change and continuity.

The national interest does not change with a change of government. The priority accorded to the Asia Pacific, the commitment to further trade liberalisation, and the strong support for the World Trade Organisation and APEC are among the important elements of continuity in the government's policy framework.
They have been continued precisely because they advance Australia's interests.
In other areas, however, this government will continue to rebalance and refocus Australia's foreign and trade policy so that Australia's interests are more effectively advanced.

A feature of the government's approach to foreign and trade policy is the importance it places on bilateral relationships as a means of advancing Australian interests. Strong bilateral relationships are not an alternative to regional and global efforts, but they are the basic building block for effective regional and global strategies.

In pursuing these strategies the government will continue to accord the Asia Pacific its highest priority. This document is our declaration of commitment to our neighbourhood as we begin what will surely be the Asia Pacific century. It reflects the weight of Australian interests which are engaged with the Asia Pacific: with the region's three major powers and largest economies—the United States, Japan and China—and with our largest near neighbour—Indonesia. It reflects the significant Australian interests which are engaged in Australia's relationships with the other ASEAN states, the Republic of Korea and New Zealand. It reflects the effort and priority we have attached to Australia's relationships with PNG and the other island states of the South Pacific. And it reflects the initiatives this government has taken to deepen Australia's ties with South Asia.

Linked to the government's focus on bilateral relations is a more selective approach to the multilateral agenda. Australia must concentrate its involvement in multilateral issues on those areas where its national interests are closely engaged.
National interests cannot be pursued without regard to the values of the Australian community, including its support for fundamental human rights.

Central to these values is an unqualified commitment to racial equality and to eliminating discrimination. Racial discrimination is despicable whether it is overt or clothed in isolationist nostalgia. The rejection of racial discrimination is a moral issue of the first order and it is fundamental to Australia's engagement with the region where its vital security and economic interests lie.
This White Paper is also about the confidence Australia should have in its capacity to shape its future.

Australians should not underestimate the assets which characterise modern Australia. Ours is among the most East Asian oriented economies in the world; an economy larger than any in South East Asia. Our objective is to build a partnership with the rapidly growing nations of the region. To that partnership we bring many economic, strategic and cultural strengths. To that partnership we bring a strong skills base, the vigour of an immigrant society and an unmatched cultural diversity. To that partnership we bring a broadly‐based alliance with the United States whose strategic engagement and commitment underwrite regional stability. To that partnership we also bring our long‐standing commercial and cultural links with Europe.

Australia does not have to choose between its history and its geography. And the priority the government accords to the Asia Pacific does not diminish the important interests Australia must pursue in the Americas, Europe and elsewhere.
These are all important assets which the government will ensure are properly marshalled and strategically directed in support of Australia's national interests.
None of this suggests that Australia can afford to be complacent about its future.

Internationally, Australia will be facing, over the next fifteen years, a much more competitive global trading and investment environment, a changing strategic environment, as well as uncertainties in some key regional countries.

As the countries of Asia grow, Australia's relative economic standing in the region will change. We will be operating in a much more complex and competitive regional environment. Australia will have to work hard and creatively to advance its strategic and economic interests, and to influence the regional agenda.
The White Paper is a document of policy and analysis.
Its judgement is that the two most profound influences on Australian foreign and trade policy over the next fifteen years will be globalisation, and the continuing economic rise of Asia.

Globalisation offers huge opportunities for internationally competitive economies, but also brings challenges for political and economic management. It has profound implications for trade policy. It blurs the division between foreign and domestic policy, increases competitive pressures in markets, and makes globally based trade rules and disciplines even more important.

SPEECH.PARA: The White Paper's judgement is that, notwithstanding some significant constraints, economic growth in industrialising Asia will continue at relatively high levels over the next fifteen years. The countries of Asia will become even more important to Australia as trade and investment partners, and in security terms.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The government's foreign and trade policy objectives will be geared towards exercising leadership on the issues which advance Australia's economic and strategic interests.

This involves ensuring that Australians enjoy the growth in jobs and higher living standards which come from an internationally competitive economy; that Australia's region remains secure and stable; and that Australia maximises the economic and strategic opportunities offered by even closer engagement with the Asia Pacific region.

This is the path to the security, prosperity and jobs which are the driving objectives of the government's foreign and trade policy. This is the jobs foreign and trade policy. Nothing else will do. Our commitment to the Asia‐Pacific region and the priority we give it will ensure that thousands of jobs are created for all working‐age Australians, and of even more concern to them, real jobs for their children. Real security means more than the defence of our borders. It also means the chance of jobs and a decent standard of living for all Australians.

The government's strategy for advancing Australia's security interests is based on a hard‐headed assessment of the security of the Asia Pacific region. Its key components are maintaining a strong national defence capability, the alliance relationship with the United States, expanding Australia's bilateral, regional and multilateral security links—including through expanded security dialogues—a task on which the government has recently made great progress—and strengthening Asia Pacific‐wide regional security institutions of which the ASEAN Regional Forum is the most significant. The government will also be working to ensure that the international regimes covering weapons of mass destruction—nuclear, chemical and biological—are implemented and, where necessary, strengthened. One of the government's proudest achievements was the key role we played in bringing to life the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty.

The government's trade strategies will focus on bilateral efforts, APEC, and the World Trade Organisation. Each has a contribution to make to increasing Australia's standard of living through expanded trade and investment. None offers the only way ahead, and all three will be needed if Australia is to continue to improve its trade performance. A major focus over the next five years will be pushing for genuinely closer links between CER, Australia's economic relations agreement with New Zealand and the ASEAN Free Trade Area, AFTA.
Central to the strategies in this paper is a whole‐of‐nation approach which emphasises the linkages between domestic policies and foreign and trade policies.

An integrated policy framework is crucial to enhancing Australia's international competitiveness. In a global economy the competitiveness of the Australian economy will be the single most important determinant of Australia's future.

The government believes that economic strength is crucially linked to measures such as labour market reform, investment in research and development, strengthening education and training systems, developing appropriate infrastructure, and implementing effective savings and taxation policies.

Foreign and trade policy can especially contribute through improving access to overseas markets for Australian goods, services and capital, and helping Australian business to identify and develop export markets.

Advancing Australia's interests is a task for all Australians and not just their governments. It requires communication and consultation among governments at all levels, businesses and the community. If Australia's foreign and trade policies are to succeed they must attract the understanding and support of the Australian community.

This White Paper is an important contribution to that objective. It draws on the views of an Advisory Panel of eminent Australians with wide experience of foreign and trade policy. Its preparation has also involved consultations with state governments, business representatives, community groups and academics.

As Australia faces a new millennium, the currents of international commerce and of power and influence are shifting. In a new century likely to be defined by the economic strength and increased influence of the major Asian economies, Australia can not rely on the advantages of geographic proximity and economic complementarity to secure its future. We must engage with our region and understand it and the way in which it operates.
If Australia is to realise the promise of the twenty first century we must have a strong economy at home and an active voice abroad.
This White Paper—Australia's first‐ever—gives Australia's foreign and trade policies the sharpest, clearest focus they have ever had: it represents the coming of age of Australia's foreign policy.
