TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Public Works, I present report No. 8 of 1997 entitled Development of infrastructure on the Bradshaw Field Training Area, near Timber Creek, Northern Territory . I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard .
Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The statement read as follows—
Madam President, the report which I have tabled concerns the proposed development of infrastructure on the Bradshaw Field Training Area, near Timber Creek, Northern Territory.

Bradshaw Station is an 871,000 hectare pastoral station which was purchased by Defence in February 1996 as a training area for the Army's 1 st Brigade. The property is about 600 kilometres by road from Darwin, along the Stuart and Victoria Highways and about 285 kilometres from Katherine in the east and 230 kilometres from Kununurra to the west.
It is a huge property, about four times the size of the ACT. In terms of distances, the property is 150 kilometres east to west and 70 kilometres north to south.
The 1st Brigade is currently being relocated to increase the Defence presence in northern Australia. The relocation will be completed by the year 2000.

New facilities for the Brigade are being provided under the $530 million Army Presence in the North Project at Robertson Barracks, about 20 kilometres east of Darwin. This project was previously examined and reported on by the Committee.
The proposal examined by the Committee involves the provision of:
. a bridge over the Victoria River in the vicinity of Timber Creek;
. working accommodation for the Range Control organisation;
. living and working accommodation for the Range managers;
. communications facilities;
. an internal road network;
. two 500 person camps;
. vehicle crossing points over creeks and rivers;
. two C-130 capable airfields; and
. vehicle wash points.
The estimated out turn cost of the proposed work is $53.66 million.
The Committee has recommended that the proposal should proceed.

The closest large training area used by the Army in the Northern Territory is the Mount Bundey Training Area. This is located 120 kilometres south-east of Darwin and comprises l 14,000 hectares. Whilst twice the size of the Puckapunyal Range, its size is inadequate for 1st Brigade to manoeuvre and undertake live firing. For this reason, Defence acquired Bradshaw.
The infrastructure on Bradshaw is limited and intended only to support the operation of a remote cattle property.

The Committee concluded that the Bradshaw property lacks the necessary infrastructure to enable training at Brigade strength to be undertaken and there is a need to develop the necessary infrastructure to allow sub-units, units and formations to conduct collective and joint training in live fire and manoeuvre activities.
After defining user requirements for the property, Defence examined a series of development alternatives. These ranged from a "do nothing" approach to full infrastructure development.

Bearing in mind that 1st Brigade will be totally relocated to Darwin by 2000, the Committee agreed with Defence that the most appropriate alternative would be full infrastructure development comprising access and training support facilities, to meet Defence requirements.

The Committee concluded that the proposed facilities will provide the infrastructure to permit and support cost effective and realistic training for Australian Defence Force units stationed, or deployed for training, in the north.
The infrastructure to be provided is necessary to ensure the long term operational and environmental viability of the Bradshaw Field Training Area as a manoeuvre and live fire training area.

The report briefly mentions the Defence record in the environmental management of its training areas. For example, the restoration of the seriously degraded Puckapunyal Training Area in Victoria which has taken place over three decades has, according to Defence, produced a remarkable result. Puckapunyal was formerly seriously degraded by previous grazing, heavy traffic and constant use during the Second World War. The area is now recognised as a model of restoration and environmental management and the Committee commends Defence for its environmental management policies.

The NT Government expressed strong support for the proposal at the public hearing and in a written submission. The Government commended Defence in being transparent and consultative in its planning and development processes.
As part of its inquiry, the Committee convened a public meeting at Timber Creek. It was evident to everyone that the proposed development has the strong support of the local community.

There will be economic benefits to be derived from the construction works which are planned to extend over 42 months. Some of the works will be of a suitable size and nature to attract tenders from local trades and builders.

Initial investigations by Defence indicate that the expected nature and frequency of usage of the training area will provide some benefits through increases in commodity consumption as a result of troop deployments into the area.
Period contracts for the supply of commodities, such as fuel and foodstuffs, will be let competitively.
I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Senate recognises that:
(a) the future of the 100 000 Australian textile, clothing and footwear (TCF) workers must be secured, together with future exports and investment growth;
(b) Australia is well ahead of its international competitors in the reduction of tariffs in this industry;

(c) if the Productivity Commission's recommendations are implemented, at least 50 000 Australian jobs will go off-shore and the remaining 50 000 workers will be forced into low-paid backyard operations;
(d) there should be a freeze on TCF tariffs from the year 2000 to, at least, the year 2005, consistent with Australia's international obligations;
(e) the Import Credit Scheme must not be removed without putting in place a program of equivalent value, consistent with Australia's international obligations; and
(f) a review of future assistance arrangements should be undertaken in the year 2004, in consultation with the industry's partners, taking into account:

EMPHASIS.TAB: (i) progress on TCF trade liberalisation among Australia's trading partners and competitors,
(ii) the industry's progress in meeting its commitments on employment, investment and exports, and
(iii) the effect of changes in the TCF industry on regional Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek support for this motion in the Senate from government members as well as members of the Democrats, the Greens and the Independents, so that this Senate, a chamber that represents the states of Australia, can speak with one voice about jobs in an important industry sector for Australia, an industry sector which is employment rich.

This is, by and large, a labour intensive sector of the Australian economy. It is also a sector which has, as a distinguishing feature, its presence in regional Australia. Industries in the textile, clothing and footwear sector relate closely to the primary production of cotton, wool and other fibres. They are, therefore, not surprisingly found in major rural centres of Australia and help underpin the nature of rural employment and the development of rural and regional economies in our nation.

The plight of regional Australia is one which is not often debated in this chamber. There is a tendency here to talk in macro terms at a national level. But if one looks at regional Australia, there is a lack of development in that part of the nation, with a worryingly high level of unemployment which means that anything that adversely affects its interests damages the national good in a severe way. But, more importantly, it continues the sense of isolation from capital cities that rural Australia feels and the hopelessness that job seekers feel being confined geographically to their region with little capacity to move out of it.

The textile, clothing and footwear industries have those two significant characteristics which, when you consider them against Australia's principal and major economic concern—the level of unemployment—have a particularly telling force in dealing with issues of protection and industry assistance for this important sector.

I will turn in a moment to the Industry Commission's report on the textile, clothing and footwear industries. This report was brought down by the Industry Commission to recommend to government steps that should be taken, in the Industry Commission's charter, to—as the Industry Commission would put it—reform this sector. This is a report that has created massive unease within this industry, not only among the workers in this industry but also among the employers. This is a report which has come at a time when a major underwear manufacturer, Berlei, has announced that it is moving offshore.

It is a report whose timing has coincided with the announcement of other exits from Australia of major companies and also small companies in this industry sector. In short, it is a report whose timing, in terms of when it was brought down, coincides with a reduction in employment opportunity and manufacturing capacity in this sector. It is a report which finds that there would be more widespread unemployment if the findings of it were implemented further.

The only way that anyone can look at this report and the future of this sector is through the needs of this economy to grow, to create lasting jobs and to be more competitive. It is the contention of the opposition that this report, if implemented, would not do that. It would reduce opportunities, reduce jobs, and reduce the capacity of industry to make the transition to a more competitive base which would secure the future for it in the foreseeable period.
Before I turn to a detailed analysis of the Industry Commission's report, might I say that at question time today, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill—

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't mean the report; you mean the draft report, don't you?

—I mean the draft report, Senator, and I thank you for the correction. The draft report is what is available to the public for comment now. But having sat in cabinet, can I say that there is often very little difference between what is exposed for public comment as the draft report and what, after hearing public comment, becomes the final report and the report upon which governments adjudicate.

SPEECH.PARA: But let me not be thrown off what I was saying. In question time today, Senator Hill attacked me for statements that I had made as industry minister. Those statements related to a reduction in protection for various industry sectors and a growth of competitiveness of Australian industry. On page 8 of the white paper tabled today by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) entitled In the National Interest—Australia's Foreign and Trade Policy there is a time series graph which I hold now for display in the chamber. This graph actually emphasises my point and proves the contention that I was making. The red line shows growth in export capability from Australia. The yellow line shows the reduction in protection.

It was said in a cheap way by the Leader of the Government in the Senate that there was something inconsistent about the Labor Party's position on this issue. I want to say that there is nothing inconsistent about the Labor Party's position on this issue. The questions of industry adjustment and industry competitiveness are fundamental questions for intelligent debate in this country. Unfortunately, it is impossible to have an intelligent debate if one side—in this case, the government—insists on being dumb and unintelligent about what that issues are that are required in terms of adjustment.

We think the motion I have moved should be carried and that there should be a pause in tariff reductions. It has been said that that is inconsistent with what we were saying when we were in government. When we were in government we had a series of industry policies and programs to support this industry, to protect employment, to offer retraining opportunities for people thrown out of employment who need to make an adjustment for new jobs, to provide assistance for the acquisition of capital equipment to make the industry more efficient, to encourage the industry to grow, and to open export markets for this industry.

BREAK.PARA: Indeed, the industry is an exporter. The total value of exports from the textile, clothing and footwear sector in Australia over the last year was in the realm of $500 million, equivalent to the amount of wine exported out of this country—a fact that most people do not appreciate. This is increasingly a sophisticated, highly skilled sector that is engaging in top end of the market production.

If you are going to make those adjustments, you need the supports to have regard to developing the skill levels higher, to developing greater employment security, to offer incentives for the maintenance of production facilities onshore and not wave them goodbye on the dock as they flee overseas, to help regional Australia meet the particular needs of those industry sectors in their regions as well, and to provide investment so that there can be a basis for reinvestment in this industry and its competitiveness can rise.

We had those programs in place. In the 1996-97 budget, the first budget of this government, those programs were substantially abolished. Programs that offered job security were thrown out the window. Programs that took a particular approach to encouraging research and development were thrown out the window. Export incentives were removed or reduced. Job insecurity was enhanced by removing regional initiatives as well. A whole raft of things that help in the transition of an industry, that work with the industry and that assist the people in the industry and meet their needs were removed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like DuPont; $60 million handout.

—You mention the question of DuPont. I am surprised that you do. It is unfortunate for your case that you have. DuPont has announced just this week that it will be moving its fibre manufacturing facilities offshore. It has done so in the face of what it reads as this government's dislike of the necessary supports for this industry sector.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Ferguson, you ought to know better than anyone else that you removed the research and development syndication scheme, you reduced R&D from 150 per cent to 125 per cent, you cut out a whole range of export market development grants and international trade enhancement grants—

TALK.START.PARA: —You gave them a $60 million handout.
—Order! Senator Ferguson, you will get your turn very shortly.

—You reduced the supports necessary for this industry to reinvest and develop, and you did a range of other things like that. No wonder companies say that they have no faith in you. No wonder they choose what they regard as more congenial investment climates overseas. That is a travesty and is close to a traitorous act by this government—traitorous to Australian workers, traitorous to Australian industry and traitorous to our capacity as a nation to be competitive in an area and a sector in which we are world class.

BREAK.PARA: So do not come to me about what we have done. We had a holistic program. You have chopped away the supports and the struts of that program and want to blindly go barrelling on down the road to more and more tariff cuts without any basis for this industry to make adjustment and without any concern for the human needs of the workers in this industry to be able to look forward to some prospect of job security for themselves in the future.

The Industry Commission brought down its report on 30 June this year and, as has been pointed out, that is its draft report. A final report on this industry is due in September. A key recommendation of the report was to reduce all TCF tariffs to five per cent by the year 2008 by continuing the current schedule beyond the year 2000, regardless—and this is my emphasis—of what our competitors do. That means that Australia unilaterally disarms itself while other nations do not move to remove protection for their industries, leaving us, given the changes that have been made by this government, to face the fierceness of international competition without the necessary levels of assistance.

The second recommendation was as above for clothing and footwear, but with intermediate goods—fabrics and yarns—reduced to zero in 2001 and a compensatory bounty applied to these goods, reducing from 10 per cent in 2001 to two per cent in 2008. That is option number two. We know what happens with bounties with this government. This government says, `The bounty cost is too high. It is an outgoing expense on the outlays side of the budget. We will cut those too.' Any industry sector in receipt of a bounty is on notice that that is a temporary thing. As soon as the cost cutters of Treasury can get their hands on it, so too will that benefit go.

The third recommendation of the report is to end the import credit scheme on 30 June in the year 2000. That scheme has served this industry well and it is necessary to encourage a competitive industry to export—something that the government has done in the case of the automobile industry. But despite the government's decision there—a decision made by the government at the urging of the Labor Party—

TALK.START.PARA: —You had no part in it at all.

—I take that interjection, that we had no part in it. For the record, Kim Beazley and Simon Crean went to Adelaide before the government made its announcement and put down their plan on the Australian automotive industry—this was a key feature of it. When the Prime Minister was finally dragooned into our position, of course he did not acknowledge it but, nonetheless, substantially adopted all the points we had proposed. The point I make here is that the import credit scheme is fundamental to this industry sector becoming internationally competitive. The Industry Commission report recommends its abolition on 30 June 2000.

BREAK.PARA: Back to the report: it also recommends no further review of assistance for the industry and no further sectoral assistance to the industry; that is to say, the gate is slammed shut. While there was no formal dissenting report, the agreement of Mr Phillip Brass, who was the industry representative on the panel, was conditional on there being a bounty applying to all TCF value‐added reducing from five per cent in 2001‐02 to two per cent in 2004. The commission argued that its recommendations will directly lead—this seems to have escaped the attention of the government—to 5,000 job losses in the industry; that is, 5,000 jobs out of a current employment level of 96,000.

It also notes that a GST would damage the industry because a large proportion of the companies are so small that they are exempt from payroll tax and most TCF goods are exempt from wholesale sales tax. The government's flirtation with bringing back the GST is, again—this time by the Industry Commission—revealed as a direct threat to this sector.

Having noted the recommendations in this report, there are a number of observations that can be made. The first is that, in reality, it is not 5,000 but about 100,000 Australian textiles, clothing and footwear workers who stand to lose their jobs if the Productivity Commission's recommendations are adopted by the Howard government. At least 50,000 of these Australian jobs will go offshore and many of the remaining workers will be forced into low‐paid backyard operations. In 1994‐95 the TCF industries accounted for five per cent of total manufacturing employment—these are in similar proportions in other OECD countries. That level of employment would fall.

TCF industries encompass a diverse range of activities. Firms within the industry operate in a variety of different markets and with varying levels of vertical integration; that is, links between various stages of production such as spinning and weaving. Many firms are also involved in horizontal integration; that is, links between different types of TCF products, such as making both industrial and household textiles. The majority of these firms are located in Victoria and New South Wales, although many of these factories are located in outer regional centres—DuPont in Bayswater in outer eastern Melbourne, and Berlei in Lithgow.

I conclude by saying: if the government is dinkum about this industry, if it has a scintilla of concern about the future of the workers and the development of Australian industry, it will vote for the motion which I have moved in this chamber. If it does not vote for it, workers and industry people in Australia will see exactly where this government stands. This is an opportunity not to hide behind your hands but to come out in the open and declare your position.

I hope you do better than the minister and the department have done because, despite massive cuts in assistance to industry programs in Australia in the 1996‐97 budget, the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism underspent their budget allocation by $131 million. An allocation of $7 million was made in assistance to textiles, clothing and footwear but they spent only $3.3 million. They could not spend the other $3.7 million, not because there was not a need but because the government's own cutbacks in staffing meant that they could not get the assistance where it was needed—at the coal face, to the workers and to the companies concerned in this sector. That is an example of performance which has sabotaged this industry as well.
I hope the Senate supports this motion. If it does not, it will be a blow for job security and justice for this industry sector. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —During the time I sat on the opposition benches, I quite often listened to Senator Cook, when he was minister, expounding with some enthusiasm the great works of his government, particularly in the area of industry reform. Is it any wonder that Senator Cook has so little enthusiasm for the task he is performing today in moving the motion that is before us. I can understand why Senator Cook is not enthusiastic: it goes against all of the things that he believed in and said with such enthusiasm when he was a minister. Senator Cook, I congratulate you because you did those things with enthusiasm when you were in government, and I have quite an understanding as to why you have so little enthusiasm for this general business notice of motion today. Part (a) of your motion—which you did not refer to very often—says:

PARA.EMPHASIS: the future of the 100,000 Australian textile, clothing and footwear (TCF) workers must be secured, together with future exports and investment growth.

SPEECH.PARA: How many jobs were lost under your tariff reduction regime from 1983 to 1996? How many jobs were lost with the programs that you put in place? When tariffs were at their highest and quotas were in place, people left the industry in droves. If you look at the graphs—they are freely available for those who want to see them—when tariffs were at their highest, that is when the greatest job losses occurred in this industry, even when there were quotas assisting these high tariffs in order to try to maintain competitiveness but also, supposedly, to protect jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —What point are you making?

—Let me just quote back to you a couple of things that you said while you were minister, Senator Cook. Before I do, I will start with a quote from the former Prime Minister, Mr Keating. On 15 May 1995, he said:

PARA.EMPHASIS: We have really opened the economy up. We started reducing tariffs in 1988 and they will be at 5% by 1997, that is 2 years time. National economic policy is savoured. So tariff reductions work you do it in your own best interests.

SPEECH.PARA: Then in 1994, when referring to motor vehicles, Senator Cook, you said:

PARA.EMPHASIS: It was said that if tariff reform was attempted in these areas—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, the transport sector, including manufactures of motor vehicles—

PARA.EMPHASIS: both sectors would be killed off entirely.

SPEECH.PARA: They have not been; they are flourishing. Then on 7 June in 1995, you said:

PARA.EMPHASIS: If we had left the tariff wall intact, the old poor quality, high‐priced, inefficient Australian vehicle would have been overwhelmed and we would have no car industry now.

SPEECH.PARA: Then in November 1995, you said:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Therefore, our thrust as government has been to push for opening up the economy, internationalising it through tariff change . . .

SPEECH.PARA: In 1994, on sectoral assistance, Senator Cook, you said:

PARA.EMPHASIS: I am not a fan of sectoral planning.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook, have you changed your mind? If you were not a fan of sectoral planning in 1994, what are you now? Senator Cook, on the area of assistance, you said:

PARA.EMPHASIS: I must repeat, however, what my predecessors have said: The era of "handout" mentality is dead.

. . . As a Government we are committed to tariff reductions and continuing micro-economic reform. Our task is to further the internationalisation of the economy and to consolidate and build further on our export success.
. . . Our focus will therefore increasingly be on best practice, bench marking and the demonstration effect of successful business.

SPEECH.PARA: So, Senator Cook, it is no wonder that you tackled today's notice of motion with such little enthusiasm in the light of the statements that you have made in the past.

You talked about the draft report. The Industry Commission's final report on the textiles, clothing and footwear industries is due out on 9 September. The government then will be making its final recommendations. It has not taken a decision. Exactly the same attitude is being taken by you and some irresponsible members of your party and other parties; that is, to try to force the government into a position before the Industry Commission has even put its final report down. That is due on 9 September.

The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is meeting with joint delegations of unions and representatives of companies involved in the textile industry in Sydney on Friday. He will then meet with another delegation next week. Senator Cook, that is how this matter should be handled, not with a cheap shot through a general business notice of motion such as you have done today.

We need to remember one or two things, Senator Cook, because you mentioned the DuPont situation. We need to remember what you said when you talked about your handout mentality and the things that have happened before. You only need to read today's Australian, and I will quote from an article there. The article states:

PARA.EMPHASIS: The chemical giant that will cut Australian operations and slash 160 jobs was paid almost $60 million in government aid to keep manufacturing textiles as tariffs were reduced to zero.

SPEECH.PARA: They were paid $60 million in government aid in order to keep manufacturing textiles. The article goes on to say:

PARA.EMPHASIS: An agreement DuPont made with Labor in mid-1990 promised its newly acquired Fibremakers synthetic fibremaking business would operate without the benefits of tariff protection or bounties in a trade-off for a $59.34 million cash handout.
DuPont was the first company to apply under the capitalisation grants program, gaining the largest share of the $141 million paid out to firms under the scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: So, Senator Cook, in moving this motion, you choose to ignore the facts as they are presented there today. You choose to ignore that and highlight that it is a decision of this government that is costing 160 jobs when, in fact, no decision has been made by this government. Up to now, DuPont have made all of their decisions working on the tariff regime that your government put in place. They also had the hide to accept $60 million of government aid on a promise that, as a trade-off, they would operate without the benefits of tariff protection or bounties in order to receive this handout. The then Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Simon Crean, at that time in June 1990 said:

PARA.EMPHASIS: To assist in integrating Australia into the global synthetic fibre market, the Government has approved a one-off, after‐tax grant of $36.2 million to Du Pont . . .

SPEECH.PARA: That was just the first tranche of aid to DuPont. So do not bring up DuPont as an example.

I heard your colleague Mr Crean in the other place talking about how 160 people at DuPont would not be happy after the government's actions of this week. Let me say that the 160 people at DuPont want to remember that they received $60 million of aid to carry them through this process of a reduction of tariffs and the removal of bounties.

DuPont was only acting under the rules as they were set out by the Labor Party. They were no-one else's rules—not the Industry Commission's recommendations in the draft report, nor the coalition's tariff regime. If DuPont were serious, it ought to wait for the final decision of the government on the TCF industries and not close its Bayswater plant.

We also had Berlei's decision, which has been mentioned over the past week, to move their manufacturing offshore, which affects over 200 workers in Lithgow. That decision was made under the tariff regime that was put in place by the Labor government—no other government—because the tariff regime has not changed. So that decision was made because of decisions that were taken when you were in government, and it has nothing to do with decisions that this government has made or might make in the future.

I want to make one or two comments about the government's position. Only yesterday, 27 August, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) assured workers in the textiles, clothing and footwear industries that the government had taken their concerns on board. He said:

PARA.EMPHASIS: . . . when the government receives the final report, it will take a speedy decision—

SPEECH.PARA: it is not going to hang around and leave people wondering what is going to happen—

PARA.EMPHASIS: as it did with the motor manufacturing industry. And in taking that decision, it will certainly pay very strong regard to the interests of employees in the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: He went on:

PARA.EMPHASIS: I regard the closure of factories like Berlei as being not only a tragedy for the employees, a tragedy for the City of Lithgow, but a tragedy for the region.

SPEECH.PARA: So let me say that the Labor Party is being totally hypocritical in its stance by calling for tariff protection now. When it was in government, the arguments focused on no more government handouts.

TALK.START.PARA: —A freeze!

—You never mentioned a freeze when you were in government. When in government did you ever talk about a tariffs freeze? I am very pleased that Senator Murray will be speaking afterwards, because I know Senator Murray's position on this: he will see through your arguments and your telling this present government what it should do today when you had 13 years to do something about it—and still saw jobs slip away.

SPEECH.PARA: Your situation has changed because you lost an election. Some of the people on your backbench—those new Young Turks that are talked about so often—want to change the direction the Labor Party is going in, and they want to bring us back to the bad old days. Senator Cook, I understand your lack of enthusiasm for this motion, because I heard you speak so enthusiastically from this side. You did so on many occasions with the full support of the then opposition, the Liberal Party, who approved of and supported what you were doing.

The enthusiasm you showed for this industry while you were on this side was appreciated but now that you have gone to the opposition benches I can understand your lack of enthusiasm: you had a chance to do something about it and you did nothing.

Your shadow industry minister Simon Crean is calling for the exact opposite of what the then Labor government was calling for. Just two weeks ago he was calling for direct government involvement—exactly the opposite what you wanted. Calling for direct government involvement, he said:

PARA.EMPHASIS: I think that if you look at a number of the programs that Labor put in place—

SPEECH.PARA: he was talking about the MTIA report—

PARA.EMPHASIS: this report (MTIA) says that many of them were very effective.

What we've got to have a suite of potential programs which have identified the barriers, having got a commitment from industry that if they get the assistance they will invest, they will create jobs, they expand exports—it's that commitment from them that really has to be the driving force to qualify for any assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: DuPont got that assistance from this government from 1990 onwards. What have they done? They have turned their backs on that assistance, gone back on the agreement and decided that they are going to move offshore.

Senator Cook, you and your shadow industry spokesman, Simon Crean, have the gall to suggest that it is this government that is responsible for the loss of those 160 jobs at DuPont. Mr Crean has had a few other things to say, which I think are worth quoting. Of Labor's policy, he said:

PARA.EMPHASIS: No one understands better than Labor how that the tariff war has been fought and won. After all it was Labor that fought and won it.

SPEECH.PARA: You fought it and started to win it, and now you are trying to abandon it. He said:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Labor is not proposing to restore the high tariffs barriers of the past or keep them at existing levels indefinitely.
Instead we are seeking firm commitments from the textile, clothing and footwear industries on jobs, new investment and increased exports.

SPEECH.PARA: If DuPont is any example of what government handouts or assistance to industry can do—and the assistance that was given by your government—to ensure that this company stayed in Australia and maintained its fabric making operations here, then I can say that it is one of the greatest failures that you have ever seen. If you think that those things will be easily forgotten, I can tell you that they will not.

I have a number of colleagues who wish to make many points in regard to the issues you have raised. I look forward with interest to what Senator Murray has to say because, having been involved with him on a number of industry inquiries, I know his position on a number of issues. It will be interesting to see what his reaction is to the sort of thing that has happened in the case of DuPont where decisions were taken by the previous government—where agreements were made and still did not work because this company has now decided that it will move offshore and 160 employees will lose their jobs.

I read with interest this motion that we are debating today and I go back to where I started. In moving this motion, Senator Cook talked about the 100,000 Australian textile, clothing and footwear workers whose jobs must be secured. I remind him that he is now changing direction on the issue of tariffs, high protection, quotas and all of those other issues which he tackled—quite fairly and harshly—when in government. Senator Cook, how many jobs were lost during your term in government—and here you are now talking about potential job losses in the industry?

You say that Australia is well ahead of its international competitors in the reduction of tariffs in this industry. Why did you not say that 18 months ago? If we are so far ahead today, we must have been ahead 18 months ago. If that was the situation you should have made it quite clear then.

I urge people to oppose this motion, partly because I think that the motion is ill conceived—because of a lack of enthusiasm by Senator Cook for this motion. Although he moved the motion, it goes completely against all the conditions that were put in place by the previous government. They have done an enormous backflip on this issue. For that reason, and for many others which will be explained by my colleagues when they speak to this motion, I urge senators to vote against it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move an amendment to the motion, which I have circulated.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Omit paragraph (d), substitute:
(d) there should be a freeze on TCF tariff reductions, effective immediately;

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ferguson was quite right: my party and I do have a long, consistent record of differing with the major parties on this issue.

I welcome this motion by the Labor Party concerning the TCF tariff cuts. I warmly welcome Labor's much improved tariff policy. I only hope that they improve it a lot more. I can only say that the Labor Party are the latter‐day saints of tariff reductions. They seem to have suddenly discovered that unilateral tariff reductions mean job losses.

The Australian Democrats' position has always been that tariff cuts must be measured against our competitors. For a decade and a half of Labor government it was the Australian Democrats alone who strongly opposed the unilateral cuts in tariffs and quotas pursued and implemented by Labor, all of them fully supported by the coalition. There is no inconsistency in the coalition's position. Labor is changing, and we are delighted to see it. Senator Cook was quite right in saying that the government adopted Labor's position on the car industry. The Australian Democrats' position was for a freeze now.

In fact the coalition has always followed Labor on tariff policy. The coalition cannot escape the blame either. They are all now cheering about how they halted tariff cuts in the car industry, what a good decision they made and how clever they have been in completely ignoring the Productivity Commission on that matter. When I listened to Senator Alston today gloating when 17,000 more job losses are expected in the Public Service, I was reminded of what a cold, hard‐hearted, money‐mad cabinet he is a member of. When they changed car policy it was votes and elections they were worried about, not people and their lives. It was the coalition which when they were in opposition wholeheartedly supported Labor's destructive unilateral tariff policies and cheered them on from the sidelines.

What did the Labor government, with coalition support, do for the TCF industries and employees? It is thanks to the Labor Party that tariff reductions in the TCF industries are legislated until the year 2000. Surely, it is obvious that certainty of that kind needs to be tempered by an ability to adjust to competition and competitors. Unilateral is just not smart. I have found it very difficult to understand why anyone should have legislated us into a bind where we are forced to reduce tariffs on this basis. Tariffs in the TCF industries are currently at a maximum rate of 34 per cent, but they are multiple rates, depending on the particular product, and some are much lower. By the year 2000 they will be at a maximum rate of 25 per cent generally, but others will be lower. Tariffs in the TCF industries are currently falling at a rate of three per cent a year. By the year 2000, as I said, they will be 25 per cent, on average. These reductions are set to take place irrespective of what our trading partners do and irrespective of their impact on employment and investment in Australia. It really was a stupid law.

Labor says it is okay to cut unilaterally until 2000, but not after that. Why? Either it is right to cut unilaterally or it is not right to cut unilaterally. I am always surprised, when faced with the intelligence of people such as Senator Cook and Simon Crean—extremely capable people—why they cannot understand that to choose a date and to say that it is okay to be unilateral up to that date, but after that it is suddenly wrong, does strike people as a very strange approach.

The coalition are right to be cross with their old tariff buddies, Labor. If a Labor government reduces tariffs somehow magically, our industries and jobs are going to be immune. But now that we have a coalition government which reduces tariffs, then devastation is threatened. Our view is that devastation was always threatened under either party.

I want to remind the Labor Party that it does not matter which party pursues unilateral tariff cuts, the outcome is the same, and that you must stop unilateral tariff cuts now. The outcome is bad for Australia. The TCF industries directly employ up to 100,000 people and a further equivalent number of outworkers. Hundreds of thousands of other employees are indirectly affected. You will recall that when 2,000 employees were advised that their services were to be terminated at BHP, 8,000 additional employees were affected. This affects far more Australians than just the 100,000 conventionally spoken about.

Unfortunately, the Liberal, Labor and National parties are fundamentally opposed to halting or even reviewing the TCF tariff cuts, which have been set in place until the year 2000. They are only open to negotiate tariffs after the year 2000, and by then it may already be too late. Why is it too late? Because the industries and the companies are closing now. The jobs are being lost now—not in the year 2000, now. Berlei has announced that it is going offshore and that is a disaster for the workers and people of Lithgow. But Berlei has made its announcement now. It has announced it under a regime of tariff reductions passed and implemented by Labor with the support of the coalition. The same goes for the decisions to close manufacturing plants by Gloweave and DuPont now, not in 2000. Those closures are happening now under the regime of unilateral tariff reductions implemented by Labor.

If Labor is serious about revisiting its stance on tariffs, if it has learnt from the lessons of the past, then why not review the unilateral reductions in tariffs that are set to occur until the year 2000? Why won't you call for a freeze on tariff cuts now? Where is the intellectual, empirical or sensible economic justification for picking the year 2000? It makes no sense to me.

Labor says tariffs should be frozen at year 2000 levels, at least until the year 2005. Now they are picking another year. Why? Why not adopt a policy that you evaluate what your competitors are doing? Sometimes your competitors will go up; sometimes they will go down. But it should be relative to your market position, domestically and internationally. It is just not good enough in terms of your current policy. If you are serious about protecting jobs, then tariffs should be frozen at current levels and there should be no reductions in TCF tariffs unless reciprocal reductions are forthcoming from our major trading partners.

Tariff cuts pursued by Labor went far beyond our obligations under the World Trade Organisation. Moreover, they were undertaken without similar measures by our trading partners who have continued to protect their industries by tariff and non‐tariff barriers. They must be saying out there in the wide world, `Wow! Those Aussies are really nice people, but they are pretty dumb.' How can we be so dumb as to give away our competitive advantage in that way?

These Labor policies, supported by the coalition, have placed Australian manufacturers and workers at a disadvantage to overseas firms operating with strong tariff and non‐tariff assistance, and which have significantly lower labour, environmental and occupational health and safety standards. These economic rationalist policies were responsible for flooding Australia with cheap imports, for decimating Australian industry, for countless job losses, and for huge national debt increases. They were bad policies.

Both of Australia's major parties seem to again agree that tariffs can be reduced on a quid pro quo basis. That is the new accord, the new pact, between them on this matter. Yet unilateral tariff reductions are still legislated until the year 2000 for two major industries directly employing tens of thousands of Australians. That is when we have eight per cent recorded unemployment—I am one of those who thinks it is far higher—and growing long-term unemployment.

The rate of tariff assistance for the car industry is set to fall from the present 22½ per cent to 15 per cent. The maximum rate of assistance for the textile, clothing and footwear industries is set to fall from 34 per cent to 25 per cent. The general rate of assistance for most other industries is currently set at five per cent. In many other instances, this is significantly lower compared to that of our major trading partners. Why the National Party allowed their own constituency to be thumped with the tariff decreases in that sector is beyond us.

The future of tariff rates beyond the year 2000 for the textile, clothing and footwear industries is to be decided by the parliament later this year. The ideologically blinkered Productivity Commission—known as the old `Industry Assassination Commission'—has recommended they fall to five per cent by 2005. They want to sign their death warrant. This recommendation has to be ignored. I project that it will be ignored, but we must go further.

The program tariff cuts in both the TCF and car industries from December 1996 to the year 2000 would have cost us $2 billion in lost revenue. Tariffs are taxes. They are no different in the tax regime than any other tax that we have. When you cut them, you lose revenue. This saving of $2 billion should be ploughed into industrial development programs targeted at generating jobs and export opportunities.

The government has been engaged in trade liberalisation negotiations and should continue to do so. However, further trade reductions must only occur if reciprocal trade liberalisations are pursued by our major trading partners. Australia must no longer proceed with tariff reductions further than what is required in the multilateral agreements unless our trading partners do likewise and also address the use of non‐tariff barriers. So-called unilateral disarmament must cease immediately, not just after the year 2000, as the ALP and coalition are advocating.

The government should produce comparative reports on tariff and non-tariff barriers between Australia and our major trading partners. It should ensure these are prepared on an annual basis as a service to the community and as a source of information for policy formulation, because you cannot evaluate the effect of tariffs and non-tariff barriers on a particular industry unless you produce those comparative reports. They were not produced by Labor in the previous government; they are not being produced by this government. This is a government which said that they do not even need cost‐benefit analysis—the very thing that Mortimer says that you do need. We have to have comparative reports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with a great deal of sorrow that I find myself joining in this debate, because I think we are already seeing the results of the Industry Commission's report. The subliminal messages being sent to the TCF industries by this report—the lack of action by the government in making comment upon this report—are not saying that the TCF industries are major industries and major contributors to the wellbeing of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: These industries have seen the furore that the car industry and the car components industry had to undertake to pressure the government into rejecting a number of the very hard line, cold economic rationalist views of the Industry Commission in relation to the car industry. It was only after a lot of very heavy lobbying by very senior people, including senior supporters within the Liberal Party, that we saw that Industry Commission report not agreed to and a more sensible approach taken—the recognition that that is an important industry to this country.

I guess the textile, clothing and footwear industries are saying, `Oh, dear, not again. Do we have to go through it?' This Industry Commission report is sending bad signals to the industry but what is sending even worse signals is the government's do nothing attitude. It is like everything else this government does—it does nothing. It just lets it slide along. They do not do anything to correct the mistruths and the misinformation that are appearing in the Asian press about one member for Oxley. The Prime Minister does nothing to dispel those sorts of inaccuracies or to rebut them. Again, you see this with the TCF industries report—nothing has been done to rebut it. It has been left to the industry to have to conduct a very serious and large campaign.

The closure of Berlei in Lithgow has been announced. What the people of Lithgow are very concerned about is that when 2,000 jobs were lost in Newcastle as a result of the steel industry changes that BHP has made the federal government came forward with a rescue package, an assistance package, to the area. Lithgow council and a number of other organisations that they are linked with have been asking to be considered also for a rescue package. The loss of 184 jobs in a population area of less than 20,000 is of significant importance to this community; that is a significant number of people.

We know from the Textile Fashion Industry Association that research studies show that only one in five retrenched TCF workers gain employment in another industry within four years of losing a job and only 50 per cent find any work. Those figures are taken across the country and include capital city areas where the job opportunities for people are much more significant. When you come to rural and regional areas there are not a great deal of alternative job opportunities available. This government is not offering to do anything, to introduce any training programs or any rescue packages. It is of major concern. This shows a lack of concern and a lack of caring on the part of this government towards this industry, and it is an important industry to the community.

The Labor Party's policy is very clear: freeze tariffs from 2000 to 2005 and, before you reintroduce any reductions after 2005, have a review to see what our competitors are doing. It is all very well for this government to want to go on hairy chested and say, `Yes, we'll keep reducing tariffs. It's important to keep reducing tariffs.' But, if the rest of the world is not keeping pace or not doing what they have made their agreements to do and showing no signs of undertaking agreements they might have already made under the World Trade Organisation and GATT agreements, we run the risk of being left out there like a lonely little shag on a rock seeing the demise of this industry.

If this government had an industry policy, the industry itself would be able to plan and know what its future was and have some idea of what the parameters are that it is working within. This government has no industry policy. This is another industry that is having to battle hard to try to get the government to have some sort of an industry plan. As I have said, we have already seen the car industry have to do it. We are seeing the TCF industries having to do it. We are seeing the gold industry having to struggle and suffer because the government just decided to sell off a lot of our gold reserves and sent the wrong messages to those markets and to our goldmines.

The TCF industries have been able to work with the careful and negotiated reductions in tariffs that have taken place. They knew what the conditions were up until 18 months ago, and they certainly knew up until the Industry Commission report. They had some idea of what the future planning was and of what the future regimes were. They were able to work within those parameters.
It is interesting to receive letters from people within the industry. I received a letter that states:

PARA.EMPHASIS: The decision to change tariffs before the industry can prepare for further reductions will cause companies like ours—

SPEECH.PARA: and this is a small to medium family owned enterprise—

PARA.EMPHASIS: to retract in volume and size, downsize and contribute to the already high unemployment and social problems. Our protection levels for this industry are lower than many of our trading partners, particularly in South‐East Asian markets, and a further reduction will increase the movement of more Australian firms offshore. The government preaches that small to medium family businesses are the backbone of Australia, but the changes to the TCF industry will only advance the entry of multinationals.

SPEECH.PARA: They are very convinced that the government is not concerned at all about family businesses and family enterprises.

When we talk about TCF, I think it is important to recognise the importance of these to the rural and regional areas of Australia. In New South Wales, 1,000 people are employed in the industries. In regional New South Wales, over 7,500 people are employed in the TCF industries. In regional Victoria, it is 7,700 people. That is 15,000 people employed in these industries in regional New South Wales and Victoria. These regional areas cannot afford to suffer these cuts to their job opportunities.

It is very fortuitous that I have a copy of the front page of the Western Advocate, the newspaper that is published in Bathurst. Bathurst also has a TCF industry in J. Robin and Sons shoes. I would like to quote from this article by Sheena Frost from page 1 of the Western Advocate. She says:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Shoe manufacturer J. Robin and Sons could take its operations off shore if the Federal Government does not freeze textile and footwear industry tariffs from 2000.

Manager of the Bathurst factory which employs 40 people, Chris Penniceard, said the company—the largest Australian owned shoe manufacturer—is planning for the worst, following recommendations by the Industry Commission that tariffs be reduced to between zero and five per cent by 2010.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier on I said the Industry Commission report was sending the wrong messages and the government was doing nothing about it. Here we have a manager of one of J. Robin shoe manufacturing factories saying that they are working on the worst case scenario. They are working on that because they obviously cannot trust the government. He then went on to say:

PARA.EMPHASIS: . . . there was no guarantee the company would stay in Australia if the government adopted this recommendation.

The Bathurst factory injects $1.1 million into the local economy in wages alone, and produces around 200,000 pairs of shoes a year. It is the only one of four factories located outside a capital city.

SPEECH.PARA: So three other locations in this country are having similar sorts of injections of funds and finances into their economy because of the fact that Robins are there. He continues:

PARA.EMPHASIS: "We're aware of the need to reduce tariffs, and agree to the overall principle, but the stage of reduction would far exceed our expectation for our productivity gains," he said.
Mr Penniceard said the company was calling for a five‐year freeze on tariffs from 2000, allowing the local industry to remain competitive.

"By freezing tariffs for five years and then reassessing them, this would allow us to achieve long term efficiency gains and take advantage of important technology innovations through cost reductions."
If this does not eventuate, the company will have to reassess its position.
"We would have to evaluate our viability," Mr Penniceard said.
"We can see ourselves surviving, but we'd certainly survive if they freeze tariffs."
However the temptation to move overseas will "be at its peak" by 2000 if the government does not freeze tariffs.

"We want to pursue manufacturing in Australia, and pursue best practice standards, increasing our productivity, improving our technology and take all the necessary steps to remain manufacturing in Australia."

SPEECH.PARA: But, obviously—to quote this particular gentleman who is in the industry—they cannot do it if the government goes ahead with the Industry Commission recommendations or if the Industry Commission does not alter its recommendations.

This is of major concern. As I said, this company injects a $1.1 million wage packet into the community each year. Forty jobs will be gone. Communities in rural and regional areas of Australia cannot stand those sorts of losses. What does that $1.1 million get spent on? It does not just go to those people; it gets spread around the community. It affects everybody in the community. If you take out an income level of $1.1 million, you must have an impact upon those regional and rural communities, but the government does not seem to understand that.

It also does not seem to understand that the industries have worked very well, as this gentleman has said, with the programs that have happened to date and can cope until the year 2000. But it is the year 2000, the year that the Industry Commission report recommendations start to take effect, that they have the problems with—the uncertainty, the rapid reduction in tariffs and things like that. It is of major concern, and it would well do these government members to think very clearly about this because they are important industries.

If this government had an industry policy, we would not need to debate here sector by sector each industry sector. They would actually be able to understand and know where they come from. But this is a government that has actually attacked the rural areas. We have seen Medicare offices under threat, and we have reversed that. In recent times we have seen AQIS inspection charges for meat exports rise. We have seen people laid off by that.

We have had abattoirs say they cannot cope with anything up to a 300 per cent increase in inspection fees. We have seen losses of tax offices in country areas. We are seeing reductions in FIS officers to the Department of Social Security. We are seeing reductions in ABC services. We have seen all these sorts of things and now we run the risk of seeing losses in our textiles, clothing and footwear industries.

This also goes in conjunction with the fact that the government have removed, destroyed, done away with, the department of regional development at a federal level. They say there is no constitutional need for them to be involved in this sort of endeavour. I would put it to the Senate that it is of vital importance that we have an understanding at a federal level and an international level of the importance of regional development to this country, of its significance and of the need for the federal government to maintain that.

One of the groups that Berlei has given great praise to has been the New South Wales department of regional development. Why was the federal department not in there helping them as well? This textiles, clothing and footwear issue is very important. They are very important industries to this country—100,000 jobs. They cannot be sneezed at, cannot be dismissed and we cannot send the wrong signals to the industries. The industries have to have some certainty. While this government thrashes around uncertain as to what the future will be, it will be sending the wrong messages. It will not be encouraging investment in industries that are of vital importance.

By freezing the tariffs to the year 2005, the industries will have some certainty by their understanding that the review will be taking place in the year 2004. They will understand what they need to be looking for and what sorts of issues will be included in the review, and Senator Cook's motion certainly outlines three of the important points that should be taken into consideration when that review is undertaken. I have a great deal of pleasure in supporting Senator Cook's motion.

It is the government's intention to encourage the development and growth of these industries, unlike the failed policies of the Labor Party, which have seen these industries shrink and decline.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you really such an idiot?

—Senator Cook, I have already been through your complete policy failure in this regard—your failure to push ahead with micro‐economic reform, with labour market reform, and all of the related reforms which were absolutely essential if industries were to be capable of not just surviving but expanding under a regime of tariff reductions.

SPEECH.PARA: We are also mindful that the industries will not benefit from uncertainty. Of course, this is in direct contrast to the opposition, which believes that the only way to gain credibility on this issue is to perform a backflip, to undertake a policy U‐turn, to which I referred earlier in my remarks. What they do not seem to realise is that that absolutely destroys their credibility; it does not restore it. A U‐turn of that magnitude completely destroys their credibility.

The textiles, clothing and footwear industries make an important contribution to the development of Australian manufacturing. In 1996, these industries provided some nine per cent of manufacturing employment. The industries have a significant impact on the Australian economy. In 1994‐95, the textiles, clothing and footwear manufacturing turnover exceeded some $9.5 billion, representing five per cent of manufacturing gross domestic product. The industries are also major exporters. In 1995‐96, they exported $2.7 billion worth of goods, which is greater than the exports of the automotive industry at $2.2 billion, and the computers and office machinery industry at $1.9 billion.

Let me conclude by reiterating the fact that the Howard government has put in place a comprehensive process to review the post year 2000 arrangements for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries. The opposition fear campaign is nothing more than a cheap attempt to divert attention away from their own policy failures during 13 years of government. It is no good now, Senator Cook, shedding crocodile tears.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak on the motion in relation to the textiles, clothing and footwear industries. The TCF crisis is certainly important, but it is not a new problem. I have highlighted the situation during virtually the whole of my term. For a more detailed consideration of the issue I would like to commend the work of Elizabeth Peak, who worked for me as a parliamentary intern in 1994. She produced a very good report called The ignorance of implications: policy making in the textiles, clothing and footwear industries . It was done in my office for the work that I was doing in the Senate, and it was tabled in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to say that it is very useful to look back now at the issues that were identified at that time. They included the fact that, during the time that former Senator Button was working with the car industry, he was also working with the textiles, clothing and footwear industries, but his way of operation with both those industries was different. It is hard to understand exactly why, considering the numbers of jobs involved and the importance of the industries.

Senator Chapman has pointed out how important the industries are in many ways employment‐wise and in terms of the actual level of the economy. But they are also obviously very important in terms of the fact that one would think it would be good for a country like Australia to be able to produce its basic food, clothing and shelter; not an unreasonable assumption, considering the distances involved between us and the rest of the world.

In the days when Senator Button was working with industry to reduce tariffs, agreements were reached between government and the car industry on tariff reductions. There were also protracted agreements between the government and the textile, clothing and footwear industries. But there was a difference: the difference was that although the government respected the agreement between itself and the car industry, not once but twice they totally ignored the outcome of those protracted discussions and recommendations from the IAC and reduced the tariffs further.

The original agreement was to have an in‐built system to assess whether or not the policies were meeting their goals. You would think that was a reasonable thing to do. If what we are trying to do is bring about a certain level of efficiency in such a way as not to damage the industry too much at one time, we would have a method of looking back to see if we were achieving those goals. But, as I say, not once but twice this agreement was reneged on.

BREAK.PARA: I come back to the point when I came into the parliament. Honourable senators who were here at the time may remember that I asked a number of questions of Senator Cook, who was then Minister for Trade. The questions related to the level of tariff reductions, whether or not the government was cognisant of their impact, and their relationship to Australia's signing of the Uruguay Round of GATT. If anybody remembers, at the time Senator Cook clearly denied that the reductions were anything to do with the Uruguay Round of GATT and that the subsequent major job losses in the industry had anything to do with the Uruguay Round of GATT because, as he pointed out, they were voluntary; they were as a result of a policy decision by this government, taken before anything was required under the Uruguay Round of GATT.

Somebody might say that this could have been considered to be a naive approach. In hindsight, of course, it was a naive approach. In the rest of the world, along with the negotiations for the Uruguay Round of GATT—which, of course, is now the World Trade Organisation—there were many great words. But they have at least left themselves the leeway since the signing and the implementation of the Uruguay Round of GATT to make the adjustments which were then required under the Uruguay Round of GATT.

Australia did not do that. We actually pushed the textile, clothing and footwear industries in particular further than they were initially happy and comfortable to go. We left them in a situation where, under the Uruguay Round of GATT and the World Trade Organisation, they were required to go further. We are getting bleats from other parts of the world—where tariffs levels are greater than ours—saying that we should be doing more to reduce our current levels. That was not particularly bright of Australia at the time. The question remains: why were the textile, clothing and footwear industries treated so differently from the way the car industry was treated?

Perhaps the answer, if I was cynical, relates to the current treatment of the textile, clothing and footwear industries by some sections of the media. I noticed the other day that one report of the closure of the Berlei factory talked about 200 pay packets, not 200 jobs—not the human impact of people losing their jobs, but 200 pay packets. Women are still not real people out there in the world of jobs. I think that has something to do with the fact that the industries have been treated differently over time from the way the car industry, the mining industry and other industries have been treated when job questions were considered.

The textile, clothing and footwear industries are generally industries where, in developing countries, worker exploitation is particularly rife. Cases such as a fire in an overcrowded Thai factory without proper fire escapes, or building collapses are not uncommon. There have been cases where women and children could not get out of the factories; they were virtually entombed in those factories. Use of bonded and child labour and wage levels well below minimum wages, even where minimum wages are $1 a day, are also strongly present in foreign textile, clothing and footwear industries.

Children and women are frequently favoured for such work because of high manual dexterity and delicacy, and good eyesight. Under typical factory conditions of long hours, poor lighting and bad diet, eyesight goes quickly. Stories appear regularly of scams where poor, isolated women workers or young children are lured with promises of jobs—so they come from rural areas and then obviously become very dependent—only to find themselves imprisoned in factories and made to work without pay.

The need to compete with massive exploitation has led less scrupulous manufacturers here to institute as much exploitation as the labour market will bear. Exploitative work practices include: piecework production, requiring workers to have their own equipment and work from home; and common use of migrant and marginalised group labour at less than the effective minimum wage.

Some people would choose to work at home; other people find that the exploitation of the piecework makes it worse than working in a factory because it is harder for anybody to check that, whether they are unions or other industry inspectors. There, they are often paid by the hour or by the piece, so in fact the exploitation is set by the piece rate rather than by anything else.

Levels of tariffs and other industry protection and promotion moves are common overseas. Most nations recognise that clothing is a necessity which will be imported on a massive scale if domestic industry is not healthy. If you look, for instance, at the trade figures between Australia and China, you will find that, about a year ago, they were worth roughly $3 billion each. The difference is that Australia is producing massive amounts of lower value, high volume goods and Australia is importing mainly fairly high value added goods, such as footwear, clothing and textiles, tools and other manufactured goods.

Nevertheless, various competitive pressures result in even more drastic exploitation as nations like Thailand use even cheaper Vietnamese labour and re‐label goods as `Thai' to circumvent trade barriers. At the same time, low Vietnamese labour costs were used to suppress an increased minimum wage push by Thai workers.

The beneficiaries of this push are rarely workers, or even manufacturers. Distributors and large retailers decide what goods to import and do so en masse. Their decisions are based on which products are least expensive. Retail price, or prices to small domestic retailers, are established on the basis of profit maximisation. A result is that lower manufacturing costs through lower wages do not necessarily translate into lower retail price.

There was an assumption that the international free market would bring a lot of such benefits to the consumer, but we need to look seriously at what exactly were the benefits to consumers in Australia. As I said, retail price, or prices to small domestic retailers, are established on the basis of profit maximisation. A result is that lower manufacturing costs through lower wages do not necessarily translate into lower retail price. They do not benefit either workers or consumers.

This is most apparent in things like designer running shoes—Nike and so on. Though the cost dropped to a small fraction of what it might have been—it might cost $1 to produce them—when manufacture shifted from the US to Indonesia and other low wage countries, the prices of such goods did not come down markedly. Nike and similar type shoes are still expensive. So the distribution is where the money is made. Therefore, we cannot say that there are benefits passed on either to the workers, necessarily, or to the consumers.

Another result has been that diversity has often decreased. Think about it: globally, there are few very inexpensive sources. All importers know who they are and that the best profit margin is likely to be on these goods. As a consequence, such goods proliferate and drive the vast diversity of goods manufactured by national, regional and local small and medium scale producers out of the market. Not entirely out of the market—some small businesses may stock them. But large distributors, department stores and retail chains will generally have what is effectively a very similar small range of goods.

These days, because they are being pushed to be internationally competitive or even locally competitive, they only stock those goods which they think they will move most quickly. So the range of goods, for a number of reasons, as part of our jump into free trade, has reduced, in my opinion.

Even if all tariff barriers were gone, we have a situation of disequilibrium between the mobility of capital and the mobility of labour. So the advantage for the owners of capital is that they can move from place to place. They can raffle down, bid down, the prices for labour from one country to another, just as they bid down the environmental conditions from place to place. Wages and conditions are being raffled down to the lowest common denominator.

The translation of that is that capital can invest wherever it makes the most money, but workers are less able to go where they make the most money. This means that human beings have needs but there is no reason for anyone to employ them, unless more money can be made by employing someone else. So they are more vulnerable.

There is some sort of fantasy that if TCF jobs go, it will create a vacuum that will be filled by very high value intellectual and other service work. This has not worked. The evidence is that skilled manufacturing workers, when made redundant, move down the ladder of skills. They do work with less value added. Not only that, imports of value added goods increase.

The truth is that not everyone is intellectually or emotionally suited to be a manager, a researcher, a computer programmer or a provider of legal and financial services. Sacking people will not improve their prospects. On the other hand, a portion of people will be suited to manufacturing work. They will like it and will be extremely good at it. If employment is any kind of objective, it is important to provide a diversity of work since there a diversity of people. If we concentrate only on those industries where we believe we have a competitive advantage we are actually doing ourselves a disservice in the long run.

We continue to function in a very unequal situation. Other nations have both high tariffs and strong policies to retain a diversity of work, particularly in the production of high volume consumables. They also foster high value added work. Is it not ironic that Australia believed that we should be naive enough to reduce tariffs much more than was required in certain industries like the TCF industries on the basis that the rest of the world would follow.

The same thinking says that we cannot take the lead and do the right thing to protect the environment through greenhouse gas reductions because we have to wait until everybody else does the right thing and we are not sure whether or not it is going to be a problem for the coal industry. Is it not ironic that in one area, the footwear, clothing and textiles industries, we can leap in with both feet naively and yet we sit with our hands behind our backs when we need to take the lead in relation to reducing greenhouse gas and creating employment through new opportunities in the energy efficiency and conservation areas. It is funny.

China produces computers, computer components, TVs and various electronic audio equipment. It has no lack of capacity for the things we say we want to move towards to replace the things they now do for us. Failure to do this will virtually ensure a negative balance of trade. They also maintain a large number of direct subsidies such that clothing from China is essentially produced below cost.

We have swallowed intellectual poison by accepting a purist version of free trade. Other nations argue such a line, but they do so when it is to their advantage. Their practice might be quite different. The United States is quite happy to bully Japan and to establish bilateral controlled trade agreements. The US and the European Union are very happy to use subsidies to act against our wheat and beef markets. Their rhetoric on free trade is usually impeccable.

We have award winning textiles, clothing and footwear industries. They need to be supported and fostered, not simply allowed to die in the interest of a counterproductive ideology. We have the capacity to build such an industry with far less in the way of trade barriers and subsidies than other nations have in place. We could improve our industry assistance and still be world leaders in deregulation.

Ultimately, there may be a case for genuinely free trade, but before that occurs I think there is a strong case for a managed trade regime. I would also say that free trade requires a strong universal international regulatory regime. There is not one now. What we have is a very undemocratic structure. The World Trade Organisation is run by corporations, and that is not the same as free trade. In the meantime, there is considerable scope to develop a strong, flexible industry policy in which the promotion of import replacement for major consumables and industry diversity have a central place.

There are a number of positive environmental and social implications of such a regime. Firstly, it would vastly decrease transport, dependency on exports and vulnerability to the global financial markets. It is truly a shame that in 1997 we have ships or even plane loads of the same goods going in different directions. That is not very bright. Secondly, it would also allow sustainable management policies to be more effectively put into place. Thirdly, it would provide a diverse job base. This is important in developing a robust economy. Without a strong set of manufacturing skills we lose the capacity to develop much in the way of closely or serendipitously associated industries. For example, skilled textile workers may shift to something like costuming for our film support industry. Many spin-off possibilities, such as high employment and high value added small businesses, result from having a healthy manufacturing sector such as the textiles, clothing and footwear industries.

I am extremely pleased—no matter whether it was brought forward by Senator Cook or someone else, although the irony is amazing—that we are having this debate. I am very pleased that it is not just the Greens and the Democrats bringing this debate to the Senate this time. I am very pleased that we are beginning to talk about jobs in a real way and beginning to talk about the need for industry policy and the future for these very important industries.

This involves real people. Not only are they in a very important employment sector; they are in a very important strategic sector. The people who produce goods and services in Australia are also the people who buy goods and services in Australia. They deserve support. They are not just wage packets; they are real people. They are part of regional Australia. They are part of urban Australia. It is time we started looking, in a more holistic way, to our future in urban and regional Australia, to produce a smarter Australia. I think there is still time for us to get that right.
