Will he be like the member for Melbourne, factional member, or will he be like Senator Cook in regard to tariff freezes? So the opposition has no credibility in this debate.

I interjected on Senator West, but she did not take up the interjection, so allow me to make my point now. The Labor Party introduced in 1989 the TCF tariff reductions, but in 1991—and we should remember the state of the economy in 1991; it was a time of deep recession, high interest rates and high unemployment—they decided to accelerate the TCF tariff reductions that they had put in place in 1989. They could not have picked a worse time to change their policy midstream. That did more damage to the TCF industries—and we are probably still seeing the effects—than anything else that they could have done. That is the inconsistency that we have in the opposition's policy.

We have heard also the false accusations today in regard to blaming this government, which has been in office less than 18 months, for the factory closures of DuPont, Berlei and Gloweave which have taken their business overseas. Far from it being this government's policy, it probably had more to do with the previous government's tariff regime which they accelerated in 1991, in the midst of a recession. So let us not forget the 1980s and the 1990s, the atmosphere and the economy that the TCF industries had to work under, with at the same time a reduced tariff regime.

This government intends to react to the Industry Commission's final report on the TCF industries in the same way as it did with the Industry Commission report on the car industry. In that particular industry we recognised that the Industry Commission's report was but one source to cabinet. We would rely on many different sources. You will recall that we undertook very extensive industry consultations and party room debate. Moreover, the government did not keep the car industry waiting for its judgment long after the final Industry Commission report. It followed up very quickly—in less than a week. I outline this procedure because we will follow the same procedure in relation to the TCF industries once the Industry Commission's report is handed down. They can rest assured that we know the debate quite well. Our record, our form, can be seen in relation to the car industry and, more than that, we will give a speedy reply to the report. In fact, like my colleagues, I wish to quote the Prime Minister yesterday—27 August—when he assured the workers of the TCF industries that the government had taken all their concerns into consideration. He said:

When the government receives the final report, it will take a speedy decision, as it did with the motor manufacturing industry. And in taking the decision, it will certainly pay very strong regard to the interests of the employees in that industry. I regard the closure of the factories like Berlei as being not only a tragedy for the employees, a tragedy for the City of Lithgow, but a tragedy for the region.

That should be a fair and proper signal to the opposition and to the industry of the government's thinking in relation to TCF industries. Our decision within the car industry, as I said, to freeze tariffs—I have not heard one speaker from the other side give credit to this decision, but we have decided to freeze tariffs in the car industry until the year 2004—is a very pragmatic and sensible outcome for that industry. In framing that post‐2000 structure decision, the government sought to balance two fundamental objectives. We had to ensure that we were acting, firstly, to meet our international trade obligations and, secondly, to provide the right environment to secure the next round of investments within the car industry, therefore stimulating employment within the industry. The extent to which we have achieved that balance was illustrated only recently with the Toyota decision to make further investments in the Altona plant with some expected 200 new jobs.

The point here is that the government is aware, better than the opposition, of the environment needed to create investment and employment in these very vulnerable industries—vulnerable to international competition. As we acted in the car industry, rest assured that a similar understanding will be given to TCF industries. It is worth mentioning that, in creating a very sound business environment for TCF industries, it just does not stop with the tariff issue. The government has supported the industry by bringing about a lower Australian dollar through a very sound fiscal management. One of the virtues of a balanced budget has been a lower dollar, putting our TCF industries on a far more competitive footing in regard to exports and, for that matter, import competition. Yet at every turn the opposition attempted to frustrate the government's budgetary process, being ignorantly unaware or just simply not caring how a balanced budget will benefit TCF industries in the long run.

The government was left a $10.3 billion budget deficit and $100 billion government debt by the previous government, in tandem with severe tariff cuts, and that had more to do with the root cause of unemployment in this industry and the closure of factories than anything else. As a senator for Victoria I am only too aware of the importance the manufacturing industry has in my state and, as has been mentioned in this debate, within the regional areas. I am sure we have all received the very fine Council of Textile Fashion Industries of Australia submission entitled A pause for a cause: TCF 2000 and beyond. That report is full of information on the TCF industries and quotes that they employ some 96,000 to 100,000 Australians, of which 8.5 per cent are within the regional areas of Australia, which is the area I am most concerned with.

In Victoria, the state which employs the largest number in TCF industries, there are some 49,600 people employed in TCF industries. In the regional areas, in Barwon‐Western district there are 1,900 employed, Central Highlands‐Wimmera area some 900 em ployed, Loddon‐Campaspe‐Mallee area 300 employed and in the Goulburn‐Ovens‐Murray area 3,200 people employed. So we are only too aware of the importance that these industries have for the towns and for employment where these people reside, and the knock‐on effect within those towns. In the town of Wangaratta alone there are three very important TCF industries. There is Bruck Textiles Pty Ltd factory, the Australian Country Spinners factory which was once better known as the Wangaratta Woollen Mills, and of course the well‐known trademark of Yakka also resides in Wangaratta.

So we are only too aware of the employment benefits that these industries bring to the local area. We are not going to leave them to hang out to dry like the previous government did, crushing them with higher interest rates, debt burdens and ever accelerating tariff reductions. We are not going to change midstream from the 1989 policy to the 1991 policy.

We are going to take into account the employment factors, the future investment factors and our trade obligations. We will come down with a decision not rushed by the opposition's motions. We are not spooked by this particular motion or, least of all, spooked by Senator Cook, the former minister, who had his opportunity to bring some benefits to this industry. We are not spooked at all. We will make a very swift decision within the month of September in regard to this industry once the IC report is handed down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take a few minutes initially in this debate to outline the importance of the textiles, clothing and footwear industries to my state of Tasmania. The industries there employ approximately 1,500 people and generate over $140 million in sales turnover annually. They provide significant value adding. This value adding is particularly important to agricultural products, including wool and hides.

SPEECH.PARA: I will take a few moments to look at the importance and the structure of a number of these firms in Tasmania. We can look at Australian Weaving Mills, and I suppose no firm has been restructured more than Austral ian Weaving Mills. It has a work force which has been reduced to 300 people. It is a major contributor to the Devonport economy. It has an annual turnover of $36 million, of which $21 million flows into the local economy. The loss of such an enterprise as this would be devastating to a city the size of Devonport, because it deals with over 100 companies in a significant way—most of which are located along the north-west coast.

In the same town, we have Tascot Templeton, which employs approximately 205 people at its east Devonport factory and a further 20 people in mainland offices. Like in so many textile mills, 54 per cent of the Devonport employees are female; 48 per cent are aged under 30; and 44 per cent have more than five years with the company. So any significant reduction that the draft report would suggest would have a devastating impact. This company spends $8.5 million in Tasmania annually.

What would be the effect of the Industry Commission's recommendations if tariffs on carpets were reduced? May I remind you that they actually have been reduced from 35 per cent to the current 21 per cent. During that time, carpet imports have increased by 52 per cent, and the number of jobs in that industry have fallen by about 20 per cent. The number of firms in that industry has roughly halved. If the recommendations of the Industry Commission's report were adopted and tariffs were further reduced from 15 per cent in the year 2000 to five per cent in the year 2005, Tascot Templeton estimate a reduction of approximately a third of their work force and minimal future investment.

We can then go to the opposite end of the island, to Blundstone footwear. They employ 320, and the company's future directly affects another 28 people employed at a local tannery—value adding. Blundstone consists of a highly integrated group of companies; that is, a tannery and two modern footwear factories owned and operated by a family whose continuous involvement in the manufacture of footwear spans 140 years. The company is highly specialised and is Australia's largest manufacturer of heavy duty work and protec tive safety footwear, servicing markets in Australia and overseas.

Importantly, the last decade has seen continuing heavy investment in new technologies and plant and unprecedented growth in production and sales. The modern footwear factory has the latest technology which ensures flexibility, high quality and efficient productivity. Blundstone maintains a strong and comprehensive program of apprenticeships and cadetships to develop its work force. In fact, this company's achievements were recognised with an Australian Export Award in 1996. Blundstone will continue to invest in new equipment and technology and become more competitive, but that relies on Australia's trading partners falling into line and all participants competing on a level playing field. They have indicated that part of their operation may be forced offshore if the recommendations of the draft report are followed.

I must say that no other country put its textiles, clothing and footwear industries under the sort of pressure that the Labor Party put Australia's industries under. Slow reductions are easier for the industry to cope with. With some slow adjustments, natural attrition can be relied upon to reduce some of the work force. But, with rapid adjustment, employers could be forced to retrench employees or close their doors. We have already seen some of that because of the fear of the Industry Commission's attitude towards textiles.

I think what is important in Tasmania—and this is generally true on the mainland—is that a large percentage of their work force are young and female. Should these people lose their jobs, they are not readily able to pack their families up and go to Melbourne or to another centre. Many of these people have husbands who work in other industries. Tasmania has the highest unemployment rate in Australia, and jobs are scarce for the unskilled. So it is rather difficult.

I point out to the Senate that most of the large gains to be expected from reducing tariffs further and at such speed have already been achieved. Australian manufacturers have been forced to improve quality and upgrade technology, and Australia's purchasers of TCF products are very much closer to world prices now than they were a decade ago, so gains to consumers in the future will be much more modest, but lower protection in the future will generate large job losses.

I put it to the Senate that the Australian textiles, clothing and footwear industries should not be expected to operate unprotected while transport, waterfront and communications industries, to name but a few, are reforming very slowly. If the TCF industries in Australia are to be internationally competitive, these other issues must also be addressed, and addressed at perhaps the same speed.

Very few companies would be in a position to achieve 10 to 20 per cent productivity increases in a year or two, and yet this is exactly what a sudden reduction in protection would require companies to achieve in order to survive. I remind the Senate that once an industry and factories are wiped out, it is almost impossible to re‐establish them. Time must be allowed for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries to adjust; otherwise increasing competition from imports will continue to cause them to contract.

The Industry Commission's findings fly in the face of the Mortimer recommendations. Mortimer says, `Go for growth and the role of the business programs in investment, innovation and export.' The Mortimer report provides a framework for the government to achieve a goal which all Australians can share in. There must be a level playing field. This is important.

But there is a problem. The Industry Commission should pause further tariff reductions after the year 2000 at their 2000 levels until at least the year 2005, when there should be a re‐examination of the progress that has been made. I believe that many of the conclusions that have been arrived at by the Industry Commission were very subjective indeed. Only a small change in some of those matters which it relied upon could have a large impact in terms of output. At a national level, it is predicted that the investment between 2000 and 2005 could drop from a projected $84 million to $9 million if the IC's recommendations were to be adopted.

BREAK.PARA: Another quick word on the assumptions on which the IC's calculations were made: they were very subjective and not scientific. Small variations in these assumptions could actually change the cost to Australian consumers from the IC quoted figure of $20,000 per employee to just $2,540 per employee. The other thing is that we must take into account the social, unemployment and underemployment costs arising from the IC's recommendations. It must have a wider concern across the whole community, taking into account other than just economic factors.

What is disappointing is the crocodile tears which are now coming from the Australian Labor Party, because these come in respect of an industry which that party has done so much in the last 25 years to destroy. I admit much of what Senator Cook had to say; however, the textiles, clothing and footwear industries are not well set up to be the vanguard of world trade reforms. The difficulties so many businesses find themselves in today are the result of the policies imposed on them by the previous Labor government, in which Senator Cook was a major player.

Until very recently, Senator Cook was a prime advocate of continuing tariff reductions and the internationalisation of the economy, including the textile industry. While I welcome his change of heart, one must at the same time consider it hypocritical, particularly as thousands of people have lost their jobs as a result of those policies. Naturally, he was formerly committed to tariff reductions. Senator Cook and his colleagues are now trying to commit to a caring attitude towards those workers. I acknowledge that caring attitude, but where was that caring attitude 13 years previously—or even in the last 25 years—because between 1988 and 1994—

TALK.START.PARA: —Where was Captain Zero? What policy did you run on in 1993?

—Your Labor government, Senator Conroy, allowed factory employment to fall by 32 per cent overall, employment to fall by 20 per cent and manufacturing output to fall by 24 per cent. The Labor government failed Australia's textiles, clothing and footwear industries, it failed the work force and it failed the industries' export objectives.

BREAK.PARA: Our government, the coalition government, now has the task of providing for a caring, pragmatic policy for these industries which will guide them through the necessary changes over the next decade without sacrificing them to join the hundreds of thousands of unemployed people who became permanent fixtures in this country through 13 years of Labor government—and many more as a result of the policies of the earlier Whitlam government. As I said earlier, it is an important industry for Tasmania. Those people need respect from government. They expect to operate and to live in a dignified way.

I naturally have a serious personal interest in this matter—and I suppose I must declare an interest—being a former employee within the textile industry. But these industries must be given a fair chance to survive, to prosper and to profit from the restructuring that has taken place. The result will then be that these people can work and continue to find satisfying employment and security well into the next century.

I continue to have very vivid memories of the catastrophic results in my home city of Launceston, which suffered from the overnight reduction of the 25 per cent across-the-board tariff cuts and revaluations of the dollar which cut a swathe through employment in Australia, and particularly in my city of Launceston.

But the textile industry still survives. It deserves to survive. It has undergone many, many changes, with improved efficiencies. In fact, if you look at many of the efficiencies in textiles, they rank pretty high by world standards. And when you start comparing our performance with Asian performances per employee, Australian efficiencies rank well, even with the so-called lower paid Asian populations employed in textiles.

Australia has nothing to gain and plenty to lose by being in the vanguard of further tariff reforms, so a pause is necessary. I believe our government will deliver a pragmatic outcome, somewhat similar to that achieved in the motor car industry where the motor car industry can now see a future. That was certainly good news for Launceston, where the very efficient, export orientated ACL Bearing Company is actually putting on extra staff as a result of that decision, and the motor car industry generally has re‐invested. We have seen a good result from Toyota, which would never have been possible without a pragmatic decision by the Liberal‐National Party coalition in relation to the motor car industry.

We must carefully monitor the reforms of our major competitors or we are seriously at risk of simply exporting the jobs of Australian workers. We have done that too often in the past and that must not be allowed to continue. So we must have a slow progress towards lower tariffs. At the same time, we must have a close monitoring of the ongoing effects which will permit the industry to adapt and plan for its future. As I mentioned earlier, many of the large gains possible through restructuring and reform have already been achieved. How much more are you going to expect from Australian woollen mills in terms of their restructuring, change of ownership, change of location and so on?

Many Australian businesses have now greatly improved technology and productivity, compared with some decades ago. There would be very few industries which could achieve this 10 to 20 per cent extra productivity over the period of a year or two at this stage. As a result, I believe that the industry should receive a pragmatic treatment, and it deserves such. It has done a lot to cope with the change, to keep alive, to keep going and to keep people employed. But unlike the opposition, who think they can gain short-term credibility from performing backflips, our government will provide a program on which the TCF sector can draw confidence into the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to be part of this debate and, in particular, to be able to follow on from the comments made by Senator John Watson, because he, I dare say of anybody in this chamber, is acutely aware of the problems that have arisen in the past in relation to this industry, such as when tariffs were dealt with in the way they were under the previous Whitlam government.

SPEECH.PARA: Many Australians will recall what happened during the Gough Whitlam era in relation to the reduction of tariffs. If you want to know why the electorate of Bass fell at the 1975 by‐election and then was retained as a Liberal seat for so long, it was a result of the Labor Party's dealing with tariffs, because it was felt very, very severely by the people of Tasmania.

It seems somewhat strange that the Labor Party should therefore come into this chamber with that sort of record and move a motion of this nature. What we need to do is remember what certain people in the past, such as Mr Crean, have told us. He said:
No-one understands better than Labor that the tariff war has been fought and won. After all, it was Labor that fought and won it.
So the Labor Party in the past have tried to claim credit for changes in relation to tariffs. We were told also by Mr Crean that:
Labor is not proposing to restore the high tariff barriers of the past or keep them in existing levels indefinitely.

The Labor Party pursued a policy which was clearly a policy of reducing tariffs. Part and parcel of that was the deal that they did with the DuPont factory, which in recent times has closed down. Senators might recall that $60 million of taxpayers' funds were introduced into that factory to save 160 jobs and, because they did not stitch the deal up properly, the factory closed anyway. If you have a look at that for a job subsidy, it really is a very high level of subsidisation. The motion before us, as I have indicated, really is one that highlights the hypocrisy of the Australian Labor Party when it is put into the context of the way that Labor have dealt with this issue in the past.

It is important to set the record straight: everybody is talking about the recommendations of a commission which is a report to government, not of government. The final report is due out on 9 September. The government will then consider that final report and make a decision. The government has made no decision whatsoever at this stage. Any factories that are closing down, such as Berlei or DuPont, are closing down as a result of Labor policies that are still in force.

We, as a government, have studied the Industry Commission draft report very carefully. We will also study their final report very carefully. But then we, as the government, will make the final decision for the benefit of all Australians, and that is something that has to be recognised and remembered. There are certain elements within the community that are seeking to suggest that the draft report, which is the topic of discussion these days, is in fact a government decision. It is not a government decision and it is a decision that we will consider in detail and determine.

I think the people of Australia can feel confident that we will deal with this issue in a mature and considered manner. After all, there were similar recommendations from this commission in relation to the car industry. We, as a government, did not fully embrace those recommendations. We looked at them and factored them in with the socioeconomic factors as well and made a decision which will see a reduction in tariffs. We also ensured ongoing investment in the vital car industry to the extent that Toyota has announced a $1 billion plant and investment. They are the sorts of decisions this government makes. Sure, it gets reports to advise itself but then it factors in the socioeconomic matters as well to ensure that a good outcome is arrived at.

It ought be remembered that tariffs per se are not necessarily good economically. What you have to remember is that ultimately a tariff is a tax. Every product that is protected by tariffs within this country means that the consumer, the Australian public, has to pay more for that particular item. Therefore, you are making the consumers, our fellow Australians, buy product for higher prices. As a result, it is quite a sensible and responsible economic policy to pursue to try to seek a reduction in those tariffs no matter in what industry they might apply.

However, you have to do it in a sensible way so that industry can adjust—readjust its work force and its investments and ensure that it is able to meet the competitive factors of overseas imports once those tariffs are reduced. It is therefore appropriate, in my submission, that we reduce tariffs, not overnight, as the previous Whitlam government did, but wean industry off tariffs slowly but surely so that ultimately the Australian people can benefit with lower priced items.

We should remember that these tariffs do impact on our exporting capacities and capabilities. For example, the tariff on the car industry adds to the costs of a motor vehicle in this country. Therefore, every business that uses a motor vehicle in this country for the purposes of production for export has to factor that extra increased price into its cost when it seeks to export its product overseas. Therefore, by that extent, the product that they manufacture is so much less competitive than it otherwise would be. They are some of the factors that need to be understood.

I note in recent times that there have been newly formed political parties suggesting we ought to have tariffs in relation to virtually everything and nothing to protect Australian industry. Just keep in mind that if we were to go down that path it would in fact be a tax on every single Australian citizen who had to buy those products at inflated prices. Remember that if the people of Australia can buy those products at a cheaper price they would therefore have more money left over in their pocket to be able to spend on other domestic items, so that money would not simply be lost to the economy.
In typical style, I note that there is an amendment from our friends the Australian Democrats suggesting that there should be a freeze on TCF tariff reductions effective immediately.

TALK.START.PARA: —You agree of course.

—Senator Murray says, `You agree of course.' I have to say to you, Senator Murray, you are jumping the gun. All you are doing is responding to a draft report. It may well be that the commission makes that very recommendation to us as a government, but we do not know because they have not reported yet. The final report still has not come down, but Senator Murray can second guess the commission. He knows better and he is going to determine that that ought be the case. He does not tell us for how long that freeze ought to be on.
—If you listened to my speech you would know.

—It does not say so in the motion, Senator Murray. That is one of the dangerous things with the Democrats: they will put one thing in a motion and say something different in their supporting speech. That is why you can never actually pin them down on anything, and they are a moving feast when it comes to policy.

SPEECH.PARA: It ill behoves this parliament to try to second guess the final report. I think it is appropriate that the government be given sufficient time to consider that report and to come down with a considered opinion and policy response to that report. With respect to the amendment of the Australian Democrats, it really is jumping the gun and not wanting to hear all the evidence that might be available. I would hope and trust that the Australian Democrats will still have a sufficiently open mind that they are able to listen and consider the Industry Commission's final report and develop a response to that rather than closing off all options as they seem to want to do in their amendment.

This Democrat amendment is in the same vein as the comments made by the shadow industry minister, Mr Crean, who has sought to be critical of the government for, to use his words, `letting the thing drift; they failed to follow up and get commitments from the companies' then demanding that the government force DuPont to honour its commitments. How can we let the thing drift when the final report isn't even down yet? It really is a ludicrous suggestion to say, when you commission somebody and they put down a draft report, `We won't wait for their final report. We ought to come down with our policy decision before that commission has had the opportunity to factor in all of the community response.'

It is interesting that he made those comments in relation to DuPont which, in fact, is a classic example of what happens when you simply try to subsidise an industry such as DuPont and they close down anyway after $60 million worth of taxpayers' money for 160 jobs. If you divide that $60 million by 160 jobs, it is an interesting exercise. How much subsidy per job is that? Have you ever stopped to think about that, Senator Murray? If you have a calculator, work it out and you would be surprised.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us; tell us.

—It is $375,000. It is a very challenging figure. When you think about that, you start to realise that trying to pick winners and losers in this industry game is not a very clever policy. What you need is a general policy but one that is sensitive to the social and economic needs of this country.
—Captain Zero!

—There is a would‐be‐if‐he‐could‐be on the other side who interjects with the term `Captain Zero'. Undoubtedly he is looking at a portrait of Mr Gough Whitlam somewhere because that is exactly what he did to the industry which so devastated the people of Bass back in 1975.

SPEECH.PARA: So it ill behoves the Australian Labor Party to think that somehow they have the right policy mix. If you have a look at the result of Berlei and if you have a look at the result of DuPont under Labor policy, they are closing down. They are the results of Labor policy. Yet have a look at what we did in the car industry and you get a $1 billion investment. That is a good result, a great result, for everybody and it will ultimately mean cheaper cars for the consumers of Australia.

The Australian Labor Party is absolutely scared that we on this side of the chamber are going to do another good, sensible deal like we did with the car industry. So they are trying to get in first to try to champion the cause. But, of course, the Labor Party's record in this area is so abysmal that nobody is going to believe them or even suggest that they are going to regain any credibility in this policy area.
Our record is a very good record. Let me just remind the Senate of what the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) said only yesterday. He said:
. . . when the government receives the final report—
and I stress that that still has not been received yet—
it will take a speedy decision, as it did with the motor manufacturing industry.

We are already on record as saying that we will act speedily as we did with the motor manufacturing industry. That was such a good policy result that you people are so upset by it. The Prime Minister continued:
And in taking that decision, it will certainly pay very strong regard to the interests of employees in that industry.

That is the bottom line. The Prime Minister has given that commitment and the people of Australia can feel satisfied that that is going to be the policy outcome as it was with the car industry. As the Prime Minister went on to say:
I regard the closure of factories like Berlei as being not only a tragedy for the employees, a tragedy for the City of Lithgow, but a tragedy for the region.

That is our concern. We have shared it and put it on the public record with the Australian people. We have shown our credentials in relation to the motor vehicle industry. We are accepted in the Australian community as doing the right thing in relation to tariffs. I am sure that everybody in their heart of hearts in this place knows that it is bad economic policy to simply perpetuate tariffs without giving consideration to their reduction to ensure benefits for the Australian consumers at large.

Our policy, very simply, is one of responsibility, one of consideration and one of taking everything on board to ensure that whatever decision is taken will be one that factors into account all those competing interests—consumers wanting cheaper prices and consumers wanting a choice of a range of goods at affordable prices—whilst also ensuring the viability of Australian based industries which, at the moment, rely on tariffs, and which will be able to continue in a regime with lower tariffs if they are slowly weened off them to provide the sorts of results that we in Australia all look forward to.
The people of Australia will see through the shallowness and shabbiness of the motion moved by Senator Cook. I am pleased to be associated with this government's tariff policies.
