SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I highlight that this committee report on access to medical records was undertaken in recent times and is vitally important, because it deals with the issue of who owns medical records. There is a great deal of debate that has been going on in society as to who owns access to medical records.

SPEECH.PARA: I was the chair for the initial part of these hearings, and found this to be of a great deal of interest. There were some within the medical profession who had a great deal of problem with this and who were adamant that they had ownership of the records. There was some hesitancy on the part of a number of people to give their patients access to records, because they had certain fears. Interestingly, some of these concerns were expressed by groups that you would have thought would express less concern than some other groups.

Psychiatrists deal with people who have mental illness and who may have a problem accepting and understanding their condition. They may well be in a fairly severe delusional state of mind which may include paranoia and psychoses. They may even have thoughts of self‐harm or harm to other people. However, psychiatrists were not as opposed as I think a number of people would have thought to their patients getting access to medical records. A number of psychiatrists wished to have support provided to the patient when the patient looked at the information that was contained in their medical record, and somebody available—maybe themselves or somebody else—to provide an explanation as to what the situation was. It was a very interesting situation in that the college and the psychiatrists understood and supported the need for their patients to understand their medical condition.

We also had some interesting submissions and evidence from lawyers. They felt that it could be beneficial if there was greater access to medical records in situations where the relationship between the doctor and the patient had broken down. At the moment, if patients want to look at their reports and their medical records and are unable to do so, sometimes the only way to do so is by instigating litigation.

There was concern on the part of the doctors that greater access to medical records would bring about increased litigation. But there was concern, and evidence was given by legal authorities, that people are often forced to undertake legal proceedings to get access to their medical records at the discovery stage of legal proceedings. If they were able to get access to their medical records prior to instigating legal proceedings, the situation would be explained to them: that there is no way that lawyers would advise them to undertake expensive and time consuming legal action. As this community becomes more litigious that situation has to be borne in mind. It is a very interesting professional judgment that a lot of people have to make. I have difficulty understanding why people are totally opposed to patients and clients knowing what is written in their medical and personal records, because what is written there is about the patient, about the person.

Evidence was given that people would use cryptic comments, would feel more constrained in what they write and would resort to having two sets of records. One has to wonder, though, about the medico‐legal aspects of this issue and the fact that all records can be summonsed or subpoenaed to be brought to court. One has to wonder about the fact that people are saying they will write less in records. There is a legal requirement for people to write full records. As someone who has written medical records, I would have thought it would be a polite requirement on the part of people when they do write their records that what they write is absolutely complete. There are ways to write some of these records: you do not have to make value judgments, and you should not make subjective judgments about people. You can write down the signs and symptoms and what the patient is complaining of without using whatever sort of slang term is current.

I have seen medical records—certainly going back a number of years—with terms like `PF' written down. That means `purely functional' in polite terminology—it had other less polite terms. I was always concerned when I saw that sort of comment written on medical records, because subsequently there were a number of occasions when the patient actually did have a serious, complex or very discrete and obscure disease, and when the use of the letters `PF' would have caused quite significant problems for the medical personnel if they ended up in a court of law.

If they had documented accurately and precisely the signs and symptoms about which the patient was complaining and left it up to people to make a judgment based on objective signs and the patient's subjective symptoms of which they were complaining, then you would have got a more accurate picture of the patient. You would not have got a value judgment and you might have got a speedier diagnosis and therefore speedier treatment for some people who have required major forms of treatment.

It is an issue of major concern. I think people should have access to their medical records. I think many doctors these days are certainly very aware of this matter and do go to great lengths to make sure that their patients understand what is written in the files. That has to be the situation because we are wanting people to have greater compliance with treatment orders, and we are wanting people to have greater understanding of the treatments they are to undertake and the consequences and interactions of drugs, diagnoses and multiple diagnoses.

The only way you can do that is if the patient has a significant understanding of their disease and of the treatment. Often, with some of the more obscure, rare diseases, it is the patient who develops a level of expertise about their own illness which many doctors do not fully have. If someone with an obscure, rare and difficult medical condition has spent 20 years having it diagnosed and finally settling on a treatment that works, the patient, in all likelihood, will know what the results of their tests should be, what their medications should be and what will interact with what for them, with their own idiosyncratic reactions. So I think it is vitally important.

I have to express some concerns about one or two of the witnesses who appeared before us. There were one or two who had very condescending attitudes, who said they would not tell a patient if there had been a little more bleeding than normal. They would tell patients a lot less; they would tell patients what they thought the patient needed to know. That is a very unfortunate attitude on the part of some in the medical profession. I am sure that Senator Herron, who is present in the chamber, would join me in saying it is the attitude of a very small number of doctors but, unfortunately, there are some out there.

I think it is vitally important that patients do have access to their medical records and that the cuts that are taking place to the workloads of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and the Privacy Commissioner do not impact upon this government having a policy and implementing a legislative framework within which this can work. This is an issue of great significance to people, particularly those with chronic illness. For people who have only a one‐off illness, it might not be so much of a problem. Certainly, for people with chronic illness, the evidence we heard showed that it is a major problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not like to engage in persiflage in discussing this report but it would not surprise me to learn that some will finagle their records and give the old yo‐ho to those who scrutinise them.
—How come you got the words before I did?
—In one sentence!

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 June, on motion by Senator McKiernan:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a few words with regard to the second report of the Legal and Constitutional References Committee on the Australian legal aid system. This gives me a chance to highlight yet again the implications of government cuts to legal aid and the type of effect that has had on people's personal lives.

SPEECH.PARA: This government seems to think that working people, women who have suffered domestic violence and so on, access legal aid to engage in average, day‐to‐day persiflage or to say to legal aid lawyers, `Look, yo‐ho, I'm here, I'm going to sue the next door neighbour because his or her dog barks at night.' The reality is that legal aid is far more serious than that. It ought to be a right. It is not in the nature of average Australian citizens to finagle their way into a legal aid office and engage in frivolous litigation. It is a very serious matter. Many states have attempted to point out to the federal government that the cuts to legal aid have affected their budgets most seriously. We well recall the comments of many state premiers from both sides of politics in that regard.

It is worth highlighting that one of the major difficulties with the cuts to legal aid is in the area of domestic violence. Many women now have nowhere to go. Many women now have no access to litigation. Many women now have no access to no‐cost legal care where they are in a relationship which has a domestic violence element to it. Of course, whether it comes under federal or state jurisdiction is still under debate.

I think it is a great shame and it adds to the litany of woe that this government has perpetrated upon Australian women with regard to a number of regressive and retrograde measures. There are the cuts to legal aid funding and child care. I refer also to the new industrial relations bill, which impacts most severely upon women. I could go on and on. Cuts to higher education have impacted on women disproportionately, and so on.

I think it is worth highlighting that this severe budget measure is having an impact now. It is impacting disproportionately on women. We regard this measure as regressive and retrograde. It is something that we will ensure will be addressed when we get back into government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I heard the shadow parliamentary secretary speaking on this subject and that is what brought me to the chamber. Senator Conroy was about to summons me. I thank him for that. I start by congratulating the Australian Labor Party for choosing Senator Mackay and Senator Lundy, an eminent senator from the Australian Capital Territory, as shadow parliamentary secretaries. I should add to the list Mr Kelvin Thomson, a member of the House of Representatives, whose selection is almost as good as the two in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Mackay has said, the issue of legal aid is very important. It is not simply a matter of trying to provide people who need representation with that representation but is a matter of how our legal system is going to work. We can take the criminal system as an example. By and large the prosecution in any criminal trial will be well resourced. The same cannot be said, in every case, for the defence of the accused. It is bad that a contest—and that is what it is in the adversarial system—which may well conclude in someone losing his or her liberties should be conducted unevenly between the parties.

In the field of criminal law, it is that concept that makes it necessary that there is equality between the parties. In other words, society has an obligation not only to see that people who are accused of criminal offences are properly prosecuted but also to see that those people are also properly defended. Otherwise, the concept of justice which underpins the society we live in is denied.

I will now address some of the issues that Senator Mackay raised. There may be a contest where a woman has proper grounds for fearing for her life and limb and fearing for the life and limb of her children. Clearly, the woman and the children should be properly represented and so should the husband against whom the accusations have been brought.

Some fearful accusations can be made and unless people are properly defended that can cause great concern. Take for example the issue of paedophilia, which is a matter that concerns the public generally. That crime was traditionally called the crime of a rock spider. People who are convicted of the offence of violating young children are very badly treated in gaol. It is only proper that anybody convicted of that offence is convicted using the proper processes. It would be dreadful if someone accused of that crime were convicted of that crime—with all the consequences to his or her life—without the proper process being followed. The issue of legal aid goes to the question of justice.

There are budgetary restraints. There is always a demand for resources. I see that Senator Herron is in the chamber. In his area, indigenous people clearly need more resources. If there is one thing that a society should deliver its citizens it is justice. In England, and it is from that place that we generally derived the system under which we live, the king had three functions—making the law, carrying out the law and providing justice. Those three arms were separated out, particularly in the American constitution. That has set the modern plan for good government, which is that those three functions should be separated. Those three functions are basic to government. They are what governance is all about. If a society cannot provide those three basic elements it fails.

Government does fail in providing justice if it allows people to go into a legal contest without there being some semblance at least of equality between the parties. You can never get absolute equality. There are going to be differences in the sort of representation that is available, but there ought to be a balance that is sufficient to satisfy a reasonable onlooker and make them say, `Yes, there is justice being done in this case.'

That is not happening at the moment because people have not got the resources to properly exercise their rights, to properly make a defence of their position or, alternatively, to vindicate their position. It is important, therefore, that we as a national parliament keep wrestling with, not the issue of legal aid—that is part of what we should be wrestling with—but this necessity to provide a fair system under which we all may live. We are presently doing that.

The person who sits next to me, Senator McKiernan, is presently conducting an inquiry through the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee on this very point. I hope it is productive. People across the party line are working very hard at it. Senator Abetz is the deputy chairman of that committee. I hope and expect that great things will come from that inquiry. They need to so that we can see that the government under which we live—when I talk about `government', I am talking about the three arms of government—is properly conducted in this country.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 June, on motion by Senator O'Chee:
That the Senate take note of the reports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I am speaking on the report of the Public Works Committee entitled Decontamination for disposal of the former Albion explosives factory site, Deer Park, Victoria . I urge everybody to read this report. It is very important.

SPEECH.PARA: In this report there is a situation which is a shame on Victoria and a shame on the processes of the government in Victoria. In 1930 an explosives factory was opened at Deer Park. It was state of the art at that time, but over the years it became run down because it did not have enough investment. The government took the decision in 1985 to close it and transfer the work to New South Wales.

In 1986 a consultative committee was established and there were public hearings. All sorts of groups made submissions, including the Brimbank City Council, ICI, the Delfin Property Group and—I guarantee this is true—Friends of the Striped Legless Lizard Inc.
What you have seen is a waste of 10 years. We had the consultative committee come up with its proposals to redevelop the site as mainly residential, with some parks as well as light commercial.

TALK.START.PARA: —It sounds a bit snaky to me—a striped legless lizard.
—It is true, Senator Patterson, the Friends of the Striped Legless Lizard Inc.
—Does that mean that the lizard was drunk?
—It could be, Senator O'Chee. Because those parks are not developed today, we do not have children playing in the parks—and nowadays parks include swings, roundabouts and xylophones.
—I have never seen a park with a xylophone in it.

—You obviously do not go to enough parks nowadays, Senator Herron. The original clean‐up bill was only around $5 million, and the decontamination continues 10 years on. We have had the ULA sitting on its hands in Melbourne.
—It's a wonder they have any hands. They are not legless and they are not handless people.

—Thank you, Senator Patterson. The clean‐ up has not been completed and this is a shame on both the Commonwealth and the state government, because both parties are involved. This is not a reflection on any individual party and it is not a question of being partisan. The western suburbs of Melbourne have many roads that are unsealed, and many streets have lighting which would be of more use if they were just table lamps. People have ignored that situation for too long.

SPEECH.PARA: Fifteen recommendations came out of this report and, unfortunately, not enough of them have been followed up. They talk about tree lines and a black powder mill, and existing structures which should be demolished. They look at expert advice on the remediation options. But there has not been enough commitment from the state and federal governments. The need to decontaminate this area is still there. I invite senators—including Senator Patterson—when visiting Melbourne to go to Deer Park, to have a look around and to see for themselves what has continued to be a waste.

Can you imagine if children—young girls—went out there in their taffeta dresses in among all that contamination? It would be a tragedy. They have had to fence the area off and because of that it has become extremely run down and almost like a tip.

I urge senators to read this report and to encourage their federal and state colleagues to get behind this project so that they can improve the lifestyles of people in the western suburbs of Melbourne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased that Senator Conroy raised the issue of Deer Park. The factories out at Deer Park were quite famous. During wartime, they did a lot of production which was necessary for the defence efforts of Australia, and I know that from personal knowledge because at that stage I was going to the Deer Park state school which was in the local hall, the former Deer Park state school having burnt down. There is a new one there now and Deer Park has expanded. It used to be well out in the bush in those days. It made a great contribution to Australia's war effort in the 1939‐45 conflict.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember people used to go to work in the munition factory, as we used to call it, when they were 14. I remember at the time that children used to make all sorts of interesting things with explosives—not weapons, but they would put gunpowder between two bolts which were held together by a nut, throw it on the road and there would be explosions. That shows, perhaps, the dangerous enthusiasm of youth. Fortunately, I was not old enough then to work in a factory.

Listening to Senator Conroy brought back those memories and I think he is right. I think there ought to be a lot of work done to preserve a site in the western suburbs which is quite historic. Listening to him made me quite sad that it had not been treated as well as it might, given its war service. The report makes me nostalgic for days that now seem romantic and are very long ago. I would like to see the recommendations of that report carried out.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 June 1997, on motion by Senator West:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —The report on the development of Australia's air links with Latin America is important. It arises out of work which the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee started in about 1991‐92 when we did an inquiry into Australia's relationships with Latin America. Prior to then, a lot of people's understanding of Latin America was very persiflageous—one of Carmen Miranda and that was about it. People had no understanding of it being a very important conti nent and one that, in trading relations, can have a significant impact on and relationship with Australia. One of the findings from that initial report was that transport links, particularly air links, between Australia and Latin America are difficult. They are sparse and, I think it is fair to say, not terribly well pursued from the Australian point of view, particularly back then.

SPEECH.PARA: The report focused people's minds on a very important part of the world—our neighbours on the other side of the Pacific Ocean—and highlighted some of the difficulties that they were experiencing or that were impeding our relationships. There were about 11 recommendations made in this report and I am pleased to see that the government accepts and supports a lot of them, which will be important in continuing the important links between this country and Latin America.

In recent times, we have seen a significant increase in some areas of trade and manufacturing industry. We have seen the Australian mining sector discover Latin America and have a significant input into many of the mines over there and into developing relationships with the countries and companies to be able to exploit and bring to fruition many of the mines. You see BHP with l'Escondida and you see a lot of other areas where there is significant prospecting being undertaken. This is not just of importance to Australia; it is of significance to the Latin‐American countries as well.

From a tourism point of view, Australia is not a large tourism market. The number of people of Latin-American origin living in this country is not particularly large. One of the reasons for that probably does relate to things such as transport links between the two continents, but there is potential there for tourists from Latin America to visit Australia.

This potential can only be realised if the air services do improve. There are several flights a week from Buenos Aires through to Australia via New Zealand, but the majority of people probably end up having to fly from Sydney or Melbourne into Papeete and Tahiti and then across. With the connection in Papeete, you may be faced with a 10- or 12-hour or an even longer delay, which is not the most conducive incentive for people to travel. Business people also have many complaints.

Another way to fly—particularly to the eastern coast of Latin America, the South American continent—is to fly from here to Los Angeles and then to Miami and then down, particularly if you are flying to Brazil. Those are long trips. It takes more than 30 hours to fly. That is very tiring, and it is not particularly conducive to encouraging travel.

One aspect which needs to be taken into account in our relations is the language in Latin America. Spanish and Portuguese are the two languages spoken. I think this reflects poorly on Australians in that we do not have the correct attitude towards learning other languages. We expect and assume that people will all speak English. We forget that Spanish, English and Chinese are the three most commonly spoken languages in the world. Not necessarily this report, but I think the other report certainly highlighted the need for the Australian education system to undertake and encourage Australian students to learn another language.

There were issues of fifth freedom rights in relation to Aerolineas Argentinas and their being able to fly beyond New Zealand. The government will consider this in any market, based on an assessment of the additional benefits to Australia through the provision of lower fare levels, higher service quality and other gains. This is an area where the air fare costs tend not to be part of the large discounting that occurs in a number of other air routes that are operating out of Australia, such as to the UK and some of the Asian ports. So I think it certainly behoves the industry and the government to look to ways that can be conducive to a fare regime that makes it more accessible to people to travel.

I think the committee's report and the committee's ongoing interest in Australia's Latin-American relations has been significant in bringing this important area of the world to the front of people's minds—to encourage the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to focus on the importance of Latin America. We are certainly seeing at this present time that we are competing with them in a number of areas. As I said earlier, they have benefited from the expertise from our mining companies. We are a competitor, of course, in the mining industry. We are a competitor with Chile in the wine industry and the exporting of wine, particularly to Europe. It will certainly provide competition for the Australian vintners to meet that challenge. So it is an important industry. It is an important market for Australia. It is an important group of countries for us to understand.

I am delighted that this report has had quite a number of favourable responses from the government. It is an issue. Latin-American relations are something that the Senate committee has, as I say, pursued for about five or six years now. I think they will continue to pursue it, because it is an important area. Australians need to remember that it is reasonably close to us. It certainly is in the same hemisphere. Therefore, we understand a number of their climatic conditions and, because of their industry similarities, a number of the problems and the challenges that they face. So I would commend the report and the government response to people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —While this response cannot be considered persiflage, it certainly is not a series of responses I would have expected. I would have thought that the government, in their response, would have been far more aggressive, particularly when we consider ourselves to be so close in a sense to the Latin-American nations.

SPEECH.PARA: I note in the response by the government that they do acknowledge that there are significant future opportunities for increased business activity, tourism and investment. They do talk about bilateral air service agreements with both Chile and Argentina. There is also a draft agreement with Brazil. However, I do not believe that the response by the government, whilst it refers to things such as hubbing and opportunities that are there, really addresses the issues that are raised in the original report.

There is no doubt that, if one looks at chapter 3, for example, one gets an idea of the increasing market that is coming forth there. Chapter 3 is about passengers, and there are a number of questions that are raised: who are they, how many are there and where are they going? You do not have to say, `Yo-ho, come over here.'

The facts speak for themselves. From 1981 to 1994, we saw a growth in passenger movements between Australia and South America: Argentina 8.96 per cent; Brazil 7.92 per cent; Chile 7.5 per cent; and others 4.56 per cent—with a total growth of 7.14 per cent. But specifically in the years 1993 to 1995 Argentina showed an increase of 45 per cent, Brazil 45 per cent and Chile 21 per cent. There is definitely no need for us to finagle our way into the Latin‐American market. They will undoubtedly welcome us with open arms as part of the broader Pacific community.

I do not believe this is sufficiently well addressed in this report. I believe that the report shows a severe amount of verbosity, without getting down to the real central issue that—as my colleague Senator West has said—people currently have to go via Papeete, and that that is not good enough if we are to be an emerging nation not only in the Asian region but in areas such as Latin America which are vastly untapped by us. The report recognises the opportunities that are available there for the Australian people and the Australian government, and the response, whilst it goes part of the way to recognising that we need to do more, does not go far enough.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I address my comments to the annual report of the University of Canberra. I do so on the basis that this particular institution forms a significant part of Canberra's educational community. At a time when the Canberra economy is experiencing great challenges, it is our educational institutions that continue to be pillars, if you like, in providing some stability for the economic future of the town.

The University of Canberra is unique in many respects. I would like to pay tribute to one of the programs that exists within the Faculty of Management, and that is the Centre for Regional and Local Government Studies. This centre has done some incredibly important work in focusing some academic substance on the concept of regional studies and, in particular, on regional economic development.

While this government will continue to finagle the confidence of regional Australia, what we have here in the Centre for Regional and Local Government Studies is something which is getting out the nuts and bolts of the parts of initiatives that make up comprehensive regional development plans. Having previously been a member of the regional economic development organisation for Canberra and the south‐east region of New South Wales, the absolute importance of this type of work is clear to me. As part of my comments, I would first like to recognise the significant work of that centre.

Another comment I would like to make with respect to the University of Canberra is about the student support structures on campus. Having recently visited the university during the University of Canberra's `Do you see green?' week, which focused on environment initiatives and a whole range of activities relating specifically to the university's environmental programs, it became very clear to me that the child‐care cuts initiated by the federal government have impacted severely on the student support services with respect to the child‐care centre on campus, Kirinari.

The loss of the operational subsidy to that particular centre has put real pressure on the service it provides. It is the mature age students—predominantly women, but also many men—on campus who find the additional costs the straw that breaks their weekly budget's back when it comes to their choice or opportunity to enter tertiary education.

I say to this government in that respect: how about you look beyond the persiflage of your own rhetoric with respect to child care and have a look at how it is impacting upon real people, in this case the students, and particularly the mature age students, at the University of Canberra, and the disadvantages that they are now suffering as a result of those cuts.

BREAK.PARA: I would also like to recognise the fact that two people were awarded honorary doctorates at the University of Canberra this year—Donald Richmond Horne and Phillip William Hughes—in recognition of their work in that regard in 1996. Also, to everyone in the students association at the University of Canberra, I give a big yo-ho. You are doing a great job out there. I would like to say to everybody involved in the students association at the University of Canberra that you are doing a terrific job and your contribution to that particular educational institution is worthy of recognition in this place.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 June, on motion by Senator Forshaw:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —This report is a result of an inquiry that was conducted by the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee earlier this year. When I last spoke about this report, I mentioned some concerns I had about the difficulties that were expressed to us in relation to the grief experienced by families as a result of deaths overseas. That was not the sole focus of the report. There were a number of other recommendations in that report, and I would hope at some stage to see a considered view of them from the government.

SPEECH.PARA: Those recommendations touched a number of issues which one could not take lightly but which a lot of Australians do not necessarily take great cognisance of when they travel. In particular, I refer to travellers taking out adequate insurance cover, because this can affect people, particularly if death is experienced overseas.

One of the things that was drawn to our attention during the inquiry was the very heavy costs associated with bringing a dead person back from overseas. Whilst people do not like to think about that side of life—or death to be more precise—nonetheless, it was very important that this issue came out in the inquiry as quite substantial costs are involved.

If this inquiry serves no other purpose or if my addressing this chamber this evening serves no other purpose than to draw the attention of the Australian public to the fact that they should take out adequate insurance, then something would have been achieved. In the recommendation, there is also an urging to have this done through the travel agencies, because it is something that people are just not in any way cognisant of, and it is something that is very important indeed.

The other thing that I found interesting in the report was the fact that the committee recognised there was a need to institute a formal counselling program for consular officers as soon as possible when they have been in touch with members of the public who have suffered a loss overseas. I think this was highly admirable, and I am sure it is one of the recommendations that the government will respond to in a positive way.

On a lighter side though, there were some interesting expectations expressed to us of how the Australian tourist overseas sees the role of the Australian embassy or the Australian high commission. In one instance, it was reported to us that some Australians had an expectation that, at grand final time, the Australian embassy or high commission would make available to them a direct telecast of the Aussie Rules grand final. Whilst that might be a highly laudable and praiseworthy task for the embassies and high commissions to undertake, it certainly is not one of their duties or roles. Some Australians, unfortunately, have a distorted view of the role and the function of our embassies and high commissions overseas.

So the report in itself, which touches a wide range of issues, is something which is highly worth reading. I trust that the government will give us some very positive responses to a report that was arrived at in a fairly harmonious way.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for this debate has expired.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT —I propose the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak to this government's commitment to listening to the women of Australia and to addressing the real issues for Australian women. Today and yesterday I had the great pleasure of meeting with women's organisations present here in Canberra for the national women's round table consultations, organised by the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, Senator Jocelyn Newman. Never before—certainly never under Labor—have women had a two‐day opportunity to network and meet with members, senators, ministers, advisers and departmental officials. For example, today the minister had organised for advisers from various departments, and senior staff from ministers' offices, to come and meet with the women to discuss issues in an informal way over lunch. Every opportunity was used to make sure they had as much contact with government as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not hyperbole to say that many of the women attending have been frankly stunned that the federal Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women actually stayed and listened to what they had to say. The national women's round table is only one of the consultative mechanisms put into place by this government. The major mechanism for Australian women to put their concerns to government is the massive number of coalition women listening and consulting with their constituents all over Australia.

In my own home state of Victoria, women make up the majority of the Liberal Senate team. And we had no dodgy quotas. We did not have to ask the union men or the faction hard men for permission to take our places here and in the other place. The coalition rewards merit—and merit alone earned the record number of coalition women their places at the table.

The minister has appointed a number of these coalition women to a parliamentary advisory group, of which I am the Victorian representative. Like all of my colleagues on the parliamentary advisory group, I have been busy meeting and consulting with women in my state, listening to the concerns of Victorian women and feeding them back to the minister. At the same time I have had the support of the state minister responsible for the status of women, who has sent either her senior adviser or one of the senior departmental officers to also list the issues of state and federal concerns or state concerns alone.

One of the concerns I have heard from many of the women I have met with over the last few months has been the concern about older women in the Australian community. I have been pleased to advise them that this government shares their concerns and that we have addressed Labor's shameful neglect of older women. Older women were the forgotten women under Labor. In the glamour and hoopla of Mr Keating's smoke and mirrors women's policy, they were not even thrown the bone of a meaningless quota. After all, the biggest thing women ever got under Labor was a quota, with a commitment to fulfilling that quota entirely optional.

I want to take this opportunity to address this government's commitment to older women and particularly the ways in which we will continue to help them achieve financial security in later life. By 2020, one in every four Australian women will be over 55. As the number of older people as a proportion of the population increases, so will the number of older women as a proportion of the older population. Latest figures show that there are 76 men for every 100 women in the 65‐plus age group and only 42 men for every 100 women in the 85‐plus age group.

In the mass media, if she is mentioned at all, the older woman is often portrayed as a social vampire—frail, dependent and requiring expensive care in a residential nursing facility. Older women are depicted either as a collec tion of symptoms or as an object of pity and scorn.

Those of us who were at the dinner last night, hosted by Minister Newman, and saw the Older Women's Network theatre group performing would have realised that all those myths, all those stereotypes, are wrong. They are the most energetic, lively group of people who put through theatre their living of life, despite for some of them disabilities with arthritis and other health problems that may have reduced their physical ability. But their spirit was strong and the message they had for all of us there was that there was a lot of living to do if you were an older person and, in particular, if you were an older woman.

For 10 years I campaigned against the inequity of compulsory retirement in the Commonwealth Public Service. I introduced into this place two private members' bills across two parliamentary sessions and hardly raised a headline. I got no support from the Labor Party or from the Democrats. There was always some feeble excuse about the fact that we could not cope with compensation for people over 65 with Workcare, Comcare and whatever else. It was an inadequate response. All the other states had managed to do it. Yet always Labor came up with some sort of hurdle that meant they were unable or unwilling to do it, and the Democrats went along with it. I regretted that for a long time. I thought it was a private member's bill that had a great deal of merit. So the same groups who so noisily protested at any attempt at discrimination against young women or working women, as they rightly should, were inexplicably mute when it came to protecting the rights of older Australians.

Older women working in the Public Service, many of whom had interrupted careers with child bearing, wished to keep working to compensate for lost earnings due to caring earlier in their careers. Yet no group sprang to their defence, no‐one lobbied on their behalf and no-one supported me, other than my colleagues on this side of the chamber, in my attempts to redress what I thought was a discriminatory part of the Public Service Act. More than anything, this proved to me the tacit acceptance of discrimination against older people which exists in Australian society and the deeper disinterest in the aspirations of older women.

Last night when the Older Women's Network were doing their performance one line they used was that age is an activity practised by the temporarily young. I thought how right they were. The government has broken ranks with Labor inaction and implemented real and effective changes for older women. The new Public Service Act before this parliament will eliminate that discriminatory aspect of making people retire when they reach 65.

The deferred pension bonus plan is also an important thing for older women. It was introduced in the last budget by the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman. It recognises that some women who have broken their careers with their caring responsibilities may wish to continue participating in the work force. Under the plan, people who choose to keep on working, defer the taking up of an age or service pension and continue to work for at least 25 hours a week, will accrue a bonus of 9.4 per cent of his or her basic pension entitlement. This bonus will accrue for each year of employment beyond age or service pension age up to a maximum of five years. The bonus will be paid as a lump sum on pension take‐up and will be tax exempt.

The potential value of this to older women, particularly an older woman who has been widowed or divorced, cannot be overestimated. Sixteen per cent of women aged 60 to 64 years and 71 per cent of women aged 85 years and over are widows. Forty per cent of women aged 65 and over live alone with sole financial responsibility for the upkeep of their homes.

The maximum bonus of $21,251 for a single pensioner and $34,450 for a couple could be used to pay for major expenditures before retirement. We have also worked out that, if it was depleted over a period, it would provide a significant amount on an annual basis for the emergency things such as roofing, hot water services or whatever else that tend to breakdown and that are very difficult to repair when you are on a pension. Whether it is getting rid of the old clunker car and getting a new one or getting the house repainted or the roof repaired, this plan can be used by older women to make the major expenditures they could never otherwise afford, giving them peace of mind and security in retirement. Of course it will not be taken up by everyone, but it is there and it is a choice and it is an option.

There are many other developments that have come into place such as the guarantee for the aged pension, savings rebate and other measures which we have introduced. One of the other things is that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has appointed a conference for older Australians to address the issue of the International Year of Older Persons in 1999. We will be consulting with the community to look for ways and means in which we can address issues that affect older people, particularly older women—issues such as flexibility in housing and other areas of concern. It demonstrates that we are a government which is concerned about older women. (Time expired)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: South Australia: Leader of the Opposition

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday on two occasions I read into the Hansard record of the Senate material relating to the case between Mike Rann, the Leader of the Opposition in South Australia, as the plaintiff, and the Premier of South Australia, Mr Olsen, as the defendant, in a defamation case.
—Did you get a headline?

—You should have a seen it. It was a ripper today, an absolute ripper. I will come back to that in a moment, Senator Macdonald. I have already read some of it into the record of the Hansard because the government refused permission for me to table these documents. In view of Senator Macdonald's remarks, I would have to say that I thank the government now for not letting me table it because the coverage I got as a result in today's Adelaide Advertiser was much greater than if you had allowed me to table it because everybody in South Australia, including the Advertiser , believes the govern ment has something to hide in this case on behalf of Mr Olsen.

SPEECH.PARA: I have already read into the Hansard the statement of claim by Mr Rann. I am halfway through reading the rejoinder from Mr Olsen, a document dated 21 August 1997. I continue now to read in the extract starting at 10.1. It states:

10.1 As to paragraph 2.10 of the Reply, the defendant has no recollection of discussing the EDS contract with Foley as alleged but says that if it was discussed, no improper exchange of information occurred.
10.2 As to the letter of 14 October 1996 from Brown to Hansen & Yuncken, the defendant denies providing or acquiescing in the provision of that letter to Foley.
10.3 The defendant does not know and cannot admit that Foley provided the document to the plaintiff.
10.4 The defendant does not know and cannot admit that the plaintiff formed the view that the defendant was seeking to undermine Brown's leadership.
10.5 The plaintiff does not know and cannot admit that the plaintiff formed the view that the defendant was the source of the document.
10.6 The defendant says that he did nothing which entitled the plaintiff to form a proper belief that the defendant was the source of the document or was seeking to undermine Brown's leadership.

11.1 As to paragraph 2.11 of the Reply, the defendant does not know and cannot admit that on or about 6 November 1996 Foley received an unmarked envelope containing cut up sections of what appeared to be a Cabinet submission relating to the EDS North Terrace building.
11.2 The defendant does not know and cannot admit that Foley provided the subject document to the plaintiff advising that the document was from the defendant.

11.3 The defendant says that he did not provide or acquiesce in the provision of the document to Foley or the plaintiff, nor did the defendant do anything which could entitle the plaintiff to form a proper belief that the defendant had provided or acquiesced in the provision of the document.
12.1 As to paragraph 2.12 of the Reply, the defendant says that he attended an event at the Powerhouse at Findon associated with the Greek Orthodox church on 10 November 1996.
12.2 The defendant says no such conversation with the plaintiff took place as alleged.
13. As to paragraph 2.13 of the Reply, the defendant says that no such conversation with the plaintiff took place as alleged.
14.1 As to paragraph 2.14 of the Reply, the defendant does not know and cannot admit that on 27 November 1996 Foley asked a number of questions as alleged.
14.2 The defendant denies that any material used by Foley included information provided by the defendant and further denies that he had provided information to Foley over a long period of time.

14.3 The defendant does not know and cannot admit the content of any discussion between Foley and the plaintiff, but says that the defendant did nothing which entitled the plaintiff to form a proper belief that he had provided or acquiesced in the provision of confidential information.

15.1 As to paragraph 2.15 of the Reply, the defendant admits that on 27 November 1996 Brown lost the leadership of the Liberal party to the defendant and further admits that a short time later the defendant gave a news conference on the front steps of Parliament House.
15.2 The defendant admits that shortly thereafter the plaintiff spoke with the defendant and congratulated him on his election.

15.3 The defendant denies that the plaintiff said to the defendant words to the following effect: `Don't forget who put you there' or that the defendant responded to the plaintiff with a smile in response thereto.

15.4 The defendant says that he did nothing which entitled the plaintiff to form a proper belief that the defendant had been the source of confidential information to the plaintiff or another Opposition Member of Parliament.
16. Save for the admissions contained herein, the defendant joins issue with each and every allegation set out in the Reply.

That is the end of that rejoinder from Mr Olsen. There are two other documents that were from the court which I do not think it is necessary to read in, because they deal with the formal procedures of the court. Of course, Senator Macdonald, if you wish me to table them, give me leave to do so and I will do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, no, go on!
—Order! Senator Macdonald, you are not in your seat.

—I also point out that the document Senator Ferguson and Senator Ferris read from yesterday in the parliament in defence of Mr Olsen is a press statement that Mr Olsen issued, not a court document. I was also refused leave to have that tabled yesterday. The most extraordinary episode: the Liberal Party refused to allow a press statement from their own Premier of South Australia to be tabled in the parliament and then they were forced in the adjournment debate last night to stand up and read sections of it out to try to defend their Premier. That was the stupidity of the Liberal Party.

—On a point of order: Senator Schacht has just referred to the contribution I made in the adjournment debate last night and said that I read out a press release. In fact, I was reading out a declaration by Mr Ian Kowalick. It was not a press release.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—I point out that that statement by Mr Kowalick was attached to John Olsen's press release and was issued accordingly. I wish you would get your facts right, Senator Ferris.
—Senator Schacht, would you like to address the chair, please?
—I put those remarks through you, Madam Deputy President.
—Just put them to me, not through me.

—I also want to point out that yesterday, when the government whip refused me permission to table these documents because of orders on high from somewhere else, he in fact did my side of the story immeasurable benefit. Why? As soon as he refused to allow it to be tabled, the press and everybody believed that there is a cover-up going on here, and the reporting of the story in the Advertiser today, I have to say, exceeded my expectations, particularly the headline `Howard covers up for Olsen'. What a great headline that was, and it was all because of the stupidity of the government whip and the leadership of the Liberal Party in this Senate in refusing to allow me to table the document.

SPEECH.PARA: In the coverage the Advertiser gave, they also pointed out my remarks on the conflict of interest—that is, the firm that advised the Advertiser, Minter Ellison, is also the firm advising the Premier. I put it correctly in context that they had received advice that there was no conflict of interest. That was reported accurately in the Advertiser this morning.

The only part of the documents that I put into Hansard yesterday that I was disappointed did not get a mention—and I hope it will get a mention in the future—is the extraordinary defence of the Premier, saying, `I didn't give information to Mr Rann about the Catch Tim donation scandal.' It was given to Mr Rann by one Alex Kennedy, then a journalist with the Messenger Press in Adelaide, who had formerly been employed by former Senator Olsen, who was employed for a short time by Senator Ferguson, who then went and worked for the Messenger Press and spent those two or three years dumping heaps of vitriol on Mr Brown as the Premier. Within a month or so of becoming the Premier of South Australia, John Olsen re‐employed Alex Kennedy as his chief speech writer and senior adviser.

We are expected through Liberal denials to believe there is no division in the Liberal Party in South Australia and that Mr Olsen, Mr Brown and their supporters are not leaking against each other. It is an extraordinary episode in South Australian political history, even Australian political history, when the Liberal Party, the Liberal government, is cannibalising itself the way it is at the moment.

I conclude by saying, again, that I thank Senator Calvert as government whip for refusing me leave to table the documents. I think next time round he will get better advice. I would also like to say that, now this issue is before the public in South Australia, they will see what a dreadful, divided government the Olsen government is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —This is my second adjournment speech on this subject—that is, the Kimberley region. On Monday night this week, I spoke about the growing sense of concern that this remarkable region is going to be caught up in a development frenzy which is misplaced and which has the potential to result in us as a community losing far more than we gain. If currently proposed developments go ahead, the character and quality of the region will be changed more rapidly and more permanently than ever before.

SPEECH.PARA: Here is a short list of planned or proposed developments: plans to greatly expand the Ord River irrigation scheme; plans for the damming of the Fitzroy River, the largest river in the Kimberley and one of Australia's few remaining large wild rivers; plans for a major irrigation area and cotton growing industry potentially covering some 200,000 hectares in the Pindan plains south of Broome; the trucking of large volumes of lead‐zinc concentrates through Derby to be shipped out of King Sound; ongoing proposals for aquaculture and tourism developments around the coast; plans for a tidal power station in mangrove creeks near Derby; and the possibility of several new mines in different parts of the region, including the prospect of a bauxite mine on the acclaimed Mitchell Plateau.

Apart from such particular projects, increasing human access and activity across the region will bring with it a range of other severe environmental consequences. These include damage caused by increasing numbers of tourists visiting largely unmanaged and fragile natural environments, wildlife smuggling, widespread and frequent human lit bushfires and the introduction and spread of exotic and feral pest species.

To a large extent, the major development projects referred to are being considered in isolation. Open-ended ad hoc development seems to be the order of the day as government and industry work hand in glove to ensure the go-ahead for projects which have enormous environmental, social and cultural implications for the region as a whole. While a number of these development projects may benefit the state or Australia, how can we assess them unless proper coordination, evaluation and assessment processes are conducted and, what is more, unless assessments are done independently, not by the proponents?

No overall sustainable development strategy is being given serious consideration. For example, while the major environmental costs and lessons of stage 1 of the Ord River dam and irrigation scheme have never been assessed, the state government is rushing to try to open up a further 60,000 hectares of Ord irrigated land in the east Kimberley. Our view is assessment first, project later. The state government's view is project first, assessment later. The fee takers and commission makers are once again leading this government in Western Australia by the nose.

The potential impacts of this project alone on internationally important wetlands at the mouth of the Ord, on riparian habitats, on ground water levels and salinity, on levels of pesticides and fertiliser in soils and waters, are alarming. If this project continues to be pushed in the way it currently is, there is a very real chance that future generations will be left with long-term costs that rival the problems now evident as a result of the ill-considered agricultural expansionism in the south‐west of Western Australia. At present rates of government inaction and weakness, much of the south‐west is economically doomed because of salinity.

The efforts that are being made at a state level on the environment front, notably the preparation of a regional conservation plan by the WA Department of Conservation and Land Management—also known to me as Genghis CALM—and some limited localised assessments by the WA Department of the Environment, are unlikely to amount to more than tokenism. The current political climate, coupled with a dismal history of previous government conservation efforts, and the totally inadequate budgets of CALM and the DEP—the Department of Environmental Planning—all suggest a lack of any real commitment to environmental protection in the Kimberley or any real commitment to economic sustainability that delivers long-term benefit to the region.

The wider public meanwhile is barely aware that the character of the Kimberley is in the process of being irretrievably changed over a matter of just a couple of decades. It is difficult for people to comprehend environmental fragility, but the Kimberley has many fragile areas, with conservation values of recognised national and international importance at stake. We have now reached a critical point in the region's history, a point at which a strong national interest must be taken. Without strong national interest—inside federal parliament and state parliament and outside in the community—a narrow, short‐term and ultimately self‐defeating form of development looks likely to prevail, and the public interest will lose as a result.

I urge the Senate and the Commonwealth government to take active leadership in shaping the future of this remarkable and beautiful region of Australia. By all means let us have development, but let it be carefully considered, consultative, well planned and with an agreed framework that takes proper account of and meets the needs of the region's environment, the Aboriginal traditional owners, the wider community, and future generations.

The first step must be to address the lack of coordinated and objective policies and strategies for ecologically and economically sustainable development. It must be to address the lack of sound regional planning, and it must be to address environmental protection and the lack of resources to implement environmental protection. In the meantime, while these fundamentals are put in place, we should seek to have the types of large‐scale industrial developments discussed above put on hold. We can always come back to them later if they are found to have merit, but we will not be able to repair the damage they do if they are rushed ahead with and later found to have been big mistakes, as many Australian big bang projects have been.

Before I close, I would like to dwell briefly on the response of Senator Eggleston to my first adjournment speech on this matter. He made a number of remarks. I think he has to understand that what we are talking about here is an appraisal of all these development schemes on a coordinated regional basis before the projects go ahead. We are also talking about putting those appraisals in the hands of independent and objective analysts and not in the hands of those who will in fact benefit from the very schemes that they are appraising and doing their feasibilities on.

Senator Eggleston referred to the water of the Fitzroy as `not utilised'. The Fitzroy River ecosystem, from the headwaters to King Sound, uses all the waters of the river. It is adapted to and relies on seasonal flooding and the seasonal drying of the river. Harvesting this water will necessarily have many impacts. Some of those impacts might well be beneficial, but many may not. You cannot regard this as a waste area where the water is just going to waste. It is very much part of the entire environment there.

He also referred to—here we have the big numbers that the Liberals love—`the food and fibre crops to generate at least $900 million a year'. I would have thought it would have been far better to have said that that would feed a certain number of people. But the real value to the Liberals is the amount of money involved, not the amount of value to human beings and whether it would generate food and work.

We do not know how the market for cotton will continue, especially with more and more producers coming into the market. We also do not know whether other products proposed to be grown could survive or thrive or be saleable and sold, or would be better alternatives to cotton. What we do know is that cotton has some serious environmental drawbacks, and there are many ways in which, in this environment, such crops may never succeed. So when you talk about $900 million a year, it really is a thumb suck at this stage of evaluation.

Senator Eggleston went on and said that `no appraisal is being undertaken'. That is a deliberate misrepresentation of what I had said. What I said was that no appraisal had been undertaken with regard to the whole spectrum of Kimberley development proposals, not just the Fitzroy project. I also said that the evaluation of the Fitzroy project, at this stage, was inadequate and elementary and needed to be far better done.

He mentioned the WAI, the organisation that is to do this feasibility study. He said, `It is WAI's plan to harvest 25 per cent of the annual flow. . . '. Once a dam is built, even though WAI's intention may be to use 25 per cent, other developers may well then come forward wanting a slice of the action. That happened in the Murray-Darling scenario, which is now one of acute degradation and real danger to Australia's breadbasket. Either way, the percentage of annual flow that is to be dealt with does not matter all that much, because once dams are constructed, an irreversible process of development and destruction can be set in motion. (Time expired)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Alice Springs to Darwin Railway Line

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferris, Sen Jeannie

TALK.START.PARA: —When is a promise not a promise? What does trust have to do with truth? In May 1983 the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, promised the people of Australia that only his Labor government could be trusted to build the Alice Springs to Darwin railway line. He made a promise, he gave an undertaking, an assurance. He offered trust, a firm belief, a confidence based on expectation. In fact, he laid his credibility on the line—the railway line. Just 10 months later it became another of his broken promises. In March 1984 Prime Minister Hawke described the railway as `totally unrealistic and uneconomic'. Of course, he was not the first Labor Prime Minister to make promises and give undertakings on this particular issue. More than half a century before, in 1910, Labor Prime Minister Andrew Fisher made another national promise. He even passed legislation to specifically fund the completion of the north‐south rail link. Now we know the answer: a promise is not a promise when it is made by the Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: The truth of this matter is that the Labor Party was never really committed to the railway link. Former Senator Peter Walsh described it as a `waste of money' and `a white elephant'. Former Treasurer John Dawkins called it `a crazy idea'. Even the dethroned emperor himself could not work out why South Australians wanted a railway at all. A wacky comment if ever I heard one.

Madam Deputy President, only this government has made a commitment, an undertaking, that we will put some money where their mouth was. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has put $100 million beside the commitments of the Northern Territory and South Australian governments. So, 87 years after it was first promised by the Fisher Labor government, the Alice to Darwin railway can finally be built.

I was privileged to be with friends and colleagues last weekend when the Prime Minister stood with my own state Premier, John Olsen, and the Northern Territory's Chief Minister, Shane Stone, to become the first government to specifically and financially commit to this visionary national project. By the end of the year 2002 our nation will be linked north to south and east to west by a railway traversing some of our most ancient and starkly beautiful landscapes. This is the second key project stemming from the Federation Fund established to support major national objectives, providing much needed infrastructure and creating vital jobs for our young people.

There are obvious benefits: a rapid competitive rail system, an important opportunity to provide alternative transport for our developing mineral and resource processing in the very rich Gawler Craton in my home state of South Australia. The rapidly expanding markets of Asia will have speedy access to the fresh produce of the farmers of South Australia. We will offer the opportunity to develop the world's best practice rail link.

Tonight, Madam Deputy President, I ask you and all other members of this parliament to pause for a moment to consider the small South Australian community of Port Augusta; a town ravaged by unemployment stemming from the disgraceful mismanagement of Australia National by the previous government. Members of the Senate committee looking at the sale of AN heard quite a heartbreaking story in evidence during a visit to Port Augusta: breakdown of families, domestic violence and financial tragedy stemming from the tide of joblessness that washed over the railway workshops under the Labor Party's reign.

Today the community has regained a little more hope, a slight sense of optimism flowing not only from this announcement but from the benefits arising from the sale of Australia National which was announced today. The news that AN will be sold for $95 million is especially good news for the businesses and the families of Port Augusta. Under the new arrangements, Port Augusta will become a principal engineering hub, and the existing workshops will expand to take in other work—a breath of life for a small country town and its families after years of disgraceful neglect by the previous government.

Whyalla, also a city feeling the cold winds of change and joblessness, stands to benefit from the steel needed for this very important new national rail project. One hundred and fifty‐five thousand tonnes of steel rail and 3,500 tonnes of structural steel will be required to build the Alice Springs‐Darwin railway. As well, 9.2 million spring steel fasteners and 2.3 million sleepers using 170,000 tonnes of steel will be needed for the project.

The weekend announcement of this exciting new national project to link Australia's north and south has given a much needed boost to my home state of South Australia. Our government's announcement at the weekend interestingly enough reflects the quite realistic view, I think, of the former Premier of New South Wales, Neville Wran. In 1995 he said:
.. the (Alice Springs/Darwin) railway will become economically viable early next century.
We have made the promise of $100 million to build this railway. It is a promise that we, unlike those opposite, plan to keep.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I speak in relation to the important issue of the sinking of the HMAS Sydney on 19‐20 November 1941. This has been one of the most intriguing unsolved mysteries of World War II. But thanks to the work of the families and friends of the 645 naval personnel whose lives were lost, we now have the government responding to community pressure to form a parliamentary inquiry into the Sydney . Groups such as End Secrecy on Sydney are calling for a full judicial inquiry and believe there has been an official retelling of the Sydney story which hides controversial facts. There is a fear that the parliamentary inquiry may add to the retelling of the official story of the sinking of the HMAS Sydney in 1941. They will, obviously, be looking at the events of the inquiry very carefully.

SPEECH.PARA: The official versus the unofficial history is: in the dark hours of 19‐20 November 1941, Australian light cruiser HMAS Sydney, with a total complement of 645 personnel, was lost to enemy action in coastal waters off the north‐west of Australia. The sinking, with an official claim of no survivors—not even a floating corpse—has been listed as one of the strangest maritime mysteries on record.

The End Secrecy on Sydney Group have a series of statutory declarations which I have circulated to the two whips. They are asking for a judicial inquiry. At this stage a parliamentary inquiry is, hopefully, coming up. It means that those people will be watching to make sure that that parliamentary inquiry is full, open and frank, and that the information is as independently available as possible. I seek leave to table the documents. They are: the notice of request to the Australian government for a judicial inquiry, and statutory declarations and other documents related to concerns for those relatives and friends who would like to see the inquiry being as full as possible.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In 56 years there never has been an investigation into those 645 presumed dead, or into the circumstances claimed to have led to those deaths. The Australian community has never been comfortable with the so‐called enemy account, to the extent that yesterday the government called for an inquiry.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission: Appeals

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 7 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Since the enactment of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Act 1986, Racial Discrimination Act 1975, Sex Discrimination Act 1984 and the Disability Discrimination Act 1992, how many decisions of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (HREOC) have been appealed by the Commonwealth.
(2) Which cases have been appealed.
(3) When were each of these cases appealed.

(5) Of the cases appealed by the Commonwealth, what did each of these appeals cost the Commonwealth.
