QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 20 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In what ways would implementation of the Wik `10-point' plan alter the capacity of governments to influence environmental management of leasehold lands.
(2) What additional activities could pastoralists undertake on leasehold land under the lease upgrading proposed in the Wik 10-point plan
(3) What reduction in public rights to access information about environmental values or to participate in land management decisions would result if the Wik 10-point plan were implemented.
(4) If the Wik 10-point plan were implemented, would leaseholders whose tenure was upgraded as a result be able to apply for Natural Heritage Trust Funding.
(5) Is there any documented evidence about whether environmental outcomes, for example, rate of clearing of native vegetation, are better or worse on freehold compared with leasehold land.
(6) Will the Minister require an environmental impact statement to be prepared for the Wik 10-point plan.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Under the 10-point plan, existing Commonwealth, state and territory legislation for land, heritage, land use planning and environmental management will remain in place and must still be complied with. The capacity of governments regarding environmental management of leasehold land is unaffected. The Prime Minister has made it clear there will be no blanket freeholding of pastoral leases at taxpayer expense.

(2) The 10-point plan does not propose blanket upgrading of pastoral lease titles. Under the existing Native Title Act 1994, states and territories can already acquire native title rights if they do it through non-discriminatory means. This will continue. The Commonwealth understands that state and territory governments do not intend to undertake large scale upgrading of pastoral leases to freehold through the acquisition of native title rights. The Prime Minister has said however, that the Commonwealth financial assistance offer will require any lessee gaining an additional benefit to pay a proper financial contribution.

Under the 10-point plan, holders of pastoral leases would be unimpeded by native title in carrying out primary production activities that are permitted under the terms of their leases, or by government permit or legislation. Grants of additional primary production rights on pastoral leases will not extinguish native title. Activities that are associated or incidental to primary production, including farmstay tourism would be permissible provided that the dominant land use remains primary production and that such activities are permitted under the terms of the lease. As noted in the response to part (1) above, such activities by pastoral leaseholders remain subject to state and territory environmental land management and other laws and regulations.

(3) The 10-point plan does not affect public access to information or the ability to participate in land management decisions. Under alternative state or territory-based regimes that might be established, native title holders will have the same procedural rights as the pastoral leaseholder in relation to compulsory acquisition and development on pastoral lease land.
(4) The 10-point plan does not affect the administration of Natural Heritage Trust funding.

(5) My Department is not aware of any research that compares native vegetation clearing rates between comparable properties with differing tenure arrangements. In the absence of such comparative information, it is not possible to draw conclusions about the effect of particular tenure systems on these types of environmental outcomes.

(6) The action Minister for this purpose is the Prime Minister. He has advised me that, after considering advice, he has decided not to designate a proponent under the Administrative Procedures approved under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 in relation to the decision to proceed with legislation to implement the 10-point plan.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission: Funding

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 20 June 1997

QUESTION.PARA: (1) (a) What cuts are being proposed for the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (HREOC) between now and 30 June 1999; and (b) what is the estimated impact on staff, programs and services.

(2) Will the Disability Commissioner be replaced when the present commissioner's term expires in July 1997; if so, will the responsibilities of that office remain the same; if not, what changes are proposed.

(3) With reference to the Attorney-General's press release of 15 May 1997, which stated that HREOC had received a 500 per cent increase in funding since 1988: (a) what additional responsibilities have been given to HREOC since 1988; and (b) what was the budgeted cost of each of these responsibilities.

(4) With reference to the fact that the Attorney-General refers to the changes to HREOC as reflecting `difficult financial times': why are the proposed cuts so much in excess of the 4 per cent efficiency dividend experienced elsewhere in the public sector.

(5) (a) How do the proposed cuts intend to reform HREOC functions, given that there is currently at least a 6 month wait for the commencement of conciliation of cases; and (b) how will the cuts improve the lives of people with disabilities.

(6) Has Australia assumed a number of international responsibilities and obligations with respect to human rights and equal opportunity; if so, please provide a list of these obligations and explanations as to how these obligations are to be met given the proposed Government decision to drastically cut funds to HREOC.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) In the 1996/97 Budget a $1.5 million saving to the HREOC budget was announced. The reduction applies as a result of the proposal, contained in the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill 1996, to transfer the HREOC hearing function to the Federal Court. As that Bill is still awaiting passage, the Department of Finance has agreed that the reduction in funding will not apply until the function has been transferred to the Federal Court.
The reduction to HREOC funding in this financial year (1997/98) is, in real terms, only the 4% efficiency saving applicable to all agencies within the Attorney-General's portfolio.

A further reduction in HREOC funding in subsequent years (1998/99 and beyond) amounts in real terms to approximately a 27% reduction—not the 40% or more some people have claimed. However, this reduction must be seen in light of the fourfold increase in HREOC funding over the past nine years.

(b) In evidence to the Senate Estimates Committee on 10 June 1997, the Commission indicated that it will refocus its activities and concentrate re sources on its main statutory functions, and in particular, on complaint handling. While the Commission has indicated that it expects to lose up to one third of its staff, the bulk of this loss will come from areas other than complaint handling.

(2) The present Disability Discrimination Commissioner's term does not expire in July 1997, but in December 1997. There is no suggestion that the current term of office of the Disability Discrimination Commissioner is under threat and no decision has been made on a replacement for the Commissioner when her term expires at the end of this year.

As Senator Neal would be aware, the functions of the Human Rights, Race, Sex and Disability Discrimination Commissioners will be changed by the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill which is currently before the Senate. The major change involves the transfer of the complaint conciliation function to the President, and the complaint hearing function to the Federal Court, the latter change being brought about by the High Court's decision in the Brandy case.

The Attorney-General has indicated that the Government will be considering further changes to the structure of HREOC. However, no decision has been made by the Government in this respect. Australians with disabilities can be assured that any changes to the structure to HREOC will not diminish the capacity of HREOC to uphold the principles of the Disability Discrimination Act.
(3) Major ongoing additions to the HREOC jurisdiction since 1988 include:
- Administration of the Privacy Act—0.60 million
- Establishment of the Aboriginal And Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner and Unit—0.38 million
- Administration of the Disability Discrimination Act—0.93 million
- Administration of amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act—0.88 million
- Administration of amendments to the Privacy Act—2.19 million

(4) The government has been forced to reconsider expenditure in a wide range of areas. In determining expenditure reductions, the Government has made appropriate judgments in relation to capacity to bear reductions and priorities.
(5) It is not the proposed cuts, but the legislation currently before the Senate that will reform the structure and functions of the Commission.

The Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill will consolidate the divergent complaint handling regimes in various Acts into one simplified scheme with common definitions and best practice pro cedural provisions. This regime has then been placed in the one Act with the President responsible for all complaint handling. Centralising responsibility will assist in promoting consistent and coordinated practices for all complaints.

The Bill also vests responsibility for the administration of the Commission in the office of the President. Those changes are designed to clarify the lines of responsibility and should lead to more consistent and coordinated management practices.
The Commissioners, freed from their role in conciliation and complaint handling, will continue to undertake, on behalf of the Commission, a range of important functions including:
‐ the development of standards, guidelines and action plans;
‐ the preparation and undertaking of educational programs;
‐ undertaking research; examining enactments;
‐ reporting to the Minister; and
‐ applying as an amicus curiae or intervener, with leave of the Court, in proceedings relating to discrimination.

As indicated in the answer to question 1 above, the proposed cuts do not apply to any particular area in the Commission and are not intended to have a particular impact on any one group. The reduction in funding will mean that the Commission will need to refocus its activities and concentrate resources on its main statutory functions, and in particular, on complaint handling.

(6) Yes, Australia has assumed responsibilities with respect to human rights and equal opportunity under a number of international instruments. The list below indicates the major Commonwealth human rights Acts and related international instruments.
Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986
Convention Concerning Discrimination in Respect of Employment and Occupation, (ILO 111).
International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
The Convention and Declaration on the Rights of the Child.
Declaration on the Elimination of All Forms of Intolerance and of Discrimination
Based on Religion or Belief.
Declaration on the Rights of Disabled Persons.
Declaration on the Rights of Mentally Retarded Persons.
Racial Discrimination Act 1975
Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination.
Sex Discrimination Act 1984
Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women.

The complaint based regimes established under each of the Commonwealth anti-discrimination Acts will continue to apply to complaints alleging a breach of human rights or discrimination. The changes proposed in the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill, including the creation of a uniform regime for discrimination complaints and the centralisation of responsibility for complaint handling in the office of the President will promote more consistent and coordinated practices and therefore assist in fulfilling Australia's responsibilities under these instruments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 27 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What impact would the proposed expansion of the Shark Bay Salt Joint Venture works in Useless Inlet on the edge of the Shark Bay World Heritage Area have on the values of the World Heritage Area.
(2) How close will the expanded works, if approved, be to the World Heritage Area.
(3) What Commonwealth environmental impact assessments of the proposed expansion of the Shark Bay Joint Venture works have been conducted.

(4) Is the Minister aware of a scientific report prepared for the Denham Fisherman's Association which indicates that the expanded salt works will have a range of serious impacts on the values of the World Heritage Area, including on the area's rich diversity of marine fauna.
(5) What is the Minister's response to the report, written by Dr Shelley Burgin.

(6) Is it a fact that a recent survey of the World Heritage marine environment immediately adjacent to the salt project area, believed to have been undertaken by the Department of Conservation and Land Management and utilising the Denham-based charger boat James Shearer, identified unique coral species or formations; if so, what efforts will be made to investigate whether such unique coral species or formations may occur within the expanded salt lease area.
(7) When are the construction works for the expanded salt project due to commence.
(8) Is it a fact that more than 35 kilometres of coastline within or adjacent to the Shark Bay World Heritage Area is now committed to salt industry leases and works.
(9) What measures will the Minister be taking to ensure that the existing salt industry operations, and any expansion of that industry, do not cause damage to the Shark Bay World Heritage Area.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 19 December 1996, I wrote to the then WA Minister for Environment, the Hon Peter Foss QC MLC, seeking his assurance that the environmental assessment processes undertaken by the State had adequately addressed potential off-site impacts of the proposal, and that there would be no significant impact on the outstanding universal values of the Shark Bay World Heritage Property.

On 20 March 1997, I received a letter from the current WA Minister for Environment, Mrs Cheryl Edwardes, assuring me that any potential impacts on the World Heritage values of the Shark Bay World Heritage Property had been identified and would be minimised by ensuring that the project is carried out in accordance with environmental conditions set out for the proposal in August 1996. I am satisfied that there will be no significant impact on the outstanding universal values of the Shark Bay World Heritage Property.
(2) The proposed expansion of the Shark Bay Joint Venture works, if approved, will be approximately 300 metres from the boundary of the Shark Bay World Heritage Property.
(3) There is no involvement at the Commonwealth level to trigger the application of the Commonwealth Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 (`the Act').

(4—5) Yes. I have been informed that the issues raised in the report were investigated during the environmental assessment process, and were addressed in the Environment Management Plan for the construction phase of the project. They will also be addressed in the Environmental Management Plans for the operational and decommissioning stages of the project.

(6) It is my understanding that, in August 1996, the WA Department of Conservation and Land Management (`CALM') conducted a marine monitoring site selection field trip in the Shark Bay Joint Venture works lease area. One coral patch was recorded (through drop-down video recorder footage) in waters transitional between oceanic salinity (35-40 parts per thousand) and metahaline salinity (40-56 parts per thousand).
CALM has advised my department that the coral identified were not unique species or formations.
(7) The WA Department of Conservation and Land Management has informed my department that the construction works are likely to commence in August 1997.
(8) The Shark Bay Joint Venture works includes approximately 35 kilometres of coastline. All of this coastline was excluded from the Shark Bay World Heritage Property.

(9) As noted above, I have a responsibility to ensure that impacts of activities adjacent to the Shark Bay World Heritage Property (`the Property') do not extend into the Property and pose a threat to its outstanding universal value. I take this responsibility seriously and have sought assurances from the Western Australian Government that these potential impacts have been adequately addressed. In addition these issues will be addressed by the Commonwealth through its involvement in the development and implementation of management plans for the Property.
